original_note:
B197
B197 is 24 years old. She is referred by XXXX, DDS. Her orthodontist is XXXX, DDS MS, 10319.
Primary concerns that B197 has include the following

Extreme tooth sensitivity.
Widespread enamel loss along gum line.
Excessive wear on teeth.
Front teeth chipping.
Clenching and grinding of teeth at night.

B197 has no significant TMJ issues. She had orthodontics from ages 13 to 16 with Dr. XXXX. A year or two after her orthodontics were completed, she began developing sensitivity in her teeth and her teeth began to wear. She began hitting more predominantly on her front teeth and began having enamel coming off of her teeth. She developed some periodontal problems around some of her teeth. She even had pain brushing her teeth. She also began developing cavities. She eventually had periodontal surgery on the lower anterior arch last year. She had a mouth guard made to wear at night 8 months ago. More recently, two weeks ago, she had sinus surgery and reduction turbinectomies. Her sinus problem was predominantly in the right sinus with almost complete opacification of that sinus.

B197 has type 1 diabetes and also Hashimoto's thyroiditis. She takes the following medications:
Novolog insulin.
Synthroid.
B197 has no problems with headaches, TMJ pain, and no myofascial pain. She rates her jaw function, diet, and disability all at 0. She gets occasional earaches, but no other joints bother. She is aware of clenching and bruxing at nighttime, but does not believe that she does it during the day. She feels that her chin may be a little bit more prominent now than it was a few years ago.

In frontal view, B197 has good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 16 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 1 mm. The maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. The nasal tip is just slightly to the right side about 1 or 2 mm. The mandibular dental midline is about 1 mm off to the left side as is the chin. In profile view, she has an obtuse nasolabial angle with the nasal tip turned up some. She may have some slight AP maxillary deficiency of maybe 2 mm. Chin is a little bit prominent by about 5 to 6 mm. The chin neckline is somewhat elongated a little bit. Chin neck angle is well defined. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower arch. She has some gingival grafting performed in the lower anterior arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She does have some chipping in the upper anterior teeth, particularly on the right side involving the central incisor and lateral incisor. She is wearing on the lower anterior teeth on the labial surface. She has about a 2 mm anterior over bite. Upper incisors are quite thinned down. She has a fairly tight Class I cuspid relationship bilaterally with just a slight 1 mm Class III on the right side. She does have some crenations on the lateral border of her tongue bilaterally. Oropharyngeal tissues look normal. It appears as though she has a deep oropharynx. To palpation, she has no tenderness around the head and neck area. The incisal opening is 49 mm, excursion movement to the right about 9 mm and to the left about 7 mm. Joints seem to function reasonably smoothly.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. The right sinus is a little bit cloudy. She has a brachiocephalic facial morphology. She has decreased anterior and mandibular vertical height. Gonial angles are quite angular. She has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower anterior arch.

Coronal view shows that she has relatively normal size turbinates. There is currently an adhesion between the left turbinate and septum. The left sinus is clear. The right sinus is smaller in size and is full of fluid that could be related to the recent surgery.

Axial view shows that the right sinus is small in size. The septums are reasonably straight and turbinates are relatively normal in size. The right sinus is full of fluid.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is flattened on top with some anterior beaking present. The joint space looks reasonably good. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with flattening on the posterior head and some anterior beaking present. The joint space looks fairly good. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination.

Left TMJ coronal view shows that the condyle has fairly good mediolateral width. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm. There appears to be decreased lateral joint space that may account for the slight noise that she heard in the left joint. It does appear that the disc is medially displaced.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 to 4 mm and appears to be more decreased in the lateral joint space compared to the vertical joint space that could correlate to a medial displacement of the articular disc.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B197 has a low occlusal plane low mandibular plane angle facial morphology. The chin is somewhat prominent. She has over angulation of the maxillary incisors, but the angulation of the crown from the root is fairly significant, placing the crown in a better aesthetic position relative to the long axis of the tooth.

Basic diagnoses for B197 would be as follows:
Bilateral condylar hyperplasia (arrested growth at this time).
Mandibular prognathism.
Mandibular AP macrogenia.
Slight maxillary AP and vertical hypoplasia.
Vertical mandibular hypoplasia.
Class I occlusion.
Over angulation of maxillary incisors. Abrasion and attrition of the teeth.
Multiple dental hypersensitivities.
Clenching and bruxism.
Enamel dysplasia.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Medications: Klonopin 1 mg q.h.s. to eliminate nocturnal clenching and bruxism. Restorative dentistry with full mouth rehabilitation.
Surgery: AP reduction genioplasty.

B197 MRI AGE: 24/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. There is a little divot in the top of the condyle. The articular disc is medially displaced and covering about half the condylar head. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. The articular disc is medially displaced covering about half the condylar head. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is quite flattened on top, but has some anterior beaking present. The articular disc is in fairly good position anteroposteriorly. The posterior band is quite thickened and appears almost to have a cystic formation in it. Out laterally, the disc is not as readily seen indicative of medial displacement. The articular eminence is moderately steep. There is some fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces. There is good translation of the condyles and articular discs.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is quite flattened on the posterior head with some anterior beaking. The articular eminence is moderately steep. The disc appears to be in position, but is not as seen out laterally compatible with medial displacement. There is fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces practically surrounding the condylar head and the inferior joint space. There is good translation of the condyles and articular discs.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular discs medially displaced.

B252 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well. Her occlusion is very good. I cleaned out her airway. She is in good spirits, although a little bit more tired today than yesterday. Otherwise, she is progressing well and to return to see me in 1 day. No evidence of infection or wound dehiscence. Reduced elastics by one on each side.

B252 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well, but not feeling quite so good today and having a little bit of depression. Occlusion is good. She is a little tachycardic and blood pressure was a little bit low. I suctioned out her airway and her nasal airway is good. She is getting plenty of fluids down. She is progressing fairly well except for a little bit of down side today, but No evidence of infection or wound dehiscence. She does have a little bit of a yeast buildup intraorally. Therefore, I gave her a prescription for Nystatin 100,000 units/mL, dispensing 200 mL, 1 tsp. q.i.d., rinse mouth thoroughly, hold for 5 minutes and swallow. She is to use it 6 times today, but then go to the 4 times a day after that.

B252 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well. Occlusion is good. Nasal airway was suctioned. She is progressing very well. She in much better spirits and feeling much better today. Her yeast buildup intraorally is improved. She is progressing well and to return to see me in 1 day. I removed all of her elastics today and occlusion is very good.

B252 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing very well. Occlusion is good. I suctioned out her nose. She is a little emotional today, but I told her that is normal. She is progressing well. I answered all the questions she and her mother had. She can stop the antibiotics. I gave her a prescription for Lortab-5, dispensing 20 tablets, 1 tablet q. 4 -6 hours p.r.n. pain, refill x1. She is progressing well and to return to see me in 2 days. I did suction out her nose for her and showed her how to blow her nose.

She is in great spirits and has lots of energy. Doing exceptionally well. She is to return to see me in 1 day.

I changed her elastics and placed a light Class II on the left side and a vertical elastic in the left cuspid area. Otherwise, she is doing well. I suctioned out her nose with very minimal return. She is to wear a heavy elastics on the right side. He did a send verbal message that I could change those if I felt necessary. I did change them to lighter elastics. I also gave her jaw exercises to do. She is progressing well, in great spirits, and to return to see me in 2 weeks. Her next appointment with Dr. _____ is in 6 weeks.

B252 
B252 presents for followup evaluation. She is doing very well. Occlusion is pretty good. Just slightly open in the molar area. Today I took off her elastics and just placed her on some rabbits in a triangular fashion around the mandibular first and second molars and upper first molars. She is in good spirits and doing well. Incisal opening is 32 mm. She really has no complaints or issues at this time. She has an appointment with Dr. ___ in 3 weeks and she is to return to see me in 3 weeks.

B252 
B252 is 15 years old, referred by Dr. ___ . B252's TMJ problems began when she was about 12 years of age of unknown etiology. She completed first stage orthodontic treatment 4 years ago and was placed in some retainers. Dr. __ did not see her again until about 2 months ago, and B252's bite has significantly changed during that time interval. She gets occasional tinnitus and moderate vertigo. She gets headaches now about every other day that occur predominantly in the frontal and temporal areas. She does not really have any TMJ problems per se. She rates her average daily pain at 1, jaw function at 2, and disability at 0. Other joints that bother her includes her knees and ankles. She has been diagnosed as having:

Lupus anticoagulant.
Abnormal homosistine levels.
She is being followed by Dr. __. Primary concerns that B252 has include the following:

Change in her bite.
Headaches.
Excessive wearing of the back teeth.
She takes the following medications:
Fexofenadine 180 mg q.d.
Flonase.
Slow Fe.
Folic acid.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B252 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 2.5 mm. The maxillary, mandibular, and chin midline are all pretty much on the facial midline. In profile view, she has fairly good facial balance. There is just some slight AP deficiency in the prediction of the mandible. Chin is fairly strong. Chin neckline is fairly close to normal in length and chin neck angle is well defined. Intraorally, Maria has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars present. Teeth are fairly well aligned. She has fairly good attached gingiva around the lower anterior arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has almost a full Class II cuspid relationship bilaterally and she has about to 5 to 6 mm overjet. She has an open bite of about 2 mm. She has a slight accentuated curve of Spee in the upper arch. Oropharyngeal tissues looks normal and healthy. She occludes predominantly on the first and second molars bilaterally. Intranasally, the turbinates are moderately enlarged. The septum is fairly straight. There is some mild nasal obstruction, but not too significant. To palpation, she has some moderate tenderness to palpation over the TMJs, but nowhere else in the head and neck area. She has an opening click at about 30 mm in the right joint and about 20 mm with closing. The left side seems to function reasonably smoothly. Incisal opening maximally is about 60 mm, and she could open to about 45 mm without significant pain and discomfort. Excursion movements are 8 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Radiographic evaluation shows that she has four impacted third molars. Condyles appear small in size and it appears they may have degenerative changes. Sinuses look relatively clear. Turbinates look moderately enlarged. Waters view shows the septum is fairly straight. Turbinates appear fairly large and some of this enlargement may be posteriorly. There seems to be a constricted nasal airway. Sinuses look relatively clear. Left TMJ tomogram shows that she is not in centric occlusion when this x-ray was taken. The mandible appears to be postured forward in the fossa. The condyle appears small in size and there is some anterior beaking. Articular eminence is moderate in steepness. She does have impacted third molars x2 on this side. Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that is a little bit small. Joint space may be relatively normal. A little bit of anterior beaking is present. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. The patient is in a little bit better Class II position. Condyle is postured less far forward as compared to the opposite side. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B252 has a high occlusal plane angle in facial morphology. She has an anterior open bite and a Class II malocclusion. Oropharyngeal airway is somewhat constricted to the lateral incisors. There is fairly angulation relative to the mandibular basal bone. She does have some increased soft tissue thickness in the progonion. Oropharyngeal airway at the base of the tongue is reduced about 5 mm and at the soft palate about 11 mm.

Basic diagnoses for B252 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ adolescent internal condylar resorption. Severe AP mandibular hypoplasia. Transverse maxillary hypoplasia. Class II end-on occlusion. High occlusal plane angle.
Occludes only on the first and second molars. Anterior open bite of about 2 to 3 mm. Headaches. Decreased oropharyngeal airway.
Hypertrophied turbinates. Mouth breathing particularly at night. Impacted third molars x4.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Open up about 1 mm of space between the upper laterals and cuspids to help correct her tooth size discrepancy. Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor.
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to expand it and advance it slightly. Surgical removal of impacted third molars x4. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies.
3. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B252 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing very well. Incisal opening is 38 mm. Excursion movements are 3 mm in each direction. She is very comfortable. Occlusion looks great. Nasal airway is good. She really has no complaints or problems. She is progressing very well and to return to see me in 3 months.

B252 
B252 is 6 months post surgery and doing very well. Her occlusion looks very good. She has really no complaints at this time. She is happy with her outcome. She is to return to see us in 6 months for a 1 year followup

B252 
AGE: 15/F
DOB:
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation: 
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit small in size and appears to have perhaps lost some vertical dimension and volume. The lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat. There is decreased superior joint space. There appears to be discal tissue anterior to the condylar head. There could be some lateral disc displacement.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears slightly larger than the left side, but there is decreased vertical joint space. The lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat. There appears to be discal tissue anterior to the condyle and with a little bit of lateral displacement.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit arthritic and may have lost some vertical dimension. There is some anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is moderately steep. The disc is anteriorly displaced and siting almost beneath the articular eminence. The disc is foreshortened anteroposteriorly. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, there is moderate translation of the condyle, but the disc remains anteriorly displaced and nonreducing with significantly degenerative changes.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have some areas of bone loss. The condyle appears quite small out laterally. Articular eminence has a moderate inclination. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced sitting down almost beneath the articular eminence. Out laterally, the posterior band is extremely thick. Over medially, the disc is not as readily seen. On opening, there is moderate translation, but the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

IMPRESSION:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced without reduction. MRI findings may be compatible with AICR.

original_note:
B302 
B302 is 46 years old, referred by Dr. __. B302 is in good health with no major medical problems except he does have some allergies. He does not take any medications. Apparently no known allergies to medications. B302 has never had orthodontics. Apparently congenitally missing maxillary lateral incisors in the upper arch but appears to have the rest of his teeth. B302 is not sure when his jaw joint problems began and there is no known etiology. B302 has had not treatment for his jaw problems to date. He has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. Other joints that bother him include his back where he has a herniated disc and he has been diagnosed as having scoliosis. He is not aware of clenching or bruxing. Headaches that he gets occur around two times per month at about a level of 3 but can reach a level of 7 to 8. TMJ pain is about a level of 2 with the right side worse than the left side. Average daily pain is about a 1, jaw function at 5, diet at 1, disability at 2.

PRIMARY CONCERNS:
Jaws popping and aching.
Difficulty breathing through the nose.
Difficulty swallowing.
Headaches.
TMJ pain.
Daytime tiredness that requires sometimes taking naps.
Snoring.
Sleep apnea concerns.

In frontal view, B302 has fairly good left to right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 26 mm. Upper tooth to lip relationship is 0. Mandibular dental midline is 2 to 3 mm off to the left side. Maxilla is retruded probably about 6 mm or so. Chin is retruded probably 20 mm. Chin-neckline is short and chin-neck angle is absent. Intraorally, B302 does have all of his lower teeth back through the second molars. Some mild crowding in the lower anterior arch. Transverse narrowness in the lower arch is present. In the upper arch, he is missing lateral incisors. Transverse width of the arch is narrow. He has a curve of Wilson. Lower arch has a slight increased curve of Wilson. He has basically a Class I cuspid relationship. He has a 2 mm vertical overbite relationship. Slight transverse cant in the occlusal plane with the right side being maybe 1 mm higher than the left side. He has oral dystopia with the right eye being 1 to 2 mm higher than the left eye. As B302 bites his teeth together, his mandible tends to shift an extra mm towards the right side. In centric relation, however, the mandibular midline and chin midline appear to be fairly close to the facial midline. Oropharyngeal airway demonstrates what appear to be healthy tissues. Uvula may be slightly elongated. Soft palate may be mildly elongated. Faucial pillars are relatively normal or perhaps slightly constricted. Intranasally, the anterior part of the septum is tipped off towards the left side but the mid part of the septum is off to the right side. Turbinates are moderate in size. The right side seems to have more airway obstruction compared to the left side and today he can breathe better through the left side although he says it does switch from side-to-side at times. Holding the left nostril open, he can breathe better. On the right side he cannot determine too much difference. Snoring is moderate. Daytime somnolence is moderate and sleep apnea syndrome is mild.

B302 

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
B302 is missing maxillary lateral incisors and all four third molars. He has a little calcification around the root apex of the mandibular left cuspid. Both condyles appear arthritic. Sinuses appear reasonably clear. Turbinates appear moderate in size.

Waters view shows that the bony nasal septum is deviated and there may be a spur at the superior right side. The right turbinate appears moderately enlarged while the left one looks relatively normal in size. Sinuses look relatively clear with essentially no development of the frontal sinuses.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears a little bit arthritic with a pseudocyst in the top of it. Decreased superior and posterior joint spaces. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Left TMJ tomogram likewise shows a condyle that appears to have a pseudocyst in it. Decreased superior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. On opening, there is moderately good translation of the left joint and not quite as good of translation on the right side although on the the translation was quite good in both joints.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B302 has AP retrusion of the maxilla and mandible. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 3 mm at the soft palate level and about 5 to 6 mm at the base of the tongue. The tongue seems to fill a good portion of the oral cavity except for the very anterior aspect. He has a skeletal Class II jaw relationship. He has a moderately steep occlusal plane angle. To palpation he has some mild tenderness over the right masseter but no other pain around the head and neck area. On jaw function he does have a definite pop in the right TMJ probably 30 mm of opening and 20 mm of closing. The left joint seems to function relatively smoothly. The right joint also has some crepitus types of noises. Maximal incisal opening is 63 mm. Excursive movement is about 12 mm in each direction.

B302's wife states that she feels that B302's profile has become more retruded in the chin area than when they first met when B302 was 20. Tooth size analysis evaluating the maxillary cuspids and centrals with the lower anterior six teeth shows that there is a difference of about 15 mm of spacing that would need to be created to accommodate the maxillary incisors and coordinate that with the lower anterior six teeth. However, both the maxillary and mandibular cuspids and incisors are excessively wide anteroposteriorly which will create a little bit more discrepancy in tooth size analysis. In fact, using the bicuspid as the cuspid and the cuspids and lateral incisors in the upper arch would actually work out as a pretty good tooth size balance. Space would be required to almost equal the size of the maxillary cuspids. An option might be to open up spacing back in the bicuspid area instead of in the lateral incisor area. Using the first bicuspids as cuspids reveals a good match tooth-size-wise between the upper and lower anterior six teeth.

B302 
BASIC DIAGNOSES:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with significant degenerative changes.
AP maxillary deficiency.
Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency.
AP mandibular deficiency.
AP microgenia.
High occlusal plane angle.
Missing maxillary lateral incisors. Class II cuspid molar relationship.
Significantly decreased oropharyngeal airway of about 3 mm (normal 11 mm.) Deviated nasal septum. Hypertrophied turbinates. Nasal airway obstruction. TMJ pain. Headaches. Sleep apnea symptoms. Snoring. Daytime somnolence.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Open up bicuspid space between the bicuspids bilaterally. Align and level mandibular arch. Consider slenderizing the lower anterior teeth removing about 2 mm of tooth structure to keep from flaring them any further forward.
CT scan (TMJ Concepts protocol.)
Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance in a counterclockwise direction. Bilateral coronoidectomies.
Bilateral fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen or buttocks.)
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. Nasal septoplasty.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
Osseointegrated implants and crowns to place teeth in the bicuspid area.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have undergone condylar resorption. There is anterior beaking and sclerosis on the anterior aspect of the condyle. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space at the articular eminence area by the disc. original_note:
B520
B520 is 17 years old. B520 was referred by Dr. XXXX. B520's TMJ issues began when she was about 13 years old. That is when she first started to notice that her chin was becoming somewhat retruded and she developed pain. Etiology is unknown. B520 had orthodontic treatment the first time at age 8 and then from about the age of 12 to 13. She wore elastics and apparently her bite was reasonably well corrected. She had splint therapy for the past 2 years to present time. Splints have been made by Dr. XXXX. B520 has had lots of adjustments on the splints, and she can tell that it is ineffective at the present time. She also has had physical therapy last year that included dry needling and exercises. She has also been treated with medications and is currently on Daypro 600 mg two times per day and birth control pills. She has been prescribed Enbrel but has not started taking that medication yet.

B520 rates her TMJ pain at a level of 8 and her daily pain levels reach a level of 8 to 9. She rates her jaw function at 4, diet at 5, disability at 6. She has no problems with headaches. She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus nor vertigo. She has no hearing loss. She has problems with her right hip. She has stiff hands and fingers in the mornings. B520 has had reactions to penicillin, cephalosporins, naproxen, and more recently she has had a reaction to adhesives and tape. She is not aware of any kind of reaction to wearing jewelry. She is aware of clenching her teeth at nighttime. B520 currently wears her splint only at night. She did wear it during the day, but it did not seem to help her situation so she discontinued daytime wear. She does not snore when she sleeps. She has some mild daytime somnolence, but no sleep apnea. She has a moderate sleep disorder where she tosses and turns a lot at night. She does breathe through her mouth at night, but not so much during the day. She sleeps on her sides and stomach.

In frontal view, B520 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is 20 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 3.5 mm. The maxillary midline looks as though it is on the facial midline. The mandibular dental midline is 1 mm to the right and chin is about 3 mm to the right. In profile, B520 has a head postured forward neck position. In profile view, upper lip supralabrale is about 3 mm posterior to subnasale. The maxilla is retruded about 6 to 7 mm. The chin is retruded about 22 mm. The chin neckline is short, although the chin neckline is reasonably well defined. She has a lip incompetence of about 5 to 6 mm. Intraorally, B520 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has some mild crowding of the lower anterior arch. She has some lack of attached gingiva around the lower incisors. She already has a little bit of gingival stripping present. In the upper arch, she is missing first bicuspids that were extracted for orthodontic reasons. She has a Class II end-on cuspid relationship being a little bit greater on the right side than the left side. She has a zero over bite relationship. She has an over jet of about 2 mm. Oropharyngeal tissues look relatively normal and healthy. There is a significant cant in the transverse occlusal plane with the right maxillary cuspid being at least 3 mm higher than the left side. The mandible is elevated on the right side about 1.5 to 2 mm at the most. The vertical discrepancy is greater in the maxilla with the right cuspid being at least 3 mm higher than left side. She does have some constricture of the luminal valves. The maximal incisal opening is 44 mm, opening without pain 18 mm. The excursion movements are 9 mm in each direction. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the masseters, retromandibular area, and TMJ area with the right TMJ being worse than the left.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. It appears as though she may be missing her maxillary second bicuspids or could be the first bicuspids. The sinuses appear relatively clear. The septum appears reasonably straight and turbinates appear moderately enlarged. She has severely resorbed condyles.

Coronal view shows that she has enlarged turbinates. The septum appears reasonably straight. Sinuses appear clear.
Axial view shows that the septum is reasonably straight. Turbinates are moderately enlarged and appear to block the airway. Sinuses appear relatively clear.

Left TMJ sagittal tomograms shows a severely resorbed condyle with loss of vertical as well as anteroposterior bone structure. The articular eminence appears to have some uneven areas, although it has a moderate inclination. The joint space actually appears somewhat increased vertically.

Right TMJ sagittal tomograms shows a severely resorbed condyle with loss of vertical as well as anteroposterior bone structure. The articular eminence appears to have some uneven areas, although it has a moderate inclination. The joint space actually appears somewhat increased vertically.

Left TMJ coronal tomograms show a condyle that shows evidence of major condylar resorption. There is some medial beaking of the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves downward about 2 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone greater resorption than the left side with extremely narrow mediolateral dimension of the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 mm. Both condyles are severely resorbed and deformed.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a retruded maxilla but anterior vertical maxillary excess and posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia. The mandible is severely retruded. She has a high occlusal plane angle. Oropharyngeal airway at the soft palate level measures 4 mm and at the base of tongue measures 4 mm. She has adenoid tissue in the nasopharyngeal area and she has an airway dimension of about 4 mm between the adenoid tissue and the turbinates and between the adenoid tissue and the soft palate. She was not in centric relation and she has almost an end-on incisor relationship.

Basic diagnoses for B520 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ juvenile rheumatoid arthritis.
Maxillary AP and posterior vertical hypoplasia.
Mandibular AP hypoplasia.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 4 mm (normal AP dimension 11 mm).
Hypertrophied turbinates.
Nasopharyngeal hyperplastic adenoid tissue.
AP microgenia.
End-on Class II occlusion.
Anterior open bite.
High occlusal plane angle of 25 degrees (normal angle is 8 degrees).

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1.	Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level maxillary arch. Keep lateral incisor roots tipped mesially and cuspid roots tipped distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. b.	Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing approximately 2 mm of tooth structure and retract to decrease the over angulation.
2.	CT scan of jaws and jaw joints.
3.	Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement in a counterclockwise direction with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. b.	Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance in a counterclockwise direction. c.	Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). d.	Bilateral coronoidotomies. e.	Nasopharyngeal adenoidectomy. f.	Bilateral partial nasal turbinectomies. g.	Medpor implant to mandible.
4.	Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B520 MRI
BIRTH DATE:
DATE OF ACQUISITION:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has lost significant volume. There may be some discal tissue present, but there appears to be a reactive pannus surrounding the disc. The disc could be a little bit medially displaced. The condyle is severely arthritic and narrow mediolaterally as well as a loss of vertical volume.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone significant condylar resorption. There may be some discal tissue present within the joint, although it appears to be a reactive pannus surrounding the articular disc. There is significant destruction of the condyle with loss of mediolateral and vertical height.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has lost significant vertical height and some anteroposterior dimension as well. There is some anterior beaking of the condyle. The articular disc actually appears to be anteriorly positioned underneath the articular eminence and there is some sort of dense tissue between the condyle and the fossa. There is some inflammation around the articular disc and in the joint space. There is increased vertical joint space between the condyle and fossa. The articular eminence had a moderate inclination. In the T2 images, it shows significant inflammation within the joint surrounding the anteriorly displaced disc as well within the joint space between the condyle and fossa. On opening, there is restricted translation of the condyle and the deformed degenerated disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is extremely small in size with loss of vertical and AP volume. The disc is hard to identify but may be anteriorly displaced. There is dense tissue within the fossa again. There is increased vertical joint space between the condyle and fossa. The articular eminence had a moderate inclination. On the T2 imaging, there is significant inflammation in the joint space. The disc is difficult to identify. On opening, there is significant restricted translation and difficult to identify any remnant of the disc.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis with significant condylar resorption being worse on the right side than the left side with articular disc anteriorly displaced, degenerated and with reactive pannus filling a majority of the superior joint space area. Findings are compatible with connective tissue autoimmune type of process.

original_note:
B165
B165 is 21 years old. They were actually referred by the XXXXs. B165 is in good health except for her jaw problems. She is not sure exactly when her jaw problems began, but the family became aware of a problem at least by the age of 15 of unknown etiology. She had orthodontics for about a year and half from age of 13 to 15. She has new braces on beginning 3 months ago. She gets a headache just about once a month at about a level of 4, but the rest of the time she has no real headache problems. She rates her TMJ pain at 2, average pain at 2, jaw function at 1, diet at 3, disability at 3. She has no trouble with earaches, tinnitus, nor vertigo. She does occasionally get some hearing loss in the right ear. She is aware of clenching and bruxing at nighttime. She has severe snoring, probably moderate daytime somnolence, and probable moderate sleep apnea. She is predominantly a mouth breather day and night.

In frontal view, B165 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 5 mm on the right and 4 mm on the left. The maxillary dental midline is about 1 mm off to the left side. The nasal tip is about 1 mm off to the right side. The mandibular dental midline is about 1 mm to the left and chin is probably 3 mm to the left. In profile, the maxilla is retruded about 3 to 4 mm and the mandible is retruded about 25 mm. The chin neckline is continuous with no real development of a chin neck angle. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars in position. Teeth are actually fairly well aligned and leveled. She has some stripping of the lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back to the second molars present. She has appliances only on her lower teeth including all of the teeth except the second bicuspids. She has an end-on Class II cuspid relationship bilaterally being probably 3 mm Class II. She has an over jet of about 2 mm. She has about a 0.5 mm vertical overbite relationship. Oropharyngeal tissues all look relatively normal. Intranasally, there may be a little bit of deviation of the septum off towards the right side. The turbinates appear moderate in size. She had a head postured forward neck position. To palpation, she has some mild tenderness over the TMJs and retromandibular area. The maximal incisal opening is 42 mm, opening without discomfort 25 mm. The excursion movement to the right is 7 mm, to the left 6 mm. There is a transverse cant in the occlusal plane with the left side being 1.5 mm higher than the right side.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. The rest of the teeth are present. There is essentially an absence of the mandibular condyles. The bony septum appears reasonably straight. There is some antigonial notching.

Coronal view shows deviation of the septum off towards the right and then off towards the left at the base of the septum. The right turbinate is quite large in this view and the turbinates seem to block a portion of the airway. The sinuses have increased thickness of the sinus lining.

Axial view shows that the turbinates are enlarged, particularly on the right side, with a little deviation of the septum off towards the left side. The sinuses both at this level appear to have thickened sinus membranes and probable sinusitis.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is severely arthritic with severe condylar resorption. The articular eminence is essentially absent. There is increased vertical joint space.

Right TMJ sagittal view likewise shows a condyle that is essentially totally degenerated and resorbed. The articular eminence is flat. It appears there could even be a perforation to the fossa into the middle cranial fossa. The articular eminence has been resorbed as well.

Left TMJ coronal view shows that the lateral rim of the fossa has been resorbed as well. There is no virtually no vertical stop on the ramus area. Actually, there appears to be an extension of the lateral rim of the fossa where there may be some bone-on-bone contact.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is severely resorbed. The lateral rim of the fossa likewise where the condyle is functioning has very little support. Back in the actual fossa area, there is no condyle as the condyle is postured anterior on the articular eminence or in front of it.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that her condyles actually are functioning completely anterior to the articular eminence and are not in the fossa at all. The maxilla appears slightly AP deficient but vertical hyperplastic but posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia. The mandible is retruded in a clockwise direction. She has a severe skeletal Class II jaw relationship. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 5 mm at the soft palate level and 4 to 5 mm at the base of the tongue. The soft palate appears to have relatively reasonable length. She has AP microgenia and a high occlusal plane angle.

Basic diagnoses for B165 would be as follows:
Bilateral severe mandibular condylar resorption.
Total disarticulation of mandible condyles with displacement into the temporal fossas.
Maxillary AP and posterior vertical hypoplasia.
Mandibular AP hypoplasia.
AP microgenia.
Class II end-on occlusion. High occlusal plane angle of 25 degrees (normal 8 degrees).
Decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 4 mm (normal AP dimension 11 mm).
Hypertrophied turbinates.
Sleep apnea.
Periodontal defects lower anterior arch. Impacted maxillary third molars x2.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. Gingival graft to anterior mandible.
2. Presurgical orthodontics: a.	Continue to align and level maxilla arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. b.	Align and level mandibular arch, but slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing about 2 mm of tooth structure and close the spacing.
3. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol).
4. Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ and mandibular reconstructions with mandibular advancement using TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. b.	Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla in a counterclockwise direction, down grafting the posterior aspect 8 mm. c.	Bilateral coronoidotomies. d.	Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). e.	Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. f.	Surgical removal of impacted maxillary third molars x2. g.	Medpor implant to anterior mandible.
5. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B165 MRI
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is extremely narrow mediolaterally. I really do not see any good definition of the condyle. There is tremendous destruction of the condyles. The lateral rim of the fossa is flat.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone significant arthritic changes and resorption. The lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat. There is not much but there appears to be soft tissue present within the joint space bilaterally.

In sagittal view, it is hard to even find the ramus or condyle at all on the right side. It is almost impossible to identify any condylar structures in these joints. It appears on the lateral view that there may be some bone on the left TMJ, but there are significant degenerative changes and resorption of the articular eminences with the remnants of the condyle functioning anterior to the fossas and almost beneath the articular eminences.

original_note:
B041
B041 is 55 years old and referred by Dr. XXXX. She is currently under orthodontic treatment with Dr. XXXX and Dr. XXXX.
B041's joint problems appear to have begun at least from a symptom standpoint at the age of 50 of unknown etiology except for clenching and bruxism. She was referred to a TMJ specialist, Dr. XXXX, who began treatment in about 3 years ago. She has been on splint therapy and was in orthodontic treatment since that time. She had multiple orthodontic adjustments and splint adjustments without resolution of her problems. The treatment was terminated six months ago. She subsequently saw Dr. XXXX and Dr. XXXX for treatment. The orthodontics was reinitiated three months ago.

B041 remarkably does not have any significant TMJ pain and rates her average daily pain at 2, jaw function at 7, diet at 5, and disability at 7. She has no problems with headaches. She has no earaches, has frequent tinnitus with the right side greater than the left side, but no vertigo. Other joints that bother her include her right hip, left knee, and left shoulder. She does not believe that she clenches and grinds currently. She current takes the following medications:

Premarin 0.3 mg q.d.
Synthroid 125 mcg q.d.
Bystolic 5 mg q.d.
Vytorin 10/20 q.d.
Fosamax 70 mg weekly.
B12 injections monthly.
Vitamin D 5000 units monthly.
Ambien 5 to 10 mg p.r.n.

Primary concerns that B041 has at this time will include the following:
Teeth do not fit together.
Limited jaw function. Speech is affected.
Open bite where the back teeth do not touch.
Difficulties eating and chewing.

B041 also has some mild snoring, moderate daytime tiredness. She does not believe she has sleep apnea, but she has had insomnia for the last 15 years. She has significant difficulties sleeping. She does not have any significant difficulties breathing through her nose. She did have a sleep study done four years and seven months ago. She had no apneic or hypopnea events. She only had about 0.3 minutes under 90% oxygenation. Her arousal index, however, was 9.7 related to spontaneous arousals. She had some snoring and 5 arousals from snoring.

In frontal view, B041 has reasonably good facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face, but some asymmetry in the mandible. Upper lip length is about 19 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 2 mm. The maxillary midline is fairly much on the facial midline. The tip of the nose is off to the right side about 3 mm. The mandibular dental midline is shifted to the left about 4 mm. The chin is 3 mm off towards the left. In profile, the maxilla is retruded 6 to 8 mm and the chin is retruded probably 10 to 12 mm and chin neckline is extremely short. Nose appears relatively prominent. Chin neckline is short and chin neck angle is not defined. She has to have an obtuse nasolabial angle. Upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale. Intraorally, she is missing the lower first bicuspids. She has significant crowding in the lower anterior arch with the left central incisor blocked almost completely out of the arch in a lingual direction. She probably has about 6 mm of crowding in the lower anterior arch. In the upper arch, she is missing the first bicuspid as well. She is in full braces currently with braces back to the first molars. She has a Class III end-on cuspid relationship on the right side being about 3 to 4 mm Class III and on the left side she is closer to a Class I relationship. She does have close to a 2 mm anterior overbite relationship. She has a posterior cross bite on the left side. The maximal incisal opening is 24 mm, excursion movement to the right 5 mm, to the left 0. B041 does have about a 2 mm open bite bilaterally in the posterior occlusion. Joints seem to function reasonably smoothly.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows that the absence of all 4 third molars and absence of the first bicuspids. She has hyper-calcification around the molar teeth in all 4 quadrants. Sinuses appear relatively clear. She has a number of crowns and it looks like a root canal on the maxillary right lateral incisor.

Coronal view shows that the sinuses are clear and turbinates are relatively normal in size. The septum deviates a little bit off towards the left side.

Axial view shows that the sinuses are clear and turbinates are relatively normal in size. The septum is deviated just slightly off to the left side.
Left TMJ sagittal tomogram shows that she has severe arthritis in this joint. There is some anterior beaking. There is significantly vertical and posterior joint space. The articular eminence is moderately shallow. There appears to be an osteophyte extending up off the head of the condyle towards the lateral aspect of the joint.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have greater arthritic changes and there also are arthritic changes in the fossa. It appears that there is some reactive bone in and around the joint area. There is decreased joint space towards the medial aspect of the joint.

Left TMJ coronal view shows arthritic changes. There is significantly decreased vertical and lateral joint space. It appears there is almost bone-on-bone contact. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 4 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows advanced arthritic changes with a pseudocyst in the condylar head and erosions. There are also erosions in the fossa. There appears to be some heterotopic within the joint space. The joint spaces are quite narrow and in some areas appear to be bone-on-bone contact.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B041 has a retruded maxilla and mandible. She has a moderate high occlusal plane angle. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 4 mm at the soft palate level and about 6.5 mm at the base of the tongue. She appears to have a skeletal Class I and occlusal Class I type of relationship. B041 has a tooth size discrepancy with a negative 1 mm.

Basic diagnoses for B041 are as follows:
Right TMJ severe arthritis and ankylosis.
Left TMJ arthritis. AP maxillary hypoplasia and asymmetry.
AP mandibular hypoplasia.
Class III occlusion on the right side.
Cross bite on the left side. Missing all 4 first bicuspids extracted for previous orthodontic reasons and all 4 third molars. Significantly decreased incisal opening of 24 mm (normal 45 to 50 mm).
Decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 4 mm (normal 11 mm).
Difficulties eating and chewing.
Bilateral posterior open bites.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level maxillary arch. b.	Align and level mandibular arch. Keep all of the teeth and align the lower anteriors. This will tip them forward slightly to an end-on incisor relationship.
2. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol.)
3. Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with eliminate the asymmetry. b.	Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla. c.	Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). d.	Bilateral coronoidotomies.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B041 MRI AGE: 55/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears arthritic. There is decreased vertical joint space. Difficult to identify discal tissue. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 3 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is severely arthritic. There is decreased vertical joint space. There appears to be osteophytic extensions off the condyle and also extending down from the fossa. It is difficult to identify discal tissue in this view.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle has some flattening on the anterior aspect of the head and a little bit of anterior beaking. There is decreased joint space and could possibly be bone-on-bone contact. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence, but severely degenerated and deformed. It is quite short anteroposteriorly. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination. On opening, there is restricted translation and the deformed articular disc remains anteriorly displaced to reduction.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears quite arthritic. There appears to be a pseudocyst in the head of the condyle. There appears to be some remnants of the disc in the joint space. The joint space is a little bit thicker than the opposite side. There appears to be increased sclerosis in the head of this condyle compared to the opposite side. The articular eminence appears slightly flatter than the opposite side and appears to have some degenerated changes in the subcondylar bone. On opening, there is severe restriction of condylar translation. The degenerative tissues within the joint space appear unmoved.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction and with significant deformation. Right TMJ advanced arthritis and severe degenerative changes of the articular disc with possible fibrous ankylosis.

original_note:
B448
B448 is 23 years old and referred by a former patient, XXXX. Primary concerns that B448 has are as follows:

His teeth do not touch.
Constant tooth and jaw pain.
Headaches. Locking. Popping in the joints. He does have some difficulties eating and chewing.
He does have a lot of congestion and times has difficulties breathing through his nose and becomes a more prominent mouth breather.

He takes no medications.
He became aware of having jaw problems at about the age of 11 when he was told to see an orthodontist. The etiology is unknown. He has had headaches at least beginning in high school and throughout high school and college. He underwent orthodontics from the age of 11 to 14 by Dr. XXXX. He has essentially had no other treatment for his jaw problems.

B448 rates his TMJ pain at 6, average daily pain at 6, headaches at 7 that occur predominantly in the frontal and temporal area bilaterally. He rates his jaw function at 5, diet at 3, disability at 2. He gets occasional earaches with the left side worse than the right side and moderate occurrence of tinnitus. He also has a moderate occurrence of vertigo, but has no hearing loss. He has some noisy joints and they are particularly in his wrists and through motion have a lot of crackling sounds. His hands and fingers hurt sometimes. He also has some problems with his neck. He is aware of clenching and bruxing at nighttime and also during the daytime.

In frontal view, B448 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 2 mm. The maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. The mandibular midline is about 3.5 mm off to the left side as is the chin. In profile view, the maxilla is posteriorly positioned at least 6 mm. The chin is back probably around 4 to 5 mm. The chin neckline is a little bit short and chin neck angle is not defined. Intraorally, B448 has all of his lower teeth back to the second molars. He has a wide mandibular arch and the first molars actually have an excessive buccal inclination. He has good attached gingiva. In the upper arch, he has all of his teeth back through the second molars. He has fairly wide arches. He has huge tonsils. This constricts the fascial pillars. Otherwise, the uvula and soft palate appear relatively normal. B448 does appear to have some macroglossia. The nasal septum may be deviated a little bit off towards the right side and at the bottom there is an osteophyte kind of formation that extends into the left side of the nose. The turbinates appear moderate in size. B448 has anterior and bilateral posterior cross bites. The cross bite is a little bit worse on the left side than the right side. He has a full Class III occlusion on the right side and on the left side he has an end-on Class III by about 3 mm. The mandibular left cuspid is about 2 mm posterior to the right cuspid. In the upper arch, the right cuspid may be 1 to 2 mm posterior to the left cuspid. He has a reverse deep bite of about 2 mm and a reverse over jet of -6 mm. To palpation, he has moderate pain in the temporalis, masseters, TMJs, styloid areas and milder tenderness over the right shoulder. Joints function relatively smoothly, but he does feel slight crepitus in his joints. The maximal incisal opening is just 58 mm, excursion movement to the right 4 mm, to the left about 3 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars and B448 says that they never formed. He has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower arch. He has some relatively short roots on the bicuspids in the upper arch and slightly elongated condylar heads and necks.

Coronal view shows that the sinuses are clear. He has some deviation of the nasal septum. The right turbinate is quite large and appears to contribute significantly to nasal airway obstruction on that side. On the left side, the turbinate is more normal. Sinuses are clear except there is a little thickening of the sinus membrane along the right lateral sinus wall.

Axial view does show that the right turbinate is enlarged and appears to block most of the functional airway.
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. Medially, the condyle is more anteriorly positioned in the fossa and there is a decreased joint space posteriorly. The articular eminence is relatively shallow.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows that medially the condyle is more anteriorly positioned in the fossa and out laterally as well and posteriorly positioned, however, there is slightly greater joint space behind the right condyle out at the lateral aspect of the joints compared to the left side.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. There is some decreased lateral joint space. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 3 to 4 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. There is decreased lateral joint space and the lateral rim curves inferiorly about 3 to 4 mm.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that he has huge tonsils that appear to displace the tongue forward and may be part of the reason that the tongue appears relatively large for the oral cavity. The posterior base of the tongue is completely supported forward by the tonsils. Oropharyngeal airway between the base of the tongue and the posterior pharyngeal wall is about 14 mm, but at the soft palate level is only 5 mm. This again in part could be due to the extremely large tonsils. He does have a skeletal and occlusal Class III relationship with about a 2 mm reverse deep bite.

B448 has had a fairly consistent cough for about the last 6 to 7 years. His jaw growth is getting progressively worse.
Basic diagnoses would be as follows:

Bilateral TMJ condylar hyperplasia (evaluate if it is active or inactive growth).
Mandibular deviated prognathism.
Maxillary AP and transverse hypoplasia.
Full Class III occlusion on the right side, Class III end-on on the left side. Anterior and bilateral posterior cross bites.
Hypertrophied right turbinate. Severely hypertrophied tonsils.
Relative macroglossia secondary to displacement related to the hypertrophied tonsils.
Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of about 3 mm.
Slight arch asymmetry with mandibular left cuspid being about 2 mm posterior to the right cuspid and maxillary right cuspid being 1 to 2 mm posterior to the left cuspid.
Sleep apnea symptoms. Buccal tipping particularly of the mandibular first molars.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1.	Removal of hypertrophied tonsils.
2.	Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. b.	Align and level mandibular arch. Try to tip the first molars lingually to align them more appropriately with the rest of the mandibular teeth.
3.	Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors. b.	Possible high condylectomies to arrest growth if confirmed active condylar hyperplasia is still occurring. c.	Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to rotate the mandible back on the facial midline. d.	Maxillary osteotomies to advance and expand. e.	Right partial inferior turbinectomy.
4.	Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B448 MRI
DOB:
DATE OF ACQUISITION:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. The disc appears to be medially positioned with the lateral third of the condyle uncovered. There is decreased lateral joint space. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good morphology. The disc likewise is medially displaced leaving the lateral third uncovered. There is decreased joint space towards the lateral aspect of the joint. The lateral rim curves inferiorly probably about 3 mm.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with fairly good morphology, although the condylar head and neck appear elongated. The disc appears to be in reasonably good position anteroposteriorly. Out laterally, the disc is not as easily seen. In some of the views, it appears that the disc may be posteriorly displaced. The articular eminence is moderately shallow. There is significant amount of fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces anterior to the condyle. This may show that the condylar disc is actually in fairly good AP position. On opening, the left TMJ has some restricted translation with the condyle only coming forward just a few millimeters. The disc does not move much. In the cine films, it appears that the disc is posteriorly displaced and then on opening it appears to jump forward into a more normal position.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with fairly good morphology. The condylar head and neck appear elongated. The disc may be slightly posteriorly positioned. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination to it. There is no fluid within the joint space. The disc appears to be posteriorly position. In the opening views, the disc appears to be in fairly good position. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. There is very minimal translation.

IMPRESSION: Left TMJ medial displacement of the articular disc and limited translation of both condyle and disc.
Right TMJ posteromedial displacement of the articular disc and on opening there is significant restriction of movement.

original_note:
B189
B189 is 17 years old, referred by Dr. XXXX, ENT specialist. B189 had orthodontics from the age of 10 to 13 including two phases of treatment. She began developing headaches when she was 14 in the ninth grade of unknown etiology. She has had no treatment except for some physical therapy that was initiated about 5 weeks ago. The physical therapy has helped her with her headaches. When she has the physical therapy, the headache intensity decreases for about 3 days. She had sinus surgery in 3 years ago and she had her wisdom teeth removed 4 years ago.

She gets daily headaches at about a level of 6 in the frontal and temporal areas bilaterally. She rates her TMJ pain at 2, average daily pain at 4, jaw function at 2, diet at 1, disability at 1. She takes the following medications:
1. Synthroid 625 mcg per day.
2. Solodyn 90 mg q.d.
3. Singulair 10 mg q.d.
4. Nasonex p.r.n.

She gets earaches bilaterally, but no tinnitus or vertigo and has no hearing loss. No other joints bother her. She does have hypothyroidism, but takes the Synthroid for that. She does have a history of recurrent sinus infections and ear infections. She does have some GI issues as well. She has been to see a neurologist and has tried various medications, but nothing has been effective without putting her to sleep.

In frontal view, B189 has good facial symmetry and balance. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 2 mm. The maxilla, mandible, and chin midline are all fairly aligned with each other. In profile, she has good facial balance. Intraorally, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has some crowding on the lower arch. She does have a 2 x 2 retainer in the lower arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has basically a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. She has a 2-mm vertical overbite relationship. Oropharyngeal tissues look healthy and normal. Intranasally, the septum may be a little bit deviated off towards the left side with a little deviation back towards the right at the base of the septum, but for the most part it is relatively straight. The turbinates appear just mildly enlarged, however, she does not have any significant nasal airway obstruction. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the temporalis muscles, TMJs, and milder tenderness over the retromandibular area. Maximal opening is 55 mg and she could open to 28 without discomfort. Excursion movements are about 11 mm in each direction.

Basic diagnoses for B189 would be as follows:
1. Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular discs laterally displaced and slightly anteriorly at the lateral aspect of the joint.
2. Relatively mandibular hyperplasia.
3. Bilateral TMJ pain.
4. Bilateral headaches.
5. Myofascial pain.
6. Earaches.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. Bilateral TMJ injections with Marcaine to evaluate effect on headaches.
2. Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair. b.	Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to maintain occlusion.

B189 MRI
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some degenerative changes with the presence of anterior beaking. The articular disc appears to be in position, but there appears to be a reactive pannus surrounding the disc. The disc could be slightly anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint. In the T2 films, there is some fluid in the superior and inferior joint space. The disc looks in a little bit better shape in these images. Right TMJ sagittal view shows more degenerative changes particularly towards the medial aspect of the joint where there is flattening of the head of the condyle and some anterior beaking present. The disc is in reasonably good position, but again there appears to be a reactive pannus surrounding the disc. At the lateral aspect, the disc appears to be anteriorly displaced. There is some fluid in the superior and inferior joint space. The disc appears to be in better condition in the T2 films. The disc may be anteriorly displaced particularly at the lateral aspect.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. Joint space appears fairly good. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly a relatively minimal amount. It appears that there may be some disc tissue present. On the left side, the disc may be laterally displaced. Left dynamic opening shows that the disc appears to be in position and translates well with the condyle.

The right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width, although there may be some loss of vertical volume. Joint space looks reasonably good, although may be slightly decreased at the lateral aspect. The disc appears it might be laterally displaced. Right dynamic opening shows that the disc appears to be in position and translates well with the condyle.

IMPRESSION:
1. Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis being slightly worse on the right side and articular discs that appear to be laterally displaced and perhaps slightly anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint.
2. Bilaterally, the discs reduce on opening.

original_note:
B333 
B333 is 37 years old and will be 38 in 9 days. Referred by __. B333 is in good health with no major medical problems. He takes no medications. Basic concerns that B333 has includes:
Clicking and popping in the jaw joints. Pain in the jaws.

B333 is unsure of when his jaw joints began clicking and popping. However, during the past year, his joints have become quite symptomatic. He has been in splint therapy for bruxism for the past 5 years. He takes occasional Advil or Tylenol when his pain gets more significant. B333 rates his TMJ pain which is fairly constant at about a level of 5, average daily pain at 4, average headaches at about 2 in the frontal and temporal areas bilaterally. He rates his jaw function at 5, diet at 4, disability at 2. He has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, nor vertigo and no other joints bother him. He is aware of clenching and bruxing at night time. B333 did have previous orthodontics from the age of 12 to 14.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B333 has fairly good facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about -2 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline is shifted about 1 mm off to the right side. Nasal tip is off to the left side about 2 mm. Chin is off to the right side about 4 mm. In profile view, B333 has some significant AP maxillary deficiency of probably a good 6 mm. Upper lip supra-labrale is probably almost 4 mm posterior to subnasale. Mandible is retruded. Chin is fairly prominent compared to the AP position in the lower lip. Chin neckline is not well defined. Chin is probably posteriorly positioned about 8 mm. B333 is missing the lower first bicuspids. He has a lot of wear on his posterior teeth. The lower incisors appear to be in a little bit of lingual inclination. Transverse with the lower arch is fairly constricted. In the upper arch, B333 is missing the upper first bicuspids as well as. These teeth were extracted for previous orthodontics. He has a slight Class II cuspid relationship on the right side by 2 mm and on the left side he has just a slight Class III cuspid relationship by 1-2 mm. He has about 0.5 mm of vertical overbite. He has relatively small upper lateral incisors. He may have just a slight cant in the occlusal plane with the left side being down no more than 1 mm. Uvula is somewhat elongated. The soft palate and fascial pillars look normal. Tonsils are maybe moderately enlarged, a little bit more so on the left side than the right side. Intranasally, he has an enlarged turbinate on the left side. On the right side, it appears that posteriorly the septum deviates off towards the right side and appears it may touch against the turbinate. He has some mild snoring, but no sleep apnea symptoms apparently. B333 has had all four wisdom teeth removed. To palpation, he has some mild tenderness over the styloid area, but no other tenderness around the head and neck area. On opening, he has an audible click in the left joint at about 20 mm and a closing click at about 10. On the right side, he has a softer click at probably about 25 mm and a closing click that is a little bit more noticeable at 15 mm. As B333 opens his jaw, he has to shift his mandible off towards the right side, open some, and then go back towards the left in order to open completely. In excursion movements, B333 has an audible pop in the right TMJ and the left side is a little bit less noisy. Maximal size opening is 53 mm, opening without significant pain 40 mm. Excursion movement to the right 8 mm, to the left 7 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars as well as all four first bicuspids. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Waters view shows that there is a septal spur off towards the right side intranasally and some deviation of the bony septum off towards the right side. The turbinates appear moderate in size with the left one appearing larger than the right one. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has a little bit of sclerosis on top. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There is decreased superior and posterior joint space. Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There appears to be decreased posterior joint space and superior joint space. On opening, there is better translation of the right condyle than the left condyle. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B333 has retruded maxillary and mandibular dental alveolar processes. Chin is fairly prominent compared to the AP position of the dental alveolus. Oropharyngeal airway actually appears to have pretty good opening with about 9 mm at the soft palate and about 12 mm at the base of the tongue. B333 has a tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 4.5 mm. Basic diagnoses for B333 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis, but articular discs anteriorly and medially dislocated.
AP maxillary deficiency. AP mandibular dental alveolar hypoplasia. Macrogenia.
Slight Class II cuspid relationship on the right side and slight Class III cuspid relationship on the left side. Small upper lateral incisors.
Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 4.5 mm.
TMJ pain. Missing maxillary and mandibular first bicuspids that were removed previously for orthodontic reasons.

Two treatment options were presented to B333.
TREATMENT OPTION 1:
Presurgical orthodontics.
a. Place appliances on maxillary arch.
Place appliances on mandibular arch. Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to maintain the occlusion, but allow the condyles to move downwards and forwards to make room for the articular discs.
Postsurgical orthodontics with consideration for opening bicuspid spaces and tipping the incisors forward as well as perhaps distalization of the posterior teeth to make room for the previously extracted first bicuspids. Restorative dentistry.
a. Placement of 4 dental osseus implants.
b. Place crowns on the 4 implants. TREATMENT OPTION 2:

Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Open about 1 mm of space around each upper lateral incisor but also open spacing for replacement of the first bicuspids. This may require distalization to a certain extent of the second bicuspids and molars. Open up spaces in the lower arch in the first bicuspid area to accommodate bicuspid replacement. The presurgical orthodontics will flare the upper and lower incisors forward.
Surgery. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor. Mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance it forward and increase the occlusal plane angle.
Maxillary osteotomies to down graft the anterior aspect approximately 2 mm and move the posterior aspect upwards 2 mm as well as advance the maxilla forward about 6-8 mm at the incisal edge.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
Restorative dentistry.
Placement of 4 osteointegrated implants. Place crowns on the 4 osteointegrated implants.
