B327 
B327 is 12 years and 4 months old. She is referred by Dr. __.
Patient History
B327 is in good health with no major medical problems. She is 4 feet, 10-1/2 inches and weighs 88 lb.

B327 has no trouble with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, or hearing loss. No other joints bother her. She is allergic to cats and dogs. She has no known allergy to jewelry. She gets headaches that range from 3 to 8 in the frontal and temporal areas, and these occur one to two times per week. Sometimes she will get light sensitive, and the headaches can cause nausea. She is not aware of any nocturnal clenching or bruxism. Prior to being placed on the atenolol, she would get headaches about every other day. Now she gets headaches just once or twice a week. Her headaches are beginning to increase again, and she feels that the atenolol is not being as effective anymore. She rates her TMJ pain at 7 and overall pain at 7 on an average day. She rates her jaw function at 6, diet at 5, and disability at 6.

Her problems began about four or five years ago when she began getting headaches, but they were infrequent. In the fourth grade, she started to get the more frequent migraines. In sixth grade is when she was placed on the atenolol. She does have some problems with both her thumbs. About the first of April, she jammed her right thumb and tore some ligaments in it, and it is still tender and sore for her. In June, she hurt her left thumb playing volleyball, but it is better now and doesn't seem to bother her. She has been told that she has loose joints.

Patient Concerns
Headaches
Difficulties eating and chewing
Lower jaws become more retruded
Her overbite has increased during the last couple of years
Her head is postured forward more than it used to be
Pain in the jaw joints
Noises in the jaw joint
When she wakes up in the morning, her jaws are sore (over her masseter muscles)
She has pain when she yawns in the masseter muscle and TMJ area
Predominant mouth breather when sleeping

Current Medications
Atenolol 25 mg, 1 q.d.
Allegra p.r.n. Ibuprofen for her headaches
Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B327 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetric. Upper lip length is about 19 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 5 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline is a little bit to the left, and chin is about 2 mm to the left.

In profile view, she has fairly good balance between the upper lip, cheeks, and nose. Chin is retruded probably about 15 mm. Soft tissues may be retruded by a couple of millimeters.

Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. Some hypereruption of the lower central incisors. Some mild crowding, lower anterior arch. Has good attached gingiva around the anterior arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has a slight Class II end-on occlusion by probably about at least 3 to 4 mm. She has an overjet of probably 2 mm. She has a vertical overbite of probably about 4 mm. She has a slight transverse cant in the occlusion with the left cuspid being about 1.5 to 2 mm higher than the right cuspid, so the left cuspid is elevated 1.5 to 2 mm higher than the right cuspid.

Turbinates are moderately enlarged particularly on the left side, and this might cause some breathing problems as she states she breathes predominantly through her mouth when she sleeps. Oropharynx appears clear. Tonsils are present but are of moderate size. To palpation, she has some mild to moderate pain over the masseters, TMJs, and styloid area with the right side being a little bit worse than the left side. Joints seem to function relatively smoothly, although she would occasionally hear a glitch in the right joint. Maximal incisal opening was 33 mm but only 28 mm with reasonable comfort. Excursive movements were 8 mm to the right and 7 mm to the left, but it was painful on the right side for her to do the excursive movements.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows that the sinuses appear reasonably clear, although there is a little fuzziness in the left one. Turbinates look moderate in size. Has all of her teeth back through the second molars, except she has no lower third molars but appears to be developing maxillary third molars. Condyles appear to have undergone some significant bony changes and resorption. No other significant pathology noted.

Waters view shows that the sinuses appear reasonably clear with the left one showing some material in it. Frontal sinuses are better developed on the left side than the right side as are the ethmoid sinuses, but they all appear relatively clear.

Left TMJ tomogram shows that the condyle has undergone some significant resorption. Very minimal joint space available. Condyle is postured forward in the fossa somewhat. Appears to be significant loss of vertical height of the condyle. Articular eminence is relatively shallow.

Right TMJ tomogram shows that there has been considerable condylar resorption that has occurred. Appears to be an osteophytic formation extending posteriorly on the condylar head causing decreased posterior joint space as well as decreased vertical joint space. Articular eminence on this side likewise is extremely shallow. The condylar head is quite flat, and there appears to be significant vertical loss of condylar bone with the resorption process.

Translation shows minimal translation of the joints.
Cephalometrically, she has a skeletal Class II relationship. Oropharyngeal airway appears good, but her head is postured forward, and her head is tipped up. Turbinates extend posterior to the hard palate. She has a little bit of nasopharyngeal adenoid tissue but not too significant. Oropharyngeal airway with the head posture projected shows that the airway is fairly good.
Basic Diagnoses

Bilateral TMJ resorptive arthritis with reactive pannus surrounding the articular disc and with possible lateral disc displacement.
Anterior vertical maxillary excess. Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency
AP mandibular deficiency
AP microgenia
Class II end-on occlusion Mild crowding, lower anterior arch
Tooth-size discrepancy with a 's difference of about 1 mm
High occlusal plane angle
Developing maxillary third molars (impacted x 2)
Moderately hypertrophied turbinates
Nasal airway obstruction with predominant mouth breathing particularly at night when sleeping
Headaches TMJ pain
Myofascial pain
Light sensitivity with severe headaches

Recommended Treatment
Splint therapy to try to unload the joints
Medications - Anti-inflammatory to see if this will improve comfort and decrease the progression of the condylar resorption
Celebrex 100 mg q.d. but may increase to 200 mg q.d. Consider possible Klonopin  mg, 1 tablet q.h.s. if morning headaches are persistent

Evaluation at the to rule out hypersensitivities to the materials in the prostheses
Presurgical orthodontics
Align and level maxillary arch. Keep upper lateral incisor roots tipped mesially and cuspid roots tipped distally in case interdental osteotomies are necessary Align and level mandibular arch. Strip lower anterior teeth removing at least 1 mm to 1.5 mm of tooth structure to correct for the tooth-size discrepancy

Surgery
Bilateral condylectomies and debridement of the joints and reconstruction with mandibular advancement utilizing TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to decrease the occlusal plane angle
Bilateral coronoidectomies
Fat grafts to bilateral TMJs (harvested from abdomen)
Surgical removal of impacted maxillary third molars x 2
HTR implant to anterior mandible
Partial turbinectomies

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion I gave B327 a prescription for Celebrex 100 mg tablets, disp. 20 tablets, 1 tablet q.d, refill x 5.

Date of Reading: 
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that is a little bit narrow mediolaterally. Slight downward curvature of the articular eminence. Joint space is decreased vertically. More toward the anterior part of the joint, it appears that there is some kind of material displaced out lateral to the condyle, head, and neck area. Cortical bone appears intact, although there may be evidence of condylar resorption.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that appears narrow mediolaterally. Mediolateral pole of the condyle is significantly taller than the medial aspect of the condyle. More significant downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. It appears there has been some condylar resorption. Discal tissue not easily seen except there is some kind of tissue extending out lateral to the condylar head that could indicate a laterally displaced disc.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that doesn't show up really prominently radiographically. Cortical bone appears to have undergone degenerative changes on top of the condyle. Articular eminence is long but moderately shallow. Articular disc appears to be in position, although the posterior osteophyte extends posterior to the disc. Appears like there almost could be a pannus around the disc, probable reactive pannus, around the disc. Condyle appears in about two or three of the cuts.

On opening, there is moderate translation of the condyle. Disc does not seem to move very well and could possibly be adhesions to the articular eminence. Condyle comes down along the posterior slope of the eminence but does not go beneath it.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle with a very similar morphology. Appears to be loss of vertical height, but there is an osteophyte extending posterior to the head of the condyle. Disc appears to be in proper AP position, but there is tissue surrounding the disc itself as one would see in a pannus.

Right TMJ, open views, show that the condyle translates moderately well. It appears that the disc remains in its original position indicative of possible adhesions to the fossa.

Impression:
Bilateral TMJ resorptive arthritis with pannus surrounding the articular discs and possible lateral displacement

B472 
B472 is 18 years old and is referred by Dr. XX.

PRIMARY CONCERNS:
Headaches.
Pain in the jaw joints. Bite shifting. Difficulties eating and chewing
She has no history of snoring, daytime somnolence nor sleep apnea problems.

B472's problems began in her early teens of unknown etiology. She had orthodontic treatment when she was about 13-1/2 to about the age of 15 by Dr. XX. Dr. XX has noted that her bite has shifted some.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:
Adderall 10 mg.
Zoloft 50 mg.
ALLERGIES: ZITHROMAX.
She gets earaches, right side worse than left side but no tinnitus. She gets occasional vertigo predominately when she gets her significant headaches. No hearing loss. No other joints bother her. She is aware of clenching her teeth at night. She gets headaches about five days per week and these have been present for about the last three years. She rates them at about a level of 7 in the frontal area behind the eyes and also in the temple areas. She rates her TMJ pain at 5, average daily pain at 3, jaw function, diet and disability at 4. In frontal view, B472 has fairly good facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face. It appears that she may have a little bit of vertical asymmetry at least in the mandible with the right side being shorter vertically than the left side by probably about 3 to 4 mm. Upper lip length is 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 2.5 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Nasal tip may be just about 1 mm off to the right side. Mandibular dental midline is about 1 mm off to the right side. Chin is maybe just slightly off to the right side maybe 1 to 2 mm at the most. Left eye may be just slightly elevated by 2 mm.

In profile view, B472 has some AP maxillary deficiency probably about 3 to 4 mm. Chin is AP deficient by probably 12 to 15 mm. Chin-neckline is short although the chin-neck angle is reasonably well defined. Nose appears to be in good balance with the cheeks. Upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale by probably a couple of mm. Intraorally, B472 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower anterior arch. The patient has adequate attached gingiva. Teeth appear to be fairly well aligned and leveled. In the upper arch, she has absence of the first bicuspids but the rest of the teeth are all present. She has a slight Class II end-on occlusal relationship by probably about 1 mm or 2.  

She has an overjet of about 2 mm. Uvula, soft palate and faucial pillars all look relatively normal. Intranasally, the turbinates appear relatively normal size with the left one being a little bit enlarged. It appears the septum is relatively straight. There does not appear to be any significant nasal airway obstruction. She believes she breathes most of the time through her nose when she is sleeping. She does drool some.

To palpation, she does have moderate pain over the TMJs and moderate pain to palpation over the temporalis, styloid areas, right masseter and milder discomfort over the shoulders and left masseter. On opening, she had a more distinct click on the right TMJ with probably 25 mm of opening and with a closing click of about 20. On the left side she appeared to have a click of about 35 to 40 mm of opening and closing click of probably somewhere around 25 to 30. On excursive movement she had a definite click in the right TMJ. Maximal incisal opening is about 50 mm but only about 18 mm with comfort. Excursive movements are about 10 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. She is missing maxillary first bicuspids. She has a 3 x 3 retainer. Condyles appear they may be slightly small but not too significant. The right side is a little bit smaller than the left side. The sinuses appear relatively clear. Turbinates appear moderately enlarged.

Waters view shows that she does in fact have a large left nasal turbinate that seems to block a good portion of the airway. Bony nasal septum appears relatively straight. The sinuses appear reasonably though a little bit of cloudiness in the maxillary sinus towards the lateral aspect of the sinus wall.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle appear to have lost some volume. It seems a little bit short vertically. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Joint space appears within reasonable bounds.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears a little bit changed in shape. Joint space appears fairly reasonable. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Lateral view shows good translation of both joints.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B472 has a retruded maxilla and to a greater extent a retruded mandible. She has a skeletal Class II relationship and a slight Class II occlusal relationship. She has a high occlusal plane angle. She has a decreased oropharyngeal airway of only about 4 to 5 mm at the soft palate level and at the base of the tongue.

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
Bilateral TMJ idiopathic condylar resorption and articular disc dislocation with reduction on the right but nonreducing on the left. AP mandibular deficiency. 
AP maxillary deficiency. Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency.
Class II end-on occlusion.
High occlusal plane angle.
TMJ pain.
Headaches.
Myofascial pain. Missing maxillary first bicuspids and all four third molars.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway of 5 mm (normal 11 mm.)

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Algin and level maxillary arch. Keep lateral incisor roots tipped forward and cuspid roots tipped distally. Align and level mandibular arch.
Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction and decrease occlusal plane angle.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it in a counterclockwise direction down grafting the posterior aspect. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence. It has a decreased anteroposterior dimension with primarily with loss of the intermediate zone. A little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction although there is fairly good translation of both the condyle and the disc.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has more of a hockey stick shape and there may be some loss of vertical volume particularly towards the lateral aspect of the joint. Increased superior and posterior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is sitting anterior to the condyle beneath the articular eminence. Disc is foreshortened anteroposteriorly. There could be a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space but not too much. On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and disc. In one view the disc appears to be reduced and in another view it appears it is anteriorly displaced without reduction.

IMPRESSION:
1.	Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction and with significant deformation of the articular disc.
2.	Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction and with significant deformation of the articular disc.
3.	Probable salvageable discs.

original_note:
B488 
Age 40. B488 was referred by XX.

B488's problems began last year, when she was 39 years old and was involved in a bus accident. During the accident, apparently she was sitting in the back row with no seat directly in front of her essentially sitting in the middle seat. When the accident occurred, she was thrown forward and she grabbed onto a seat to keep from rolling down the aisle and struck her jaw. She apparently struck it on her right side. Initially, she had quite significant pain in the back of her neck, shoulders, down into her arms and it was even black and blue in these areas. The pain was quite intense and she was not aware of the jaw pain until the first month after the accident she was aware of having tightness and pain in her jaw areas. When she finally was referred to chiropractic treatment, she brought that up to his attention that she had pain in the shoulder, neck and jaw areas. When she went to the chiropractic treatment, she had about 20 sessions about 2 to 3 per week. This made her dizzy and made her very sleepy but did provide no improvement in her pain levels. She then was sent to a pain management doctor who did epidural injections into the lower cervical vertebrae. The injections did not help her. She had the epidural injections done twice, but this did not improve her pain. She then was recommended to have aquatic therapy. She started the aquatic therapy earlier this year and still continues that treatment. Early this year, she tried a splint but this did not help her and, in fact, increased her pain and made the pain more frequent. It caused muscle cramps in the jaws.

B488 rates her headaches at a level of 8 that occur predominantly on the right side in the frontal and temporal area, but they occur bilaterally in the posterior head area and she gets these about three times per week. She rates her TMJ pain at 8, average daily pain at 8, jaw at 8, diet at 6, disability at 9. She gets occasionally right sided earaches, moderate tinnitus and moderate vertigo. She is aware of clenching her teeth severely at nighttime and she also clenches during the day. Other joints that bother B488  include her right shoulder, right elbow, right wrist, right hip, right ankle, neck and back. She has some neuropathies somewhat are affecting her right arm, but since the epidural injections in the cervical vertebrae area, this problem has improved. She still has the pain, but she had numbness through arm and hand that has cleared.

In frontal view, B488 has good facial balance. In profile, she has good facial balance as well. Occlusally, she has a Class II end-on cuspid-molar relationship and an anterior deep bite of about 9 mm. She has a reversed curve of Spee in the upper arch and an accentuated curve of Spee in the lower arch. She has all of her teeth back through the second molars present. Oropharyngeal tissues look healthy. She has moderately enlarged tonsils with the right one being larger than the left one. To palpation, she has low severe pain over the TMJs, retromandibular area, right shoulder, high moderate pain over the masseter muscles, right medial pterygoid and right SCM and moderate pain over the left medial pterygoid, left SCM and left shoulder as well as right temporalis area. She has significant clicking and popping in both joints with an opening clicking at about 15 mm on the right and 20 on the left and closing clicks at about 15 mm on the left and 10 mm on the right. The maximal incisal opening is 47 mm, opening without pain only about 20 mm. The excursion movements in each direction are about 7 mm with pain.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. The turbinates appear moderately enlarged. Sinuses appear relatively clear. She could have a periapical lesion around the mandibular right second molar.

Coronal view shows that the turbinates appear moderately enlarged. The sinuses appear clear.
Axial view shows that the turbinates are moderately enlarged and the sinuses appear clear.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has a little bit of anterior beaking. Out laterally, the condyle appears narrow. The posterior head of the condyle appears somewhat flattened particularly towards the medial side of the joint. The joint space appears narrow vertically and posteriorly. The articular eminence has a more shallow inclination.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is flattened on the anterior aspect with some anterior beaking present. There is decreased vertical joint space. The articular eminence has moderate inclination. The vertical joint space appears narrow.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has an odd shape to it where the medial pole is significantly higher than the lateral pole. There is decreased vertical joint space. The lateral rim of the fossa curves probably about 4 to 5 mm. There is decreased lateral joint space.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has a little bit better morphology than the opposite side. There is decreased vertical joint space. The lateral rim curves inferiorly probably 4 to 5 mm.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a Class II skeletal and occlusal relationship. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 8 mm at the base of the tongue and 5 mm at the soft palate level.

Basic diagnoses for B488 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc dislocation with reduction.
Mandibular hyperplasia.
TMJ pain.
Headaches.
Myofascial pain. Class II end-on occlusion with anterior deep bite of 7 mm.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1.	Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level maxillary arch. b.	Align and level mandibular arch.
2.	Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors. b.	Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to maximize the occlusal fit.
3.	Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

I will be referring her to Dr. XX. The other person to receive a letter is Mr. XX.

B488 MRI  
AGE: 40/F
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. The articular eminence is moderate steep. The joint space is narrow. It appears that the disc may be in position but very thin. At the lateral aspect of the joint, the disc might be anteriorly positioned, but very difficult to tell.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with fairly good morphology. The disc tissue appears extremely thin and hard to identify. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space.

Right TMJ coronal view shows it may have a laterally displaced articular disc. The condyle appears to have good width mediolaterally. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has a little bit more arthritic changes associated with it. The joint space is somewhat narrow particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint. It is very difficult to tell where the discal tissue is.

Left TMJ opening shows good translation of the condyle and the disc is in a reduced position on opening. In another view, the disc looks as thought it is of adequate size.

Right TMJ shows that the articular disc is in good positioning on opening and appropriately positioned between the condyle and the articular eminence.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular discs that are quite thin and could be slightly medially displaced with possible disc displacements but with reduction on opening.

original_note:
B264  CT Scan 
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading: 
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows extremely flat lateral rim of the fossa with no downward curvature. Decreased joint space vertically at the medial aspect of the condylar pole. Medial beaking of the condyle is present. Roof of the fossa is absolutely flat. The patient has probably had previous surgery. Cortical bone on the roof of the fossa is extremely thin in some areas and actually may be lacking. Cortical bone is intact on the condylar head.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that has undergone significant osseous changes. It is narrow mediolaterally. Some medial beaking present. Sclerosis on the head of the condyle with some small pseudocysts in the condylar head. No joint space between the condyle and fossa. Fossa appears very sclerotic. The roof of the fossa is extremely flat with no downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. Degenerative changes are present in the fossa.

Left TMJ, axial views, show that the condyle has fairly good mediolateral width. Fairly flat in angulation compared to the opposite side. Shape of the condyle looks relatively normal.

Right TMJ, axial view, shows a condyle with fairly significant curvature of the lateral aspect anteriorly as compared to the medial aspect. Appears there is no joint space between the anterior aspect of the lateral pole of the condyle and the articular eminence. Osteophytic formation coming off the medial aspect of the lateral pole of the condyle. The bone appears to be more disrupted as compared to the opposite side.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has a hockey stick shape to it. Anterior aspect is flat. Decreased posterior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Some roughness on the cortical bone particularly toward the lateral aspect. Significantly decreased joint space out laterally as compared to more medially where there is a little bit greater joint space. Some sclerosis on the head of the condyle. Condyle appears arthritic but not nearly as significant as the opposite side. Some unevenness and even some minor osteophytic formation are present on top of the condyle. Translation is somewhat restricted, but the condyle comes down fairly close to being beneath the articular eminence. Joint space appears decreased although it is present.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that demonstrates significant degenerative changes. There is a small pseudocyst in the head of the condyle. Condyle head and neck are very sclerotic. There is some evidence of bone resorption in the condylar head. Virtually no joint space between the condyle and the fossa and articular eminence. Degenerative changes on the articular eminence as well.

Translation is restricted with the condyle coming only about two thirds of the way down the articular eminence. At this position, there is no joint space indicative of perforation being present. Pseudocyst in the condyle is larger at the lateral aspect of the condyle and becomes smaller toward the medial aspect.

Impression:
Left TMJ arthritis and probable articular disc dislocation
Right TMJ severe arthritis with bone on bone function
B264  MRI Evaluation 

Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading: 
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. Cortical bone appears to be intact. Joint space appears to be a little bit narrow toward the medial side of the joint. Minimal downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. Difficult to tell if discal tissue is in position, but it appears that there is discal tissue anterior to the condyle. Also, the disc could be laterally displaced. Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that is small mediolaterally compared to the opposite side. Arthritic changes in the condyle and loss of vertical height. Appears to be some roughness on the superior surface of the cortex. Significantly decreased vertical joint space. Normal downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. Difficult to identify discal tissue.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has osteoarthritic changes with it particularly toward the medial side. Articular disc appears to be anteriorly and laterally displaced. Does not appear to reduce on opening.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows severe osteoarthritic changes and a disc that is severely degenerated. Condyle is quite small on this side with evidence of loss of vertical anteroposterior dimension. Significantly decreased vertical posterior and anterior joint spaces. Evidence of heterotopic or reactive bone formation. Anterior beaking is present. Articular eminence is moderately steep, and the eminence itself appears degenerated. Virtually no evidence of discal tissue present on this side that can be identifiable, or there may be some areas of severe degenerative deformation of this disc.

MRIs were reviewed with Dr. __ and we agreed on the following findings:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly and laterally displaced without reduction
Right TMJ severe arthritis
Dr. __ feels that there is significant arthritis in the left joint but obviously not as severe as the arthritis in the right joint

The best treatment for this treatment would probably be bilateral TMJ total joint prostheses.
B264 
B264 is 59 years old and referred by Dr. __.

Patient History
B264 has had three back surgeries. She has had a bladder and rectum repair, and she has had her ovaries and ovarian cysts removed. She also has had surgery for a ruptured appendix and a hysterectomy as well as two sinus surgeries. She has persistent back pain and leg pain as well as TMJ problems and has low thyroid.

She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, and has some hearing loss, but this may be genetic in nature since both her father and her mother have hearing problems. She has high sensitivity to smell. She is very much aware of clenching and bruxing her teeth at night. She has probably had TMJ problems for a long time, but the problems didn't get worse until a few months ago when she has having a root canal done, and her mouth was cranked open, and this exacerbated the TMJ problems. Recently, she had a right TMJ arthrocentesis by Dr. __ .

She does have a history of having two resistant staph infections following her sinus surgeries. Prior to her sinus infections, she had been on Cipro for a while presurgery. Postsurgery is when she developed the resistant staph infections and had to be on IV home therapy on Vancomycin. They then switched her to Synercid. Other joint problems that B264 has include the following: Neck, back, fingers, and feet. She does get epidural injections in her neck that seem to be helpful for her.

B264's TMJ problems began at about the age of 21 when she fell down about 14 basement stairs and hit her head. She developed a closed lock situation. She had all four third molars then removed, but this didn't help her situation. She had extensive equilibrations done, but this did not fix the problem. She had three steroid injections into the right TMJ, and after the third one she did fairly well in reference to her right joint from 20 to 33 years ago when she began developing problems again. At that point she was seeing Dr. __ , who placed her into a splint. She had orthodontics for five years from 15 to 10 years ago. All together she has worn splints for about 20 years. Since April of this year, she has had to wear her splints continuously to be reasonably comfortable in order to eat. She has had physical therapy p.r.n. since 20 years ago until recently. She gets massage therapies weekly as well.

B264 is in recovery from alcoholism for the past 18-1/2 years. She had two pancreatic attacks which stimulated her desire to get into AA and get away from alcohol.

Allergies
Environmental allergies
CECLOR (anaphylactic shock)
VANCOMYCIN (red-man syndrome, severe)
HORSE SERUM AND ANY MEDICATION MADE FROM THAT TYPE OF SERUM creates joint pain and hives
FLUORESCEIN DYE 10% (head to toe hives, immediate)
SULFA
In addition, she cannot take ORAL PAIN MEDICATION and can only use suppositories

Current Medications
Synthroid 0.1 mg q.d. Protonix 40 mg (for acid reflux)
Zetia (for cholesterol)
Corgard 10 mg Soma q.h.s. Robaxin 750 mg b.i.d. Vitamin E 600 IU
Darvocet 50 mg suppositories for her back pain p.r.n. Tylenol suppositories for back pain p.r.n. Estrogen injection therapy q. monthly
Ambien 2.5 to 5 mg p.r.n. q.h.s. Bimonthly desensitization injections for allergies

Patient Concerns
Right TMJ comes out of place
Difficulty eating and chewing
Lower jaws are retruded
Sleep disorder
Teeth don't fit together
Wakes up with headaches during the night or in the morning
Chronic neck and back pain
If she yawns, her right jaw joint will go out of the socket
If she tries to chew an apple or anything hard like that, the jaw will go out of the socket
If she rests her jaw on her hand on the left side, it will cause the right joint to go out of the socket

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B264 has good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 25 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 2 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline as is the mandibular dental midline. Chin may be a little bit off to the right side about 2 mm.

In profile view, she has an obtuse nasolabial angle. Upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale by a couple of millimeters. Maxilla is probably 6 mm AP deficient. Chin is retruded about 15 to 20 mm. Chin-neckline is not well-defined, and length is probably less than 20 mm. She has a lot of fullness in the submental area and fullness in the neck area.

Intraorally, she has some significant buccal tipping with a major reverse curve of Wilson in the lower arch. She has crowns on all of the lower teeth. She has an accentuated curve of occlusion in the lower arch being a little bit worse on the left side as compared to the right side. Cuspids on forward are elevated probably a couple of millimeters on the right side and probably maybe 3 mm on the left side compared to the posterior teeth. Left cuspid maybe just slightly posterior to the right cuspid by about 1 mm. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has an end-on Class II cuspid relationship bilaterally. She has posterior crossbites and major open bites posteriorly of probably a good 5 to 6 mm bilaterally. Oropharynx appears relatively clear. Soft palate and uvula appear relatively normal. She does have a geographic tongue. She doesn't have any problems with her geographic tongue, except when she eats pineapple; it causes a significant burning sensation.

Intranasally, the airway looks clear. It appears that she has had previous turbinectomies with complete removal on the left side and probably at least two thirds on the right side.

In the closed position, she has about a 4-mm anterior overbite relationship. Maximal incisal opening is about 45 mm, but she can open to about 42 without significant discomfort. Excursive movements are about 9 mm in each direction.

To palpation, she has some relatively mild tenderness over the right temporalis, left TMJ, and right styloid area. Left joint functions relatively smoothly. Right joint has some significant crepitation associated with it.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows the sinuses appear relatively clear. Septum is in line. Inferior turbinates are essentially absent. All four third molars are absent. She has multiple root canals and this includes the mandibular left possibly second bicuspid but definitely the left cuspid, left central incisor, right second bicuspid in the upper arch, right cuspid, second bicuspid, second molar, and left first molar. She has crowns on all of her lower teeth and all of her upper teeth except for her four incisors and left cuspid. She has arthritic changes in the right TMJ and some mild changes in the left TMJ. There is some dense calcification at the base of the mandibular right second molar mesial root. Just below that area there is a little round area measuring about 4 to 5 mm in diameter that may be just a change in trabeculation pattern in that particular area.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has some flattening on the anterior head. Appears to be some decreased vertical joint space in one of the views, but on the other view it appears better. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Slight hockey stick shape to the condyle.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that is quite small in size, and it appears to have lost significant volume. Anterior beaking is present. Decreased vertical joint space, although the posterior joint space is actually increased. Significant posterior open bite present throughout the whole arch.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyle on the left joint and some restriction in translation on the right joint. In the right joint, there is virtually no space between the condyle and articular eminence, whereas in the left joint, there is fairly good space that could be compatible with the disc being in position.

Waters view shows that the sinuses appear relatively clear. Turbinates are quite small in size, and the nasal airway is excellent. Some asymmetry is present in the lower jaw with the right angle being probably a good 7 mm elevated compared to the left side.

Cephalometric analysis shows that she has a high occlusal plane angle with it actually being a little bit higher in the maxillary arch than in the mandibular arch. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 6 mm at the soft palate level, and at the base of the tongue one of the dimensions measures about 5 mm. Mandible is quite retruded, and maxilla appears retruded. Posterior maxillary aspect appears deficient vertically as well.

Basic Diagnoses
Right TMJ severe arthritis secondary to steroid necrosis
Left TMJ arthritis but condition and position of disc are unknown
AP maxillary hypoplasia
Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia
Transverse maxillary hypoplasia
AP mandibular deficiency
Transverse mandibular dental excess
Class II end-on occlusion Posterior open bites of about 6 mm
Reverse curve of Wilson, lower arch
Crowns on all the mandibular teeth and on all but the maxillary incisors and left cuspid
TMJ pain
Headaches Myofascial pain

Recommended Treatment
MRI of left and right TMJ to determine the condition of the left joint and the extents of disease created by the right TMJ steroid necrosis

Presurgical orthodontics Align and level maxillary arch Align and level mandibular arch. Try to narrow the lower arch by rotating the posterior teeth lingually to eliminate the reverse curve of Wilson and establish a more normal curve of Wilson. Try to level out the accentuated curve of occlusion as well

CT scan of TMJs (TMJ Concepts protocol)
Surgery
Right TMJ reconstruction with TMJ Concepts total joint prosthesis
Reconstruct left TMJ depending on MRI findings by either Nothing if joint is healthy and disc is in position
Left TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor if disc is dislocated but salvageable
Total joint prosthesis if disc is displaced and nonsalvageable
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla and downgraft it posteriorly
Bilateral coronoidectomies Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvested from the abdomen)
Left mandibular ramus osteotomy if the left TMJ is healthy or the disc is displaced and can be repositioned by the Mitek anchor (total joint prosthesis would not be indicated if the joint can be treated by either or these options)

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
Dental restorations as necessary to finalize the bite


RE: B264 
Dear __:
I recently talked to B264  who continues to have significant pain problems although according to her, her occlusion is fine and she looks great.

She continues to have significant problems. She just recently had two heart stents placed. She has GERDS.
She is currently taking the following medications:
Ticlid to thin the blood.
Cozaar for high blood pressure.
Thyroid medication.
Corgard.
Robaxin to help with her back pain.
Antibiotic for sinus infection which she is almost finished with.
Lidocaine cream to her lips.
Lidocaine gargle for the pain in the roof of her mouth.

She is getting physical therapy one day a week to try and improve her jaw excursive mobilities but this does not seem to be helping her. She has no headaches and no TMJ pain but does have a burning kind of sensation and pain down through her lower lip and chin area as well as in the upper jaw behind her teeth. In addition she has hypersensitivity to smell though it has been fairly stable for the last 2 years and has not gotten worse. She says her husband John tells her that she looks like a teenager and her face is very symmetric. Her occlusion fits together reasonably well but she does have these pain issues. I believe she probably has systemic factors that are ongoing that are affecting her abilities to heal well. This may account for vascular problems with the maxilla as well as the poor response to her nerves after the usual stretching that goes on with this type of surgery. I told her that in 95% of patients at least do not have this kind of problem after this type of surgery. She says that her brother, 2 sisters and her mother all have had surgeries that have yielded poor outcomes and her physicians tell her that there must be something systemic within her family that interferes with the normal capabilities.

RE: B264 

She says she has tried Lyrica and Neurontin and has been unable to tolerate those medications as they upset her stomach. I suggested that we try Topamax 25 mg b.i.d. to see if this would help her. The dosage may need to be increased. She will check with her pharmacist to make sure that there is no cross reaction to the other medicines that she is taking and will talk to her pain doctor about perhaps prescribing that for her. It will be important for her pain management doctor to prescribe this for her instead of you or myself only because her pain physician is seeing her on regular basis and managing other medicines for her. She will keep me informed of her progress.

I told B264 I know of no way to eliminate the nerve problems that she has except to try medications. Any treatment for her around the jaws or elsewhere where nerves may be stretched could end up with a similar kind of nerve outcome. The pain she experiences is very unusual and thus there may be genetic factors and her own systemic factors that are probably contributing to her current pain problems. Hopefully she will be able to tolerate the Topamax as I feel this is the medication that may help her pain levels. I just want to update you in reference to my recent conversation with B264 .

I hope all is going well with you and I look forward to seeing you again soon.
With best regards,

original_note:
B422 
B422 is 21 years old and referred by Dr. XX.
Patient History
B422 previously has had her tonsils removed. She does have some allergy problems, and this makes her nose fairly stuffy. She did have asthma as a child but not now. She takes birth control pills but no other medication.

B422 's problems began probably a couple of years ago of unknown etiology. She became aware of clicking noises in her joints particularly on the right side. This is of unknown etiology. The past four or five months she has started to get a locking problem primarily involved the right joint, where she can only open so wide and then can't open wider than that. Previous treatments that she has had include orthodontics with three sets of braces in the past. She has also undergone myofunctional therapy, and she has a night guard that she has worn for approximately two years now. This is to help control her clenching and bruxism. She does have nocturnal clenching and bruxism. The splint does disocclude the teeth, but she still clenches with that device in. She has no trouble with earaches, vertigo, or hearing loss but does get occasional tinnitus. The only other joint problem she has is some lower back problems that she feels may be related to her vertebrae. She does have a lot of allergies to environmental things such as grass, molds, mites, trees, dogs, cats, etc. She cannot wear cheap jewelry as she gets contact dermatitis with watches, braces, earrings, etc.

Patient Concerns
Teeth don't fit together very well
Tongue thrust problem
Difficulties breathing through the nose
Clicking in the jaw joints, particularly on the right side

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B422 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm, and upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 2 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline as is the mandibular dental midline. Chin may be just slightly to the right a millimeter or 2. Nasal tip is just slightly to the right 1 or 2 mm.

In profile view, she might have just some slight AP maxillary deficiency of a couple of millimeters. Chin is deficient by 10 to 12 mm. Chin-neckline is short, and chin-neck angle is not well-defined. Some fullness in the submental area is present. Does hold her head in a neck postured forward head position.

Intraorally, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has some mild crowding, lower anterior arch. Has some lack of attached gingiva in the lower anterior arch right adjacent to the central incisors but otherwise has adequate gingival. She occludes primarily just on the second molars bilaterally, and the rest of the teeth are essentially out of occlusion. She has about a 3-mm anterior open bite. Has a slight Class II end-on cuspid relationship being probably about 2 to 3 mm Class II. Just a slight transverse cant in the occlusion with the right side being about a millimeter lower than the left side. Anteroposteriorly, the cuspids appear to be in fairly good symmetry.

To palpation, she has no tenderness over the head and neck area to palpation. No tenderness over the TMJ areas. On opening, she has a soft opening click at about 10 to 15 mm on the right side and a closing click at about 10 to 15 mm. The left side appears fairly smooth.

Oropharynx appears quite clear.
Intranasally, she has a severely deviated nasal septum off toward the left side. Left turbinate is moderately large in size. On the right side, the right inferior turbinate is moderately large in size, but she has a huge structure above the inferior turbinate that is either an extremely enlarged middle turbinate versus a nasal polyp. The superior aspect of the septum is the area that is deviated far off towards the left side, and this structure up there almost completely obliterates the nasal cavity at that level.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars, but all the rest of the teeth are present and accounted for. Sinuses look relatively clear. Deviation of the septum is not as easily identified on this film, but it does appear that she can see some of the deviation present. Inferior turbinates look relatively normal in size. Middle turbinate on the right side appears to be quite large and filling a lot of the area cavity, but the left side appears to be blocked because of the severe deviation of the septum off toward that left side. Condyles look a little bit flattened but otherwise not too bad.

Waters view shows that the sinuses are relatively clear. Septum doesn't look too bad in this film. Airway looks reasonable particularly at the inferior turbinate level.

On the right TMJ tomogram, it appears that the mandible is maybe postured forward slightly, and the condyle may be postured down and forward from its more centric relation. It shows that there is good joint space around the joint. There appears to be anterior beaking present. The articular eminence is moderately steep.

Left TMJ tomogram shows that she may not be occluding together quite all the way. Joint space looks fairly good, although it appears that there have been some bony changes on the condyle. There is some anterior beaking present, and in the anteroposterior direction, the condyle appears a little bit narrow. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There is good, in fact, exception translation of the condyles anterior to the articular eminences.

Cephalometrically, her head is tipped up somewhat. Oropharyngeal airway at the base of the tongue measures about 4 to 5 mm. This might be even less with better orientation of the head. Lips are forced together. She has an accentuated curve of occlusion in the upper arch and perhaps just a slight reverse curve of occlusion in the lower arch. Tongue is sitting down and does not completely fill the maxillary available volume.

Tooth size analysis reveals about 0.5 to 1 mm of discrepancy.
Basic Diagnoses
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocations with reductions
Anterior maxillary excess
Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency
AP mandibular deficiency
Class II end-on occlusion
Anterior open bite
Occluding only on maxillary and mandibular second molars
Anterior open bite of 3 to 4 mm
Accentuated curve of Spee in the upper arch
Slight reversed curve of Spee in the lower arch Tooth-size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of about 1 mm
Slight over-angulation of lower incisors
Severely deviated nasal septum
Severely hypertrophied right middle turbinate versus polyp
Nasal airway obstruction
Decreased oropharyngeal airway

Recommended Treatment
MRI of left and right TMJ
Presurgical orthodontics
Align and level maxillary arch in three segments using a continuous arch wire with a vertical step. Align the four incisors in an elevated plane compared to the posterior teeth. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies.
Align and level mandibular arch. Strip lower anterior teeth removing 1 to 2 mm of tooth structure and retract

Surgery
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to level the accentuated curve of Spee and close the anterior open bite
Nasal septoplasty
Removal of severely hypertrophied right middle turbinate versus nasal polyp

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B422  MRI Evaluation 
Date of Acquisition: Date of Reading:  
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. Lateral pole of the condyle seems to extend beyond the lateral rim of the fossa. Very minimal downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa of probably only about 2 mm. Cortical bone on the condyle appears to be intact. There is a decreased vertical joint space particularly at the lateral rim of the fossa. There could be some medial displacement of the articular disc. Discal tissue appears to be anteriorly and possibly medially displaced.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly just a couple of millimeters. Appears to be a little bit greater joint space on this side as compared to the opposite side. Difficult to identify discal tissue, however. Condyle appears to extend a little bit beyond the lateral rim of the fossa. Possibly could be some medial displacement of the articular disc on this side. Discal tissue appears to be anteriorly and possibly medially displaced.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that is flattened anteriorly with some anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Appears to be some discontinuity of the cortical bone on the top of the condyle on the anterior aspect of it. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and out laterally appears to be quite thickened in the posterior band area. However, more medial cut shows the disc is not as thickened at the posterior band as it is more laterally. Appears to be some discontinuity on the head of the condyle of the cortical bone. Decreased superior and posterior joint space. More medially, the disc appears to be in a little bit better position and appears to have less anterior dislocation. Joint space looks better balanced toward the medial aspect of the joint. There is some fluid in the superior joint space.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has some peaking at the superior aspect and perhaps a little bit of loss of cortical bone on the anterior leading edge of the condyle. Articular disc is moderately steep. Appears to be some increased superior and posterior joint space. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence. Posterior band is slightly thickened but not as significantly as the opposite side. There is some flattening on the anterior head of the condyle and some anterior beaking as we go more medially. More medially, the disc is in a little bit better position but still in a vertical orientation within the fossa. More medially, the disc also appears to become thinner. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces.

On opening, it appears as though there is some restricted translation.
Impression:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with reduction

original_note:
B224
B224 is 15 years old and, referred by Dr. XXXX.
B224 is in good health with no major medical problems.
PRIMARY CONCERNS:
1. Bite is shifting.
2. Chronic mouth breather.
3. Significant difficulties breathing through the nose.
4. Severe snoring. He has probably moderate-to-severe snoring.
5. Clicking and popping in the jaw joints.

HISTORY: B224 may get earaches about every 3 months. He gets occasional tinnitus. He gets vertigo only when he is tired. No hearing loss. The only other joints that bother him are his knees. He is not aware of clenching and bruxism. He has some significant nasal airway obstruction. He is probably a mouth breather. He takes no medications. He rates his headaches at a level of 0, TMJ pain at 0, overall facial pain and headaches at 0, jaw function at 0, diet at 1 disability at 0. B224's TMJ problem began about 4 years ago when he was about 11 years of age. Shortly after that, he began his orthodontic treatment and has had 2 orthodontic treatments from the age of 11 years to 15 years. One time he was treated with a twin block and also he had a maxillary expander procedure done.

CLINICAL EVALUATION: On frontal view, B224 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Some deviation of the nose. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is 3 mm. Nasal tips off to the right side about 3 mm. Midline is off to the left about 2-1/2 to 3 mm. Mandibular dental midline is probably fairly close to being on the facial midline or maybe just about 1 mm to the left. Mandibular dental midline and chin midline are pretty well aligned with the facial midline. In profile view, upper lip superlabrale is posterior to subnasale. The upper lip is probably retruded by about 4 to 6 mm. The chin is retruded by approximately 20 mm. Chin-neckline is extremely short. Chin-neck angle is not well defined. Intraorally, B224 has all of his lower teeth back to the second molars present. He has adequate attached gingiva though quite thin around the tooth central incisors. Also, thin around the cuspids. In the upper arch, he has all of his teeth back through the second molar. In centric relation, B224 has a Class II malocclusion about 2 mm on the left side and probably 5 to 6 mm on the right side. He has an open-bite tendency from the cuspids forward. He has about a 1 mm vertical overbite, but has an overjet of probably about 4 mm. When B224 bites his teeth together he hits prematurely on the right side. Intraorally, the oropharyngeal tissues look healthy. The uvula is moderately hyperplastic, but the soft palate is normal length and the fascial pillars look relatively normal. Intranasally, the septum appears to be deviated off towards the left side and there is a big spur at the base of the nose. Turbinates on the right side is moderately enlarged and the left side at least anteriorly is of a more normal size. B224 had a nasal injury when he was in his early grade school years where fell off some mats and hit his nose and had some significant bleeding and also hit his head. He was taken to the ER for evaluation at that time. To palpation, he has some mild tenderness over the masseter muscles. On opening, joints seem to function relatively smoothly. On excursion movement there may be a little bit of crepitation. Maximal incisal opening is 53 mm. Excursion movement to the right is about 4 mm, to the left 8 mm. Transverse cant and maxilla are relatively level.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
: Panorex shows the presence of all four third molars impacted and the lowers are trapped beneath the distal aspect of the crowns on the second molars. Sinuses appear relatively clear as best as be evaluated from these photos.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears narrow anteroposteriorly. Difficult to see the cortical bone across the top of the condyle. Condyle is posteriorly positioned in the fossa with significantly increased anterior joint space. Articular eminence has a moderate inclination to it.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that is somewhat flattened on top and posteriorly positioned in the fossa. Articular eminence is steeper than the opposite side. It is difficult to identify the cortical bone on top of the condyle, but a little more legible then the opposite side. On opening, there is adequate translation in both joints, but the condyles do not quite clear the articular eminence.

Waters view shows that that the left maxillary sinus is fairly opaque, particularly probably a sinusitis occurring in that sinus at the time. Right sinus is clear. There is significant deviation and a huge septal spur off the left side of the septum that actually goes over and almost touches against the lateral nasal wall. Turbinate on the right appears quite large. Turbinate on the left side is pretty much obliterated by the large septal spur.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows slight anterior vertical maxillary excess and posterior vertical maxillary deficiency. The mandible is AP deficient and there is a skeletal Class II and an occlusal Class II jaw relationship. He has a fairly large adenoid mass in the nasopharynx and an AOA dimension of about 3.5 mm between the turbinate and the adenoid tissue. Airway at the base of the soft palate measures about 6 mm and the base of tongue measures about 7.5 mm. There is no significant tooth size discrepancy.

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
1. Bilateral TMJ idiopathic condylar resorption and articular disc dislocations without reduction.
2. AP maxillary deficiency.
3. Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency.
4. AP mandibular deficiency.
5. Class II occlusion.
6. Maxillary midline shifted 2 to 3 mm to the left of the facial midline.
7. Anterior open bite.
8. Decreased oropharyngeal airway.
9. Severely deviated nasal septum with large septal spur obliterating the left nasal airway passage.
10. Bilateral hypertrophied turbinates.
11. Nasopharyngeal adenoid hyperplasia.
12. Wide columella creating narrow nostrils.
13. High-occlusal plane angle.
14. Back to maxillary mandibular third molars x4.
15. Sleep apnea symptoms.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
1. Surgery stage I. a. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
2. Monitor facial growth and development.
3. Presurgical orthodontics. a. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. b. Slenderize lower anterior teeth removing 1 to 2 mm of tooth structure and retract, but be careful not to remove any more than 2 mm of tooth structure.
3. Surgery stage II. a. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to move the anterior maxillary superiorly, downward at the posterior aspect, upright the incisors and decrease the occlusal plane angle. b. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counter-
clockwise direction. c. Nasoseptoplasty. d. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. e. Removal of nasopharyngeal adenoid mass. f. Surgical removal of bone impacted third molars.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B224
MRI Evaluation
Date of Acquisition: Date of Interpretation:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears to have perhaps some loss of integrity on the cortical bone underneath the condyle. Quality is either very poor or he is having some significant degenerative changes in the bone structure of the mandibular condyle. Decrease in superior joint space is present. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly a moderate amount. Cortical bone appears somewhat irregular on the head of the condyle. Disc appears to be anteriorly displaced. Appears there may have been some condylar resorption present.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that shows up a little better on the imaging as compared to the opposite side. There is fairly good mediolateral width. Decreased superior joint space particularly at the lateral aspect of the condyle and the medial aspect of the condyle. The disc appears to be anteriorly displaced. Condyle appears somewhat flattened. Appears there may have been some condylar resorption present.

Left TMJ sagittal view show a condyle that appears to have lost some volume and some vertical height. Condyle is posteriorly positioned in the fossa and appears to be some loss of vertical height of the joint space. Articular eminence is quite long and moderately steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and actually sitting beneath the articular eminence. Condyle appears to be extremely narrow towards the medial aspect of the joint. It appears small compared to the size of the fossa. Disc is somewhat deformed. It appears to be shortened anteroposteriorly and a little bit thickened. It appears to have lost the intermediate zone. In some areas, there appears to be amorphous tissue in the joint space. On opening, there is significantly restricted translation and the disc appears nonreducing. Disc may be adhesed to the articular eminence.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle is a little bit larger on this side than the opposite side. However, the bone particularly towards the medial side of the joint appears to have resorbed somewhat. Some anterior beaking is present. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Decreased posterior joint space. This is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence. Disc is short anteroposteriorly and thickened. There may be amorphous type of material surrounding the condyle. On opening, the condyle has restricted translation although slightly more than the opposite side and the disc remains nonreducing.

IMPRESSION:
1. TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation possibly compatible with ICR. Disc is significantly deformed, but may still be salvable.
2. Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction and with significant deformation. Questionable salvagability though there may be enough there to utilize.

original_note:
B199
B199 is 25 years old. B199 was referred here by Dr. XXXX. B199 has been aware of having TMJ problems since about the age of 10 years old. It did not really become a significant issue until she was about 20 years old when her pain levels began to escalate fairly significantly. Primary concerns B199 has at this time include the following:

TMJ pain. Headaches. Myofascial pain. Difficulties eating and chewing. Difficulties breathing through the nose creating predominantly mouth breathing. Teeth and jaws do not fit together.
She does at times get twitching of her facial muscles.

B199's initial problems began at the age of 10 and could have been induced by a lot of stress that she was under at that time or other factors. Following the escalation of her pain and headaches at the age of 20, she has undergone some significant treatment attempts. This includes the following:

Upper and lower jaw splint devices that I have not seen before that she wore for 1 year. Since age 22, she has had 4 additional splints. She basically wears through them and then requires new ones to be made. Acupuncture last year for a few months.
She has seen 2 different chiropractic doctors between ages 21 and 23 for treatments without any successful improvement. She had physical therapy for the past year, again without any significant improvement.

B199 rates her headaches at a level of 6 throughout her head area that is fairly constant and can exacerbate to a level of 8 to 9. She rates her TMJ pain at 7, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 5, diet at 5, and disability at 8. The only medication she currently takes is Motrin, although she has tried Vicodin and pain medications with codeine that have been ineffectual for her. She gets earaches occasionally, no tinnitus, but vertigo with no hearing loss. Other joints that bother her include her knees, hips, ankles, and possibly her neck vertebrae. She is aware of clenching her teeth at night time and also during the day.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B199 has fairly good facial symmetry in the upper and lower third face, and there may be some slight asymmetry in the mandible. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 5 mm. The maxillary dental midline is just slightly off to the right side about 1 mm. The mandibular dental midline is about 2 mm off to the right side, and the chin is probably 2 to 3 mm off to the right side. B199 has about 12 mm of lip incompetence. In profile view, B199 has some slight AP maxillary deficiency of probably about 3-4 mm. The chin is retruded by about 18 mm. Lower third face appears elongated. She has a high occlusal plane angle mandibular morphology. Intraorally, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. Lower molars are tipped lingually along the right bicuspid slightly. She has a transverse and narrow lower arch. She has some mild crowding of the lower anterior arch, but has good attached gingiva. There is a slight accentuated curve of Spee in the lower arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has a slight reverse curve of Wilson present. Oropharyngeal tissues look relatively normal in structure and in health. Intranasally, as best I could see, the septum appears reasonably straight. The turbinates appear moderate in size particularly on the left side. The right one is not quite as large as the left one. B199 has a Class III cuspid relationship bilaterally by probably 3 mm or so. She has an anterior open bite. She has an end-on incisor AP relationship and posteriorly it appears that the maxillary and mandibular posterior teeth are tipped lingually. Her Class III occlusion appears to be splint induced. She does have a slight transverse cant in the occlusal plane with the right side being about 1 to 1.5 mm lower than the left side. The mandibular left cuspid is about 1 or 2 mm posterior to the right cuspid. To palpation, she has moderate to high moderate pain throughout the head and neck area with the worse being in the TMJ area and the shoulder area. On opening, she does have a click in the right joint at about 30 mm of opening and a closing click at 15 mm. The left side functions reasonably smoothly, although she feels sort of like a rubbing kind of noise on the left side. On opening, the mandible does shift off towards the right side about 3-4 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of all teeth actually erupted in including the third molars. Sinuses look relatively clear. It is difficult to evaluate the TMJ joints. Styloid processes are moderately long. Coronal view shows that she does have enlarged turbinates that fill most of the nasal cavity with the right side being worse than the left side. Septum appears reasonably straight and sinuses appear relatively clear. Axial view also shows that anteriorly the turbinates have been reduced particularly on the left side, but posteriorly the turbinates are quite large particularly on the right side. Sinuses are clear. Left TMJ coronal view shows condyle that appears to have a reasonable shape to it. It may be a little bit narrow mediolaterally. Joint space vertically is reasonable except at the lateral rim of the fossa where it is a little bit narrow. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm. Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears slightly smaller than the opposite side. Joint space appears fairly well balance. There is a little bit decreased joint space at the lateral aspect of the joint perhaps in one view. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to be posteriorly positioned in the fossa in some of the views. Articular eminence has a moderate inclination. A little sclerosis on the head of the condyle. There may be a little flattening of the condyle in the superior aspect towards the lateral aspect of the joint.
Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has a pseudocyst in the head. There is some anterior beaking present, and there actually appears to be a decreased anterior joint space between the articular eminence and the condyle. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B199 has a moderately high occlusal plane angle, a Class III occlusion with a Class II skeletal relationship. She has anterior vertical maxillary excess and AP mandibular deficiency. The airway space appears somewhat constricted with it being about 10 mm at the soft palate and at the base of the tongue measures about 8 mm down to less than 4 mm of airway space. She has a significant lip incompetence with anterior vertical maxillary excess. Maximal incisal opening is 46 mm, opening without discomfort 28 mm. Excursion movement to the right 7 mm, to the left 6 mm.

Basic diagnoses for B199 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with reduction on the right side and without reduction on the left side. AP vertical maxillary hyperplasia, but AP and posterior vertical hypoplasia.
AP mandibular hypoplasia, but anterior vertical hyperplasia.
Anterior open bite. Class III occlusion. High occlusal plane angle.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 3 mm at the base of the tongue (normal dimension 11 mm).
TMJ pain. Myofascial pain. Headaches. Hypertrophied turbinates creating nasal airway obstruction.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
MRI of left and right TMJ. Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisors roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies if they are necessary. Align and level mandibular arch. Try to expand the arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing no more than 2 mm to correct for a 1.5 to 2 mm tooth size discrepancy. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol).
Surgical option 1. Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla in a counterclockwise direction. Bilateral coronoidotomies. Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen).
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. Anterior mandibular ostectomy to advance the chin forward and reduce it vertically. Consider removing the third molars.
Surgical option 2.
Bilateral TMJ disc repositioning and stabilization with Mitek anchors. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla in a counterclockwise direction.
Bilateral turbinectomies.
Consider possible removal of third molars. Anterior mandibular ostectomy to advance the chin forward and reduce it vertically. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B199 MRI AGE: 25/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. There appears to be discal tissue in the joint area with some what appears to be lateral disc displacement. It is difficult to tell whether it is anterior or posteriorly. There is good condylar width. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle is just slightly smaller than the left side. There appears to be discal tissue displaced laterally, but also it appears that there may be some tissue medially as well. Joint space appears reasonably good. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. A little sclerosis on the top. Articular eminence is moderately steep. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and significantly degenerated and deformed. It is quite short anteroposteriorly. The posterior band is quite thickened. Intermediate zone is extremely short. There is fluid in the superior joint space. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence. On opening, this side seems to have moderately good translation with the disc in position. The disc appears to move with the condyle.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have some arthritic changes with some areas that appear like small erosive areas on the anterior and superior head of the condyle. It appears that there is discal tissue that is degenerated, but in position. What appears to be the posterior band is of relatively normal thickness. Intermediate zone appears to be degenerated as does the posterior disc. Anterior band appears fairly dense. There is some fluid in the superior joint space. The right TMJ appears to have anteriorly displaced disc that is nonreducing, although there is reasonably good translation of the condyle. The disc remains thickened, deformed, and degenerated.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced with significant deformation and nonreducing. Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc that may be laterally displaced, but otherwise appears to be in position, although somewhat degenerated.
