original_note:
B508
B508 is 16 years old and referred by Dr. XXXX. B508 has had her wisdom teeth removed and had left second premolar and mandibular right second premolars extracted 4 months ago. She had her wisdom teeth removed 8 months ago. B508 is in good health with no major medical problems. She is 5 feet 5 inches tall and weighs 120 pounds.

PRIMARY CONCERNS:
Breathing difficulties.
Difficulty eating. Difficulty talking. Pain in the jaw joints. Headaches. Difficulties eating and chewing. Noises in the jaw joints.
Difficulty breathing through her nose.

Currently B508 takes no medications.
In frontal view, B508 has fairly good left to right facial symmetry. She has a little bit of increased fullness in the right cheek area. Upper lip length is about 18 mm. Upper tooth to lip relationship is about 4 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the fascial midline. Mandibular dental midline is probably about 3 to 4 mm off to the left side and the chin is probably 5 mm off the left side. As B508 bites her teeth together, she tends to shift off towards to the right side a greater amount than her centric relation. In centric relation she is still off to the right about 3 mm. Upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale by probably about 2 mm. The maxilla is retruded by about 4 to 5 mm. Chin is AP deficient by approximately 15 mm. B508 has a head postured forward neck position, Intraorally, she is missing lower second bicuspids. She has some moderate crowding in the lower anterior arch. There is a high attached labial frenulum but otherwise appears to have good attached gingiva. In the upper arch she appears to be missing first bicuspids but has the rest of her teeth back through the second molars. She has an anterior open bite of about 5 mm. On the right side she has a crossbite and a tendency towards a crossbite on the left side. She has a Class II end-on cuspid relationship on the left side about 2 mm and on the right side she is probably 4 to 5 mm Class II. Open bite in the cuspid area on the left side is greater than the right side by probably a couple of mm. Transversely the maxillary occlusal plane is fairly level. However, there is asymmetry in the lower arch with a transverse cant and the left side is 2 mm lower than the right side. Mandibular dental midline and chin are fairly closely aligned to each other. She bites primarily on just the second molars bilaterally with the rest of the teeth essentially being out of occlusion. Oropharyngeal tissues look relatively normal. The uvula, soft palate and faucial pillars all appear relatively normal. Intranasally, she has moderately enlarged turbinates and they may be larger posteriorly. The septum has some deviations to it with accepted norms. Moderate nasal airway obstruction. Columella is somewhat wide and nostrils are a little bit narrow. However, opening the nostrils with a scope did not appear to improve her ability to breathe through her nose.

She does report mild snoring and mild daytime somnolence but no sleep apnea syndrome problems. Maxillary incisal opening is about 49 mm, excursive moves are approximately 7 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars as well as mandibular second bicuspids and maxillary first bicuspids. Sinuses look relatively clear. Turbinates appear moderate in size. The bony septum appears relatively straight. Condyles appear arthritic particularly on the right side. She has a root canal in the mandibular right first molar.

Water view shows that the sinuses appear relatively clear. The bony septum at least appears relatively straight. Turbinates appear moderately enlarged with somewhat constricted airway.

Right TMJ tomogram is a little hard to interpret but it appears there are arthritic changes in the joints and moderately flat articular eminence. There maybe some decreased joint space present.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to have some less arthritic changes compared to the opposite side. Joint space appears a little bit better balanced. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. On opening, there is fairly good translation of both condyles coming down beneath the articular eminences.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B508 has a high occlusal plane angle, Class II skeletal and occlusal relationship and a significant anterior open bite of almost 7 mm. Oropharyngeal airway is constricted with a dimension from the soft palate to posterior pharyngeal wall of about 5 mm and at the base of the tongue about 4 mm. She has lip incompetence of about 8 mm.

B508 believes her problems began perhaps when she was about 11 years of age. She may have had some clicking and popping in her jaw joints at that time of unknown etiology. Except for initiating the orthodontic treatment she has had no other treatment for her joint problems.

Dental model analysis reveals a tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm. She has a significant accentuated curve of occlusion primarily related to the second molars being quite a bit higher than the rest of the teeth. The first molars are also slightly elevated. The lower arch has a slight accentuated curve of occlusion associated with it but not too significant. Dental model analysis also reveals transverse maxillary deficiency. B508 does require 10 to 11 hours of sleep a night in order to feel good. This is probably related to the constricture of the oropharyngeal airway. She also has the abnormal head and neck posture that helps open up her airway and does improve her breathing some. However, she is developing curvature in the shoulders and abnormal neck shape and posture.

B508
BASIC DIAGNOSES:
Bilateral TMJ idiopathic condylar resorption and articular disc dislocations with the right side significantly worse than the left side.
AP mandibular deficiency. Anterior vertical maxillary excess.
AP maxillary deficiency. Transverse maxillary deficiency. Mandible deviated off to the right side approximately 3 to 4 mm. Class II end-on occlusion being worse on the right side than the left side.
Bilateral posterior crossbites being worse on the right side than the left side.
Transverse cant in the mandibular occlusal plane with the left side being 2 mm lower than the right side. Occluding predominately only on the second molars bilaterally. Hypertrophied turbinates. Nasal airway obstruction. Significantly decreased oropharyngeal airway of 4 mm (normal 11 mm.) Snoring. Daytime somnolence. Speech deformity. Masticatory dysfunction. High occlusal plane angulation.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Continue to align and level maxillary arch. Open a little bit of spacing around the upper laterals and cuspids to equal about 0.5 to 1 mm to correct for the tooth size discrepancy. Keep lateral incisor roots tipped mesially and cuspid roots tipped distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level mandibular arch. Try to lose significant posterior anchorage so that the lower incisors do not retract at all. In fact they could benefit by being tipped forward slightly. Surgery stage I:
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors. Surgery stage II:
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to expand, advance and level the occlusal plane.
Partial turbinectomy. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears to have reasonably good mediolateral width although there appears that there are some arthritic changes within the joint. Decreased lateral joint space. Moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa. There may be discal tissue over medial.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears to have lost some volume vertically. The condyle appears more deformed than the opposite side. The joint space actually looks very good. Cortical bone appears to be intact. Moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa. It appears there may be some discal tissue displaced laterally.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have some arthritic changes. There is a little bit of flattening on the head of the condyle. It is difficult to see the cortical bone over the top of the condyle. At the lateral aspect of the joint it appears that the disc is anteriorly displaced but towards the medial side the disc appears to be in better position although there may be degenerative changes associated with the disc. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, the disc appears to reduce and there appears to be moderate translation of the condyle and the disc.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has a little bit of anterior beaking and flattening on the head of the condyle. There appears to be some loss of volume to the condyle. Articular eminence has a moderate inclination. Articular disc appears to anteriorly displaced and it is more visible at the lateral aspect of the joint than at the medial. A little bit of fluid present in the superior joint space. On opening there is restricted translation of the condyle and the articular disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction. The disc appears fairly deformed and degenerated. There is questionable salvageability of this disc but it still may be salvageable.

IMPRESSION: Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly and medially displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint. Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced without reduction and severely deformed

original_note:
B274 
B274 is 69 years old. Referred by __. She was also referred by Dr. ___. She has also been to see Dr. __ who did some splint therapy. She has dentures and also wears splints. Primary concerns that B274 has include the following:
Jaw aches and pains.
Headaches. Earaches.

She would like to have relief of pain and be able to return to a normal life and have dentures that work properly for her. Additional problems that she has includes arthritis and depression. Previous surgeries include a partial hysterectomy 44 years ago, bladder surgery 18 years ago, and then some type of surgery to release adhesions 30 years ago. B274 Jean does have a problem of her blood pressure dropping out and apparently can pass out. B274 takes the following medications:

Cymbalta 60 mg q.d.
Actonel 30 mg weekly.
Nexium 40 mg per day.
Senna Soft Gels 2 or more daily as needed.
Refresh Celluvisc.
Calcium.
Alprazolam 0.5 mg per day. She only took 3 of those and has not taken any in the last couple of weeks.
Myochrysine 50 units every 4 weeks.
Fish oil 1000 mg 2 to 3 per day.

She has a number of medications that she is allergic to and we have that listed in her chart.
To B274's best knowledge, her TMJ problems began when she was about 64 years old when she had her teeth extracted 5 years ago. B274 gets headaches predominantly on the left side and, for the last 2 to 3 weeks, they have reached to a level of 10. Today her headache is at a level of 1. She rates her TMJ pain at 5, her facial pain and headaches together at about a level of 10 within the last 2 to 3 weeks. Today her pain levels are about 2. Jaw function is at 3, diet at 4. She has been at a level of 8 recently, but today her disability is probably closer to 1 or 2. She gets earaches, tinnitus, and vertigo. Other joints that bother her include her hips and her back. She was at one time diagnosed as having rheumatoid arthritis, but her rheumatologist, Dr. __ , apparently is backing off that diagnosis currently. Today, however, B274 had a Cymbalta and also two Valiums which may improve her overall levels today. She took the Valium to aid her in going through the MRI.

CLINICAL EVALUATION. She has good facial balance to the left and right direction and good vertical balance. She has dentures in right now and she has a 3-mm thick splint it. In profile, she has fairly vertical and AP facial balance. Intraorally, she has upper and lower full dentures and she has a lower splint. Oropharyngeal airway tissues look relatively normal. She has some mild snoring, but no daytime somnolence and no sleep apnea symptoms. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the masseter muscle and high moderate pain over the TMJs. The styloid area has milder tenderness. She is unaware of clenching her teeth.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows that B274 is totally edentulous. There are some arthritic changes probably in her joints. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to be posteriorly positioned in the fossa. There appears to be some decreased vertical and articular anterior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is posteriorly positioned in the fossa. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There seems to be increased anterior joint space. On opening, there is some restricted translation bilaterally. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has basically a skeletal Class I jaw relationship. Oropharyngeal airway appears reasonable with about 8-9 mm airway space at the soft palate level and about 7-8 mm airway space at the base of tongue. However, she is holding her tongue down in her mouth when this x-ray was taken. Basic diagnoses for B274 are as follows:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with early reduction. TMJ pain. Headaches. Myofascial pain.
Earaches, tinnitus, and vertigo.
Totally edentulous.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Surgery. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors. Reconstruction of dentures.

With this approach of placing the discs back in position, it would shift the mandible out of position. B274 will need reconstruction of her dentures post-surgery. They understand this. I believe that this procedure will give her the best chance of getting rid of her headaches, TMJ pain, myofascial pain, and ear symptoms, although they understand there is no guarantee that this will eliminate these problems. She has been under treatment with Dr. __ for some time now without significant improvement. She has tried conservative treatment unsuccessfully.

B274  MRI EVALUATION 
AGE: DOB:
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation: 
Left TMJ coronal views shows a condyle that a little sclerosis on the top. Joint space could be a little bit compressed. The disc may be anteromedially displaced. The lateral rim curves inferiorly 1 mm or so.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width and some sclerosis on top. The disc appears to be medially displaced. There is decreased lateral joint space.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some arthritic changes. There is a little bit of anterior beaking present. Some flattening on the superior head and perhaps a small erosion in this area. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and in a vertical orientation. There is decreased posterior joint space. The disc may be acting as a wedge pushing the condyle posteriorly. There is a little bit of fluid in the inferior joint space. Unfortunately, there are no open views so difficult to tell if there is reduction of the disc on opening.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is a little bit sclerotic on top. Articular eminence is moderately steep. The articular disc appears anteriorly displaced, but appears to be an early reduction on opening. There is decreased posterior joint space and superior joint space. Disc appears somewhat thickened.

IMPRESSION:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly dislocated, but appears that there would be early reduction in both joints.
B274 

The patient presents for final presurgical workup. Final records were taken at her last appointment here. History and physical performed today. Consent form reviewed and signed. I did my final examination. I answered all the questions she and her husband had. B274 states that she has drainage from her ears and odor from her ears. Examination shows that her ears are very clear with no evidence of infection or other problems. No drainage is seen. Tympanic membranes appear clear, although a little bit sclerotic on the right side. I did not notice any odor emitting from her ears. She is ready for surgery tomorrow.

B274 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing very well. She looks good. She has a smile on her face. Her severe headaches are not present any more. She is feeling much more comfortable. A little bit of tenderness and soreness in the temple areas. Today I removed her sutures. No evidence of infection or wound dehiscence. She says she has felt the best that she has in the past 5 years. She is doing very well and return to see me in 3 months.

B274 
Telephone conversation with her. She is doing fairly well. She has some tenderness in her joints as expected and makes noises particularly when she yawns. I told her that that is fairly normal and that she should not be overly concerned about that at this time. She is to keep me informed of her progress.

B274 
The patient presents for a followup evaluation. She is now a little bit over 3 months postsurgery. She had done fairly good. Her headaches have dropped down to a level of 5 on that left side. She only gets occasional pain in the jaw joints. She has some minor complaints, but nothing real significant. To palpation, she has some moderate tenderness in one spot over the left temporalis muscle, but relatively minimal tenderness over the left masseter and bilateral TMJs. She gets occasional left-sided earaches and still gets some tinnitus, but no vertigo. Other joints that bother her include her hips, back, elbows, and wrists. She takes the following medications:

Cymbalta 60 mg q.d.
Actonel 30 mg weekly.
Nexium 40 mg q.d.
Gold shots periodically.
Fish oil.
Her occlusion looks good. We took some x-rays today and joint spaces look well balanced bilaterally. She appears to be progressing well, is in good spirits, and is very thankful for the improvement she has had so far. She is to return to see me in 3 months.

B274 
Telephone conversation with Dr. __ . She has cataracts and he wants to do surgery on her and she is allergic to lidocaine. He wanted to know if she could be intubated. Her surgery was about 5 to 6 months ago. I told him as long as the anesthesiologists were gentle with her jaws and jaw joints that I do not see a problem with that. She is edentulous and it appears that she should be a relatively easy intubation. They will try to do with her a laryngeal mask kind of technique so that they do not actually have to intubate her, but if they do need to intubate I told him I felt it be fine as long as they were reasonably gentle with her.

B274 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient is significantly improved, but still having some problems, predominantly on the left side. She gets some pain in the left temporal area just above the arch and just above the joint area. This is about a level of 6. She apparently does not have any pain directly in the joint itself. To palpation, she has some mild tenderness over the masseter muscle, but not directly over the joints. She has some tenderness over the left shoulder. She takes the following medications:

Cymbalta 60 mg q.d.
Actonel 30 mg each week.
Nexium 40 mg q.d.
Gold shots.
Her arthritis in her joints is apparently doing better, and she is not having much joint problems except I believe for her right little finger that she fell and broke. It is a little bit tender for her. Her incisal opening is 30 mm. She feels as though her ear canal closes on the left side, and it may be due to the fact that the disc is back in position and she still has some inflammation that causes some swelling in the area. She has tried some medications with Dr. __ that did not agree with her. Will try to get those records from Dr. __ . There are some medicines she cannot take. She can take Excedrin. I suggested she take Excedrin two times a day to see if this will help settle the inflammation and help her feel better. She also has some problems with her vertical dimension, and she over closes currently and this may contribute some to her muscle tenderness. Overall, she is improved. She is only 6 months postsurgery and still in the healing process. She is to call me in 2 weeks to let me know how she is doing.

B274
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well. Her occlusion is good. Incisal opening is about 35 mm with a little bit of help. Her occlusion looks stable. She has some different symptoms and feels that her back teeth are not as far apart as they should be when she opens, but to me it looks like things function fairly well. She has about 3 mm of excursion movement in each direction. To palpation, she has no pain over the joints and just very minimal tenderness over the temporalis, particularly on the left side, and the left medial pterygoid area. For the most part, she seems to be progressing well, although psychologically she appears to be improving more slowly. She does get some headaches in the left temporal area. Otherwise, she seems to be progressing well. We will try to set her up with the CMP clinic to see if they can make dentures for her at the dental school. She is to return to see me in about 3 to 4 months for a year followup.

B274 
B274 presents for followup evaluation. She is now about 14 months post bilateral TMJ articular discs repositioning with Mitek anchors. She continues to have some problems. She gets some pain predominantly in the left TMJ area and ear area. Incisal opening is 33 mm. I forgot to measure her side-to-side movement. She gets headaches on the left side in the frontal and temporal area at about a level of 3. She gets some TMJ pain at about a level of 3 and average daily pain at 5. She rates her jaw function at 0, diet at 4, disability at 3. She actually has fairly good side-to-side movement, but I forgot to measure it. To palpation, she has rather severe pain over the temporalis muscles, but relatively minimal to mild tenderness over the rest of the head and neck areas. She has no earaches, but gets tinnitus, left side worse than the right side, and she gets some vertigo. No other joints bother her. She is not aware of clenching or bruxism. She does get some sharp pains into her ears particularly on the left side, but not earaches per se.

The last time she was here I had suggested that she go to the CFP Clinic to have her dentures constructed. This was done, but she found the dentures uncomfortable. She went back to her original dentist who made her a new set of dentures. These fit together pretty well and are more comfortable than the previous set, but she feels as though her tongue is squashed down and flattened and there is no room for her tongue. She also gets some tissue trapped between the dentures of the left side which is basically cheek tissue which she feels has fallen down and gets between her dentures. She feels that her back teeth may be down too far. I explained to her that the resorption of the alveolar ridges, particularly in the upper arch, is what has caused the palate to be so flat as the vertical height of the alveolar ridges decreases, the palate will relatively seem flatter. I am not sure how to remedy this situation for her except to have the upper denture remade bringing it down further vertically and trying to thin the palate on the denture as much as possible. A second alternative would be to do sinus lifts with bone grafting and placement of osteointegrated implants so that the upper denture could be made to palatal coverage.

Radiographically, with the tomograms, she has good joint spaces in the coronal and sagittal views indicative of the discs being in proper position.
When she bites her teeth together, she tends to get dystonic jaw movements. I suggested that she take magnesium 3 tablets in the morning and 3 tablets in the evening to see if this will help quiet this down. An additional alternative may be to try perhaps Klonopin 0.5 mg once or twice during the day to see if this would help quiet the muscles down. At this time, we will just start with the magnesium. She is to keep me informed of her progress.

B274 
She presents for further evaluation. I earlier talked to Dr. __  in reference to her. He likes the teeth she is currently wearing, although they do need some adjustment that he will be willing to do. The other set of teeth made by Dr. __  Dr. __ does not like as well. He feels she is over closed too much with those. She still has her muscular dystonia with constant movement of her jaw and facial muscles.

She had problems with the magnesium as it gave her diarrhea and an upset stomach, although initially when she first started taking it, she felt significantly improved. She now has stopped taking it, because even at one tablet she continued to have problems with diarrhea and feeling weak. She continues to complain of pain around her ears and that she feels as though her ear is closed off on the left side, though clinically the ear passage appears relatively normal. She pushes on the back side of the condyle from inside her ear and she says it makes it feel better and then she also can push back on the posterior aspect of the external meatus and it feels better for her at times. At times, her husband is saying that she is clenching and grinding her teeth.

At this time, I decided to start her on another medication, Klonopin 0.5-mg tablets, dispensing 30 tablets, 1 tablet q.h.s., refill x5. We will try the Klonopin and see how it works. We may have to increase the dose or even decrease it some depending on how she responds to it. She states that she has been to several neurologists and they have tried her on various medications, but nothing has really helped her, but most of that was before I did surgery on her. She believes she feels much better since surgery, but still has some difficulties. She does take Prozac, and this may be one of those medications that may cause muscular dystonia type functions. I suggested we try to taper off the Prozac, but try the Klonopin and see what difference this makes. She is to call me in 4 days to let me know how she does.

B274 
She presents for followup evaluation. She had 2 weeks that were very good, but then yesterday she was at some kind of blue grass concert and she was leaning her head forward for a while and this set off some muscle problems for her. She is having difficulty with her dentures. One set fits better than the other. I told her to wear the set that feels the best. She feels better than before the surgery, but still has some issues. Her muscular dystonia may be affecting her. I suggested she try the Klonopin again to see if this makes a difference. She is to keep me informed of her progress.

B274 
X-rays show that there appears to be good space that would be adequate for the discs. She is taking Prozac right now. Apparently, she has elected not to get off of that as I had suggested before. In fact, she had a couple of good weeks and we are going to try the following plan:

Magnesium. Take 1 tablet in the morning for 1 week.
Add a second tablet after 1 week at night.
If this does not work, then consider taking the Klonopin again. She essentially has not taken the Klonopin as prescribed, but takes it only once in a while. Therefore, we do not know if this is effective for her or not.

If we need to reinitiate the Klonopin and it is ineffective, then another medication we could consider would be thorazine. We will see how she progresses. She is to call me in 3-4 weeks.

original_note:
B269 
B269 is 46 years old, referred by Dr. __. B269 has had previous surgery which include 19 years ago she had a herniated discs at L4 and L5 repaired. Earlier this year she had a hammertoe surgery on the right foot. By history, B269's problems began about 4-1/2 weeks ago of unknown etiology. However, about a year ago she and her husband were hiking and they were carrying something heavy and they slipped and fell and he accidentally kicked her in the jaw area. Her jaw was a little bit stiff and sore for about 3 days and then that dissipated and she had no further problem until this recent episode. Initially she went to an emergency-type room and they placed her on some antibiotics and muscle relaxant (Norflex.) She then developed some high blood pressure and was placed in the hospital for about 4 days because her jaws kept closing down to where she could not get her medications in and had significant difficulty eating and chewing. Her muscles would go into a spasm. Finally, she was injected with some local anesthesia into the masseter muscles on the anterior edge and this helped relieve her. The injections were done just on the right side. B269 believes that most of her problems are on the right side as best as she can tell. Following the injections of the right masseter muscle, she feels as though she is locked in her TMJs. She is currently taking Norflex 100 mg b.i.d. and lisinopril 5 mg q.d.

PRIMARY CONCERNS
Severe limitation of jaw function.
Difficulties eating and chewing.
Stiffness in the jaws.
She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. No other joints bother her at this time. She has hayfever and did have an adverse reaction to Benadryl recently, but no other known food or medication allergies. She is not aware of any problems with jewelry either. Chewing does cause stiffness and discomfort in her jaws. She is not aware of clenching or bruxism. She has lost 10 pounds in the last 4-1/2 weeks. She really has no problems with headaches. She is not aware of having any specific TMJ pain. She does get discomfort in her jaw muscles mainly on the right side at a level of 4. She feels it could possibly go up in the joint, but she cannot differentiate between joint discomfort and the muscle discomfort. Therefore, she may have TMJ discomfort to a level of 4. She rates her jaw function, diet and disability all at 7.

In frontal view, B269 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 3 mm. In profile, B269 has good facial balance and symmetry. Intraorally, B269 has missing mandibular first bicuspids. She has all of her upper teeth back through the second molars. She had a division II malocclusion. She has Class II end-on cuspid relationship and an anterior deep bite probably of 7 or 8 mm. Maximal incisal opening is 22 mm counting the vertical overbite. There appears to be overjet of 3 to 4 mm in each direction. With a little digital help, B269 was able to go to the right about 9 mm and to the left about 6 mm. I was able to get her up by getting her to relax to almost 30 mm. During that relaxing, trying to stretch episode, she had significant tightness and soreness on the right side over the masseter muscle more so than in the joint itself.

B269  Page 2
With the ability to go 9 mm to the right and 6 mm to the left, there is definitely not an ankylosis in the joint and it appears that her problems are more muscle related, although the muscle problems could be stimulated from the TMJ pathology.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows that B269 actually had her bilateral mandibular second bicuspid extracted. She has the rest of her teeth back through the third molars present. In the upper arch, she is missing third molars. Apparently, the lower second bicuspids were congenitally missing. Sinuses look clear. The condyles actually look relatively normal as best as can be seen in that particular view.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle with fairly good shape. Articular eminence is relatively steep. Joint space looks reasonably good. Styloid process is slightly elongated, but not real significant.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears appropriate in size for the fossa. There may be a little bit of flattening on the anterior head. There is joint space all the way around that could be slightly decreased perhaps. On one of the tomograms, there appears to be a section of bone that comes out and overlaps the condyle and seems to extrude from around the external meatus area. On the right tomogram there does appear to be some heterotopic bone overlapping the posterior aspect of the condylar head extruding from the posterior fossa area. Styloid process also has a slightly elongated ligament as best as I can see on the tomogram. B269 has no problems, however, in all movements of the neck in both flexion and extension as well as rotation and tipping. She has no difficulties swallowing and has no pain down through the neck or throat area.

Waters view shows that the sinuses are clear. Turbinates appear relatively normal in size and it appears that it is probably an adequate airway.
Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has some slight AP mandibular deficiency and a little bit of a high occlusal plane angle. She has an anterior deep bite of only about 8 mm. Upper incisors are in a division II position and have a decreased axial angulation. Oropharyngeal airway looks adequate.

I gave B269 a prescription for Klonopin 1 mg tablet dispending 10 tablets 1 tablet q.h.s., refill x2. I also gave her a prescription for a CT scan of the bilateral TMJs, ears and temple bone area to include axial views, coronal views and sagittal views.

BASIC DIAGNOSES Severe limited jaw opening.
Right masseter muscle myositis and dyskinesia.
Calcified mass, right TMJ/ear/temple area.
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc disloction.
B269  Page 3

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT
CT scan of TMJs, temple and ear area.
Klonopin 1 mg tablet q.h.s. to see if this will decrease muscle dysfunction.
Presurgical Orthodontics.

Align and level the maxillary arch.
Align and level the mandibular arch.
Surgery.
Consider removal of calcified mass around the right TMJ, ear and temple area if CT scan proves abnormal enlargement and impingement. Consider possible articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors if direct examination shows disc displacement.
Post Surgical Orthodontics a. Finish and retain

B269  MRI Evaluation
Age: 46-year-old female.
Date of acquisition: 
Date of interpretation:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has very good mediolateral width. Cortex appears to be intact across the head of the condyle. Fossa appears to be intact. Moderate downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. It is difficult to identify the discal tissues. Joint space appears to be decreased.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is a little bit more narrow than the opposite side, but not too much. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly a little greater amount than the opposite side. Joint space appears to be decreased at the lateral rim of the fossa. Cortical bone structures appear to be intact. Disc may be medially displaced. There appears to be heterotopic bone overlying the right joint including coming down below the head of the condyle, down the neck and up above the arch.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some superior peaking of the condyle and decreased superior and joint space particularly at the lateral margin of the fossa. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Articular is in the vertical orientation probably functioning as a wedge displaced in the condyle posteriorly. There is some sclerosis on the head of the condyle particularly involving he osteophyte sticking out along the lateral aspect of the joint. More medially, the disc is more difficult to identify. It is possible that this disc may be laterally displaced although reviewing the coronal views again, there possibly could be lateral displacement of the disc. On the open views, there is very restricted translation of the condyle and discs. Condyle may come forward a couple of mm. There may be some inflammation around the joint, but not a real significant. No fluid seen in the joint space.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some arthritic changes associated with it. There is some flattening on the posterior head and there is actually an osteophyte sticking out from the posterior head of the condyle in one area. There is some anterior beaking present on the head of the condyle as well. Also, there is some peaking on the top part of the condyle. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is vertically oriented and anteriorly displaced more so towards the medial side of the joint as compared to the lateral. There is a little bit of sclerosis on the top of the condyle. On opening, there is virtually no translation of the condyle, though the disc does appear to be in position in some of the views on opening. Decreased translation could possibly mean adhesions within the joint spaces. Need to correlate this to clinical evaluation. There does not appear to be any significant inflammatory process around the joint.

IMPRESSION Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocated anteriorly and perhaps laterally with minimal translation of the condyle and disc.
Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced in a vertical orientation with minimal translation.
Discs appear salvageable depending on correlation of jaw function with the clinical evaluation. Possible heterotopic bone formation over the right TMJ.

B269 CT 
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation: 
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has some arthritic changes associated with it. The cortical bone is intact across the head of the condyle. Decreased superior and medial joint spaces. Cortical bone in the fossa appears to be intact with some relatively minimal downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa, but decreased joint space there as well.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit more arthritic. The superior surface has some slight irregularity, but not much. Decreased superior and medial joint spaces. In both joints, the medial wall of the fossa seems to curve inferiorly quite significantly.

3D assessment shows from a posterior view, that the styloid processes are moderately long being greater on the left side than the right side. Condyles appear to have a good width.

Left TMJ lateral view shows moderately long styloid processes. The condyle appears to have reasonable morphology, but the joint space looks narrowed superiorly, but this is probably not the best to determine joint space. The condyle appears to be sitting forward slightly in the fossa. The view of the left TMJ shows the condyle has good mediolateral width.

Right TMJ basically likewise shows good width of the condyle. The right joint appears to have fairly good morphology, but there seems to be limited joint space. But again, this may not be the best view to evaluate joint space.

In the coronal view, the styloid processes look longer than normal.
IMPRESSION: Arthritic changes in the joint. Most notable is decreased joint space, lateral, superior and medially.

B269 Brain MRI 
BRAIN MRI ALSO INCLUDES THE TMJ (PROBABLY RIGHT JOINT)
First sagittal view shows a condyle that has a little bit of sclerosis on top. It appear to be a little bit postured forward in the fossa. The fossa has a little bit of a different kind of shape to it with a little downward depression in the mid part of the fossa area. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Disc appears to be vertically oriented within the joint. It may be acting as a wedge pushing the condyle posterior into the bilaminar tissue. It is in a displaced position, but in a preclick position. Out laterally, this is harder to visualize.

Left TMJ shows a little bit more arthritic change compared to the opposite side. Disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence as best as I can see. There appears to be decreased vertical joint space in some views toward the medial side. There is anterior beaking present on this condyle. Laterally, the disc is not as readily seen. The joint space appears to be decreased vertically.

Left TMJ coronal view shows decreased joint space medially. There appears to be some arthritic changes on the head of the condyle. Moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa. It appears discal tissue may be anteriorly displaced. I really cannot identify discal tissue in the fossa area. Significantly decreased medial joint space.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit better in morphology. Decreased medial joint space and lateral joint space. I cannot see the disc in these views. There is some medial displacement of the disc towards the anterior aspect of the joint.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ arthritis and anteriorly displaced articular disc that could be creating a closed lock based on clinical assessment.
Right TMJ anterior displaced disc with a vertical orientation.

original_note:
B061
B061 is 57 years old, referred by Dr. XXXX. B061 was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis at the age of 9. She is affected in most all of her joints. She is not aware of when the TMJ problems began. She feels that it is more recently. She had orthodontics as a teenager and apparently her bite was pretty good at that time. She then had orthodontics again in her 30s, but only on the lower arch because her teeth were crowded there and the teeth are straightened up. She does not believe that she had an open bite at that time. In her 30s, she also had a rhinoplasty and she had a chin implant. Her primary concerns are as follows:

Teeth do not fit together.
Teeth are getting crooked.
Based on B061's MRI, she has severe advanced rheumatoid arthritis of both temporomandibular joints with significant loss of condylar head and neck structure. However, she has no pain associated with the jaw joint issues, nor does she have any problems with headaches. She feels that her jaws function is at a level of 0, her diet is at 0, and disability is at 0.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B061 has fairly good facial symmetry in her middle and upper third face, but some asymmetry in the mandible. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 0. The maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. The mandibular dental midline is about a 1 mm off towards the right side, and chin is probably about 5 to 6 mm off to the right side. In profile view, B061 is probably a good 6 to 8 mm AP deficient in the maxilla. The mandible is at least 20 mm AP deficient. Chin neckline is extremely short and chin neck angle is poorly defined. Intraorally, she is missing the lower probably second bicuspids, but she does have third molars in place bilaterally. She has some significant crowding in the lower anterior arch and a little bit of gingival stripping. In the upper arch, she is missing probably first bicuspids and has all of her teeth back to the third molars on the right side and on the left side as well. She appears to occlude primarily on the third molars and it is possible the distal part of the second molars may touch, but the rest of the teeth are out of contact. There is about a 2 to 3 mm anterior open bite. She has a Class II end-on cuspid relationship. B061 does have a transverse cant in her occlusion with the left side being about 2 mm lower than the mandible and 1 to 2 mm in the maxilla. Midline of the chin may be just slightly to the right of the midline of the transverse occlusal plane. The chin implant apparently is not centered correctly on the mandible. The chin implant is off towards the right side. B061 states that immediately after the surgery she told the plastic surgeon that it was off center, but he said that was because her face was asymmetric. It is very difficult to see the oropharyngeal areas, but as best this could be seen the tissues look relatively normal and seem to have a relatively normal architecture. Intranasally, the septum is deviated off towards the right side and this seems to block most of the airway. She has a spur at the base of the septum off to the left side. The turbinates on the left side may be more normal in the size, but the one on the right side is difficult to see but may be somewhat enlarged and contributory to the significant obstruction on the right side of the nose. B061 does have pain to palpation around the head and neck area. Maximal incisal opening is 34 mm, but only about 23 mm without pain. Excursion movements were about 5 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of mandibular second bicuspids and the maxillary first bicuspids. All the rest of her teeth are present. Sinuses appear clear. She essentially has no condyles and I only see remnants of the condylar neck still remaining. She has a root canal in the mandibular left first molar. Waters view shows that the bony septum is deviated significantly off towards the right side. Left airway appears reasonably good, although there may be a spur coming off the superior aspect of the septum into the left side of the nose. Turbinate on the right side appears compressed against the lateral wall from the significantly deviated nasal septum. Sinuses appear clear. Right TMJ tomogram shows that the remnant of the condyle is functioning out of the fossa and beneath the articular eminence. It appears a new fossa has developed anterior to almost where the articular eminence would be. Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that is likewise postured forward and functioning on the base of the articular eminence and completely forward out of the fossa and probably 7 mm anterior to its normal position. The right side is similarly dislocated to maybe slightly a greater extent. There appears to be a little bit more resorption of the right joint in the condylar head and neck as compared to the left side. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has AP maxillary deficiency and significant AP mandibular deficiency. Oropharyngeal airway is only about 4.2 mm at the soft palate level and about 7 mm at the base of the tongue. She has a high occlusal plane angle facial morphology. She has a vertical discrepancy at the occlusal plane levels and also at the inferior border of the mandible where the vertical discrepancy measures about 7 to 8 mm. At the occlusal surface, the difference is probably about 4 mm in the molar area.

Basic diagnoses would be as follows:
Generalized rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis of bilateral TMJs with severe destruction. AP mandibular hypoplasia. AP maxillary hypoplasia. Transverse maxillary hypoplasia.
Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia. Anterior open bite with occlusion only on the second and third molars bilaterally. Class II end-on occlusion.
3-mm anterior open bite. Crowding of the lower anterior arch. Decreased oropharyngeal airway.
Deviated nasal septum.
Hypertrophied turbinates. Nasal airway obstruction. High occlusal plane angle.
Transverse cant in the occlusion with the right side being 1 to 2 mm higher than the left side.
Previously placed and malpositioned Silastic implant to anterior mandible.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Periodontal evaluation of particularly lower anterior arch and appropriate treatment.
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing about 2 mm of tooth structure from the anterior teeth. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol).
Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla forward, down graft it posteriorly, and expand it. Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). Bilateral coronoidotomies with bone plate stabilization.
Nasal septoplasty. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. Removal of Silastic chin implant.
5. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
6. Restorative dentistry as necessary to complete the occlusion.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears anteriorly positioned in the fossa, and it appears as though the fossa has been altered and that the actual articulating area is about 8 to 10 mm anterior to the condyle's normal position, but there is almost a new fossa that appears to be generated. There is little articular eminence anterior. The condyle looks very narrow and very sclerotic. There is some kind of tissue material in the joint that evolved just behind the condyle. There is increased tissue posterior to the condyle. The condyle appears to be significantly degenerated and resorbed. There is some kind of hot spot in the articular eminence or base of the skull area and the eminence position is quite bright. I cannot really identify any evidence of discal tissue, but perhaps a little medial and anterior there may be some. It appears the condyle may have received previous surgery. The condylar head is extremely narrow anteroposteriorly.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that looks severely degenerated and there may be some increased soft tissue thickness between the rim of the condyle and the fossa. The fossa looks strange and there does not appear to be an articular eminence. The condyle must very narrow anteroposteriorly.

Right TMJ T2 shows a condyle that is significantly degenerated and appears to be superior and posteriorly positioned in the fossa. The articular eminence is malformed.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is extremely narrow almost to a knife edge formation. It is sclerotic up to the condylar neck and the remnant of the head. Bilateral TMJ severe resorptive arthritis with essential destruction of the condylar heads and articular eminences. On the left side, there is a cystic formation in the articular eminence area that extends down into the socket area.

original_note:
B365 
B365 is 29 years old. She was referred by a doctor in Monterrey, Mexico, she saw down there, but B365 cannot remember the doctor's name. B365 has been diagnosed with fibromyalgia. She has had TMJ problems since she was about 18 years old that she feels was likely initiated from stress she was under at that time. She has it predominantly on the left side. Since the age of 22, she has had maybe 4 or 5 splints, some of those over-the-counter type. She has a lot of chiropractic treatment, massage therapy, acupuncture, and she has also been seeing a psychologist. She did have some intranasal surgery that may been a septoplasty done last year. This improved her airway some, but she still has some problems with congestion particularly during allergy-type seasons.

She rates her TMJ pain at about a level of 7, average daily pain at 7, jaw function at 5, diet at 2, and disability at 4. She gets headaches predominantly on the left side and temporal area about a level of 6. She gets occasional left-sided earaches and occasional tinnitus. She does experience vertigo and nausea that she states occurs fairly frequently. Other joints that bother her include her left shoulder. Her knees are noisy and she can get some pain particularly if she wears heels or walks for a long time. She has been diagnosed with fibromyalgia. She is aware of clenching and sometimes grinding of her teeth at night time and also during the day.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B365 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 3.5 mm. The maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline as is the chin. The mandibular dental midline may be just slightly off to the right side 1 to 2 mm. She has some mild lip incompetence of probably about 5 mm. In profile view, she does demonstrate some mandibular retraction of probably about 6 to 8 mm. The maxilla appears to have good projection. Intraorally, B365 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has some mild crowding of the lower anterior arch. In the upper arch, B365 has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She actually has a third molar in on the left side. She has basically a Class I cuspid molar relationship and maybe just a slight Class II tendency on the right side. She has about a 2 mm anterior deep bite relationship. Oropharyngeal tissues looks relatively normal. Tonsils are mild to moderate in size, but appear non-inflammatory. Intranasally, the septum is deviated a little bit off towards the left side. The turbinates are moderate in size. B365 does have some moderate snoring problems. She has moderate to severe daytime somnolence. She sometimes will wake up at night unable to catch her breath. She does not sleep well at night, and she feels that is due to either snoring, pain, or thinking about things. She usually needs a nap during the day. To palpation, B365 has moderate pain over the left TMJ, left temporalis area, left SCM, left posterior neck, and left shoulder. She has moderate tenderness over the masseter muscles, right TMJ, and retromandibular areas as well as the right SCM. On opening, she has an early click in the left joint at 5 to 10 mm of opening and a closing click of about 5 mm. The right side seems to function reasonably smoothly. Maximal incisal opening is about 49 mm, excursion movement to the right 5 mm, to the left 9 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows that she is missing the mandibular third molars and maxillary right third molar, but the left third molar is still present. Sinuses look clear. The septum appears to be deviated off towards the left side. Turbinates particularly on the right side are moderate in size. It is difficult to evaluate the condyles. Axial views show that she has moderately enlarged turbinates. Sinuses, however, appear clear. Frontal view shows the turbinates are moderately enlarged and sinuses are clear. Right TMJ tomograms show what appears to be relatively normal joint space. In the coronal views on the right side, the joint space looks reasonably good as well
In the left TMJ tomograms, there appears to be actually greater joint space vertically as compared to the opposite side. The condyle appears to have reasonably good morphology. Coronal views likewise show reasonably good joint space. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B365 has retrusion of the mandible. She has a significantly decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of about 3 mm at the soft palate level and about 7 mm at the base of the tongue.

B365 's boyfriend has observed that she does stop breathing at night and this concerns him. Apparently, this is a common occurrence.
Basic diagnoses for B365 would be as follows:

Left TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc dislocation with early reduction. AP mandibular hypoplasia.
Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia.
Slight anterior maxillary hyperplasia.
Class II end-on occlusion on the right side, but basic Class I on the left.
High occlusal plane angle of 15 degrees (normal 8 degrees).
Decreased oropharyngeal airway of 3 mm (normal 11 mm).
Hypertrophied soft palate.
TMJ pain.
Sleep apnea syndrome. Hypertrophied nasal turbinates causing nasal airway obstruction.
Crowding of the lower anterior arch. Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally in case any interdental osteotomies are necessary.
Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing at least 2 mm of tooth structure to keep from flaring them any further forward.
Surgery.
Left TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it forward and down graft it posteriorly. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (UPPP). Anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to advance the genial muscles.
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies.
Extraction of maxillary left third molar.
3. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

Shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. There appears to be discal tissue in position on this side. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly 1 to 2 mm. In some other views, however, the disc could be anterior and medially displaced.

Right TMJ coronal view shows reasonably good condylar morphology. There is some discal tissue that appears to be displaced medially. Otherwise, joint space looks fairly good. The disc appears to be in position.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. There is slightly decrease posterior joint space in some views. Out laterally, the disc is not as obvious as is medial. More medially, the disc is anteriorly displaced, although there does appear to be some condensed tissue over the top of the condyle. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. On opening, there is reduction of the disc relatively early and there is good translation of the condyle and disc. There is some slight sclerosis on the head of the condyle and some slight anterior beaking. There is some fluid in the superior joint space.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a little flattening of the condylar head at the lateral aspect of the joint. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. Articular disc appears to be in position. On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the disc.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc anteriorly dislocated but with early reduction. Right TMJ relatively normal architecture.

original_note:
B255 
Met with him and his mother at my home for about 2-1/2 hours discussing his conditions and recommended treatment. Reviewed the MRIs showing the arthritis and also the indicators of a displaced articular disc that does reduce bilaterally. Doesn't have many TMJ symptoms but does at times get some pain in his jaw joints. Has no problems with headaches, earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, or any of those factors as previously recorded. He and his mother definitely agree that the mandible has grown off to the left side in the last couple of years, and it has been a couple of years since his completed his previous orthodontics. Discussed the pros and cons of doing the joint procedure. If the high condylectomies are not done, he has a good probability of continuing to grow on the right side. If the discs are not repositioned, then there is a risk of worsening arthritis particularly since he already has arthritic changes present in both joints. Discussed activities postsurgery as well as dietary restrictions. Discussed the necessity for doing both jaws in order to get the best functional and aesthetic result as compared to doing just the lower jaw or just the upper jaw. Discussed the locations of incisions. The biggest problem affecting them in the financial aspect and the fact that I am not on their plan. They have already met with Dr. . Dr. has told them that he doesn't do joint work. Suggested that possibly Pedro Franco is probably on their plan and would be a possibility for them if the financial factors will control whom they will see. I answered all the questions that B255 and his mother had at this time. Discussed at length sinuses problems, turbinates, etc. The mother, who is an allergist, is more concerned about the middle turbinates. A CAT scan apparently was done that I have not seen, but she says that there are some abnormalities in the middle turbinates. I told her that those could be reduced at the time of surgery. Apparently Dr. told them that the middle turbinates can't be approached during the procedure. I also strongly suggested that the inferior turbinates be reduced in size, and the mother is concerned as to how much is removed as she says she has experienced people who have developed atrophic rhinitis as a result of that treatment. I think likely those are patients that may have been on long-term steroids or other nasal conditions prior to the reduction turbinectomies. They are to contact me if they have any other questions or concerns.

B255  CT Scan Evaluation
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading: 
On CT of the sinuses, he has extremely large frontal sinuses particularly on the right side where the sinus extends the entire way out to the lateral orbital rim. On the right side, the sinuses are quite a bit smaller but still extend probably almost half way across the orbit. Appears to have a sinusitis in the left frontal sinus where there is some definite thickening, perhaps a mucous retention cyst in the sinus toward the lateral aspect. Maxillary sinuses are quite large. There is no evidence of any sinusitis there. The ethmoid sinuses are also quite large with more septae on the left side than the right side. The inferior turbinates are hyperplastic particularly on the right side. The right turbinate almost totally obliterates the right nasal airway. Left turbinate is quite large, but there is better airway passage on that side. The middle turbinates have a very abnormal shape to them where they actually curve in toward the lateral nasal bones and have essentially a reverse curvature associated with them. The ostium is located quite high beneath the superior aspect of the middle turbinates. The nasal septum is relatively straight. Only the right TMJ is seen in the coronal view, and it shows a significantly decreased joint space vertically. Lateral pole of the condyle is located quite inferior to the medial pole. Impression:
Normal-appearing bilateral maxillary sinuses and bilateral ethmoid sinuses
Extremely large maxillary right frontal sinus but clear of pathology
Left frontal sinus mucous retention cyst versus thickening of the lining at the lateral aspect of the sinus
Hypertrophied inferior turbinates with the right side being extremely large and almost obliterative of the nasal airway
Bilateral middle turbinates with significantly abnormal pathology with a reverse curvature and hyperplasia

Recommendations:
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies
Bilateral partial middle turbinectomies
B255  MRI Evaluation

Date of Reading:

Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that is a little bit hard to identify. Head may be overrotated. Condyle appears a little bit narrow. Joint space is difficult to determine. Disc position is difficult to determine. Does appear that there is a decreased joint space vertically.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with good mediolateral width, and the condyle appears larger than the opposite side. Appears to be significantly decreased joint space. Articular disc may be medially displaced. Cortical bone appears to be intact on the condyle and in the fossa.

Axial views show that both condyles are fairly broad mediolaterally. Cannot identify the disc on these views.
Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that out laterally appears to have a fairly good shape but toward the middle and medial aspect there is anterior beaking present. Decreased vertical joint space is present. Difficult to tell where the articular disc is but appears that it may be anteriorly and medially displaced. Appears to be a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space.

On opening, there is restricted translation. Appears that the disc may be in position. Condyle looks narrow anteroposteriorly compared to the opposite side.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that appears a little bit broader anteroposteriorly compared to the opposite side. Out laterally there appears to be a little bit of flattening on the anterior head of the condyle. Appears to be decreased joint space superiorly. Articular disc appears to be anteriorly displaced sitting beneath the articular eminence. Articular eminence is relatively shallow in its slope. On opening, there is a question as to whether the articular disc reduces or not.
Impression:
Left TMJ arthritis and possibly anteromedial displacement of the articular disc Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation and possibly nonreducing

B255 
B255 is 17 years old.
Patient History
As far as noting any problems, this has only been within the last one to two years. B255 has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, or headaches. He gets periodic TMJ discomfort, more so on the left side. B255 has undergone significant previous orthodontics with Dr. __. He had ortho for about five or six years and had palatal expanders and a number of different appliances. B255 originally did have a lot of difficulties eating and chewing because of a crossbite problem. Dr. ____ retired, and they transferred to Dr. ____. At the completion of orthodontic treatment approximately two years ago, the bite was satisfactory. Since then, there has been a significant shift of the lower jaw off toward the left side and development of an anterior crossbite. He has no headache problems. He gets periodic TMJ discomfort, the last time being a couple of weeks ago that registered at about a level of 4 predominantly on the left side. On an average day, he really doesn't have any significant pain or headache problem. He rates his jaw function at 2 and diet and disability at 0. He does have a significant history of sinus problems and difficulties breathing through his nose. He does experience significant problems with his ears when he flies probably due to change in air pressure. He has difficulties clearing his ears after plane flights. Recent tympanogram revealed that there was fluid in just the left ear.

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B255 has fairly good facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is 2 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline is shifted off to the left side approximately 3 mm. Mandibular dental midline and chin are fairly well aligned with each other. Therefore, chin is also shifted off to the left side about 3 mm.

In profile view, B255 has probably about 4 or 5 mm of AP deficiency in the maxilla. In the upper orbital area, may be just slightly retruded by about 2 to 3 mm. Chin also may be just slightly AP deficient by about 3 to 4 mm. Chin-neckline appears fairly normal in length and chin-neck angle is fairly well-defined.

Intraorally, B255 has all of his lower teeth back through the second molars. He has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower anterior arch. Has fairly good attached gingiva around the lower anterior teeth. A little bit of inflammation about his lower anteriors. In the upper arch, B255 has all of his teeth back through the second molars present. B255 has a Class III cuspid relationship on the right side by about 4 mm and on the left side by probably about 2 mm. Maxilla appears fairly symmetric in anteroposterior position. Slight cant in the transverse plane with the left side being about a millimeter lower than the right side. Oropharynx appears clear. May have a bifid uvula present, but otherwise everything looks relatively normal. Appears to have good oropharyngeal airway space. B255 has a 0 over bite relationship. Is tending toward a crossbite on the left side, and he has an anterior crossbite tendency particularly on the left side. Right side central and lateral incisor are end-on with the lower lateral incisor and cuspid.

Intranasally, the nasal septum is deviated a little bit of toward the right side but not really significantly. Right turbinate is quite enlarged creating a decreased airway on that side. Left inferior turbinate is moderate in size, but there appears to be a little bit greater airway on the left side as compared to the right side. Both turbinates could be hyperplastic and causing some airway problems. Cannot see posteriorly to evaluate the airway dimension at that level.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows that all four third molars are absent. Sinuses appear reasonably clear. Appears there could be some obstruction in the left nasal airway more toward the posterior aspect. Right side shows a turbinate that is enlarged, but it appears there is a little bit of airway at the base of the nose. Has a 3 x 3 retainer in the lower arch. Right condyle appears larger than the left one both in anteroposterior width and in vertical height.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that actually appears narrow anteroposteriorly compared to the size of the fossa. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. Decreased superior joint space indicative of possible anterior and/or medial displacement of the articular disc. Occlusion is Class III.

Left TMJ tomogram shows that there is a decreased superior and posterior joint space. Condyle appears somewhat narrow anteroposteriorly compared to the size of the fossa. Articular eminence is relatively shallow. Less of a Class III occlusal tendency on this side.

On opening, there appears to be a greater restriction of translation on the left side as compared to the right side, although both of they are a little bit shy of translating onto the apex of the articular eminence.

Waters view demonstrates that the septum may be a little bit of toward the right side. Right turbinate is extremely large and essentially obliterates the right nasal airway. Left side does demonstrate some passable airway. There is either enlargement of the middle turbinate or a polyp present in the right side. It most likely may be the middle turbinate. Sinuses look relatively clear and equally lucent on either side.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that he has a skeletal Class III relationship. Has and end-on incisor relationship. Vertical height of the mandible is fairly symmetric with just about a 2-mm difference at the inferior borders. Oropharyngeal airway looks relatively normal. Soft tissues thickness at pogonion is decreased. Tongue looks relatively normal size. Maximal incisal opening for B255 is 41 mm and about 36 mm without discomfort. Excursive movement to the right is 6 mm and to the left 7 mm.

Basic Diagnoses
Right TMJ condylar hyperplasia and medial displacement of the articular disc Left TMJ arthritis and medial displacement of the articular disc AP maxillary hypoplasia
Mandibular deviate prognathism
Class III occlusion on the right side and moderate Class III occlusion on the left side
Anterior crossbite and developing left posterior crossbite
TMJ pain
Hypertrophied nasal turbinates
Nasal airway obstruction
Chronic sinus problems secondary to nasal airway obstruction

Recommended Treatment
Presurgical orthodontics Align and level maxillary arch. Keep the lateral incisor roots tipped mesially and cuspid roots tipped distally. May need to tip the right lateral incisor root more mesial than it currently is to provide adequate room for interdental osteotomies
Align and level mandibular arch

Surgery
Right TMJ high condylectomy and articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor
Left TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance, expand, and level the occlusal plane
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to align the mandible back on the facial midline
Bilateral partial turbinectomies

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B255 
Telephone conversation. Last week he had a couple of days when he had increased clicking in his jaw joints where it would click about every hour. This was slightly uncomfortable, but not too bad. This week he is feeling better. He is going to get a night guard made. He has an Essex retainer which is an equal thickness over the occlusal surfaces and it is not good for his occlusion. I told him that could intrude the posterior teeth creating a posterior open bite for him. He understands. He does have an appointment to met the splint man and I told him to be sure that all of the teeth touch in the splint. He has not been taking Klonopin. I explained to him what the problems are that are going on. I explained to him that since his mother did not allow us to use a Mitek anchor that the system we had to use is not strong and supportive of the disc. With his clenching and bruxism that could tear any system apart. Hopefully, he will get better with the splint. Otherwise, he is doing well and enjoying dental school. He is to keep me informed of his progress

B226
B226 is 13 years old, referred by Dr. XXXX. B226 is in good health with no major medical problems. B226 does have some asthma problems that sometimes are exercise-induced. He takes Ventolin when needed. He is on no other medications. He does have problems breathing through his nose and one side is pretty much blocked off.

PRIMARY CONCERNS
1. Facial imbalance.
2. Nasal airway obstruction.
3. Predominately mouth breather.
B226 has had orthodontics for about 2 to 3 years but the braces were not placed on all of the teeth, just some of the teeth. B226 has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, hearing loss, headaches, TMJ pain or myofascial pain. In frontal view B226 has good left to right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth to lip relationship about 8 mm. Maxillary midline, mandibular dental midline in line with each other. In profile, he has some prominence in the nasal dorsum. The nasal labial angle has pretty good form to it. He has lip incompetence of probably about 10 mm. Cheeks are somewhat sallow by maybe 3 to 4 mm. The lower third face is elongated. Lower lip is everted. The chin appears to be AP deficient by probably about 15 to 18 mm. As he postures his mandible forward, he does have better chin projection. There is a little deficiency in maxillary projection as well. There may be about 3 to 4 mm AP deficient. He does have hyperfunction of mentalis muscle. He has all of his teeth back through the second molars with good attached gingiva. In the upper arch he has all of his teeth back through the second molars present. He has a Class II occlusion with an overjet of about 4 mm. He has a vertical overbite of about 2 mm. The uvula is moderately enlarged. The soft palate may be mildly elongated. The faucial pillars appear fairly significantly constricted. Tonsils are present. The septum is deviated a little bit off to the right side. Turbinates are hyperplastic particularly the left one which is quite large. The nasal airway appears quite constricted. The nasal luminal valves appear fairly constricted. Holding the luminal valves open did not seem to improve his ability to breathe through his nose. He has no tenderness to palpation around the head and neck area. Maximal incisal opening is 50 mm. Excursive movements are 8 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of all 4 developing third molars. The rest of the teeth are all erupted in place. Turbinates appear fairly large. Difficult to evaluate the sinuses. The condyles look relatively normal.

Waters view shows that the sinuses appear relatively clear although the right maxillary sinus appears quite small in size compared to the left one. Turbinates appear to pretty much obliterate the nasal airway. The right side looks larger than the left side at least posteriorly.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to be normal in architecture. There may be some anterior beaking. There could be a little bit of decreased superior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular eminence is moderately shallow.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly reasonable morphology with perhaps a little flattening on top in one area. The joint space looks pretty good. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. On opening, there is good translation of both joints.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B226 has anterior vertical maxillary excess and AP mandibular deficiency. Occlusion is Class II and he is skeletal Class II. Oropharyngeal airway for the most part looks good except he has an adenoid tissue mass in the nasopharynx that almost touches the turbinates. The turbinate extends posterior to the hard palate. There may be 2 mm of airway space between the posterior aspect of the turbinate and the adenoid tissue. He has significant lip incompetence. He has a vertical bite of at least a couple of millimeters. He does have a left posterior crossbite. With a Class I occlusal relationship, the crossbite worsens. There is tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm.

BASIS DIAGNOSES
1. Anterior vertical maxillary excess.
2. Transverse maxillary deficiency.
3. AP mandibular deficiency.
4. Class II occlusion.
5. Posterior crossbite on the left side.
6. Hypertrophied turbinates.
7. Nasoseptal deviation.
8. Nasopharyngeal adenoid tissue.
9. Nasal airway obstruction.
10. Impacted third molars x4.
11. High occlusal plane angle.
12. Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
1. Presurgical orthodontics. a. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisal roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. b. Align and level mandibular arch. Strip the lower anterior teeth removing about 2 mm of tooth structure and retract to correct the tooth size discrepancy.
2. Surgery. a. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to move it superiorly and level the occlusal plane angle. b. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction. c. Partial nasal turbinectomies. d. Nasoseptoplasty. e. Surgical removal of impacted third molars x4.
3. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B226 MRI EVALUATION
AGE:
Left TMJ coronal view shows good mediolateral width of the condyle. There is some decreased lateral joint space. Disc space appears to be medially displaced. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly just 1 to 2 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. The disc appears to be medially displaced with a slightly decreased joint space. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly just 1 to 2 mm.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has a little bit of flattening on the posterior head and a little bit of anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is fairly steep particularly towards the lateral aspect of the joint. Disc is not as easily identified at the lateral aspect of the joint as it is over medially. Medially, the disc appears to be in fairly good position. No inflammatory process seen around the joint. On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the disc appears to be in position.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has a little bit better morphology than the opposite side. There is some slight anterior beaking present. However, the disc appears to be in position. Lateral the disc is a little bit more difficult to see. No inflammatory process is seen in the joint. The articular eminence is fairly steep particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint, a little less inclined more medial. On opening, there is good translation and the articular disc is in a good reduced position.

IMPRESSION:
Bilateral TMJ mild arthritic changes and articular disc possibly medially displaced.
