original_note:
B278
B278 is 19 years old and referred by Dr. ___.
Patient History
She has had previous biopsy of a lymph node behind her ear. She does have mold allergy. B278 is in good health with no major medical problems. She takes Yasmin and Glucophage for polycystic ovaries. B278 has had orthodontics twice before and now has her orthodontic appliances on for the third time and just got these on this year. B278 has had orthodontics x 3. The first time was from 8 to 10 years ago. The second time was 6 to 7 ago. She then went about five years without too much of a change and then her bite started to change again, and her bite started to open more. That is when she went to her dad and said she was ready to proceed on, and then she got braces few months ago. She has seen Dr. __  for surgery.

Patient Concerns
Jaws and teeth don't fit together properly
Difficult to get her teeth together
Predominantly a mouth breather
Possible difficulties breathing through the nose particularly at night when she sleeps
Some pain and discomfort through the jaws

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B278 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is almost 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 3.5 to 4 mm. Nasal tip is just slightly off to the right side probably 1 to 2 mm. Maxillary dental midline appears to be pretty much on the facial midline as is the mandibular dental midline and chin.

In profile, B278 has a slight obtuse nasolabial angle. Upper lip supralabrale is probably about 3 to 4 mm anterior to subnasale. She has lip incompetence of about 9 mm. Lower lip is somewhat everted compared to the AP position. The chin-neckline is short, although the chin-neck angle is well-defined. Chin appears to be AP deficiency by probably 10 to 12 mm. Labiomental fold is fairly prominent in part due to the eversion of the lower lip.

Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. Teeth are well aligned and levels. She has really good attached gingiva around the lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars present. There is an accentuated curve of occlusion in the upper arch. She has a Class II end-on cuspid-molar relationship of probably about 3 to 4 mm. She has an anterior open bite of at least 3 mm. Left cuspid is probably a millimeter lower than the right cuspid. She has had her wisdom teeth removed. When occluding, she hits only on her second molars on the right side. She cannot feel the second molars or any of the other teeth touch from the right first molar all the way around to the left second molar. Oropharynx appears clear, and she has a little red spot on her soft palate just to the right of the midline. It measures about 2 mm across. Turbinates are moderately enlarged. The septum may be deviated a little bit off toward the left side. Seems to have moderate airway constricture. Nostrils are a little bit narrow. Holding her nostrils open, she could breathe easier through her nose. Luminal valves could be a little bit constricted as well. She gets tired during the day but could be related just to college life.

Maximal incisal opening is 55 mm. Excursive movements to the right are 9 mm and to the left 100. Joints seem to function fairly smoothly although there were some rough areas in the joints. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the masseter muscles, TMJs, and high moderate pain over the styloid areas. She had a T&A done when she was in the fourth grade.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows that the sinuses look reasonably clear. Difficult to evaluate the nasal airway as it appears that there is some deviation in the septum, and the left airway looks fairly well blocked. Missing all four third molars. Appears to be adequate space between the lateral incisors and the cuspids, although there is a laceration of the maxillary left lateral incisor where it curves back toward the cuspid. It appears that there is enough room to get through there. Condyles appear a little bit abnormal but difficult to tell on those views.

Waters view shows that the sinuses appear clear. Nasal airway appears to be fairly well blocked. A little outward curvature of the angle of the mandible on the right side compared to the left side. This may be due to the fact that she has better tooth contact on the right side than the left side.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to be postured forward in the fossa somewhat, and she is in more of a Class I molar relationship than her centric relation would indicate. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Posterior joint space is increased, but I am sure in centric relationship it is going to be decreased. The space between the condyle and the articular eminence appears decreased and less than normal. This could be indicative of possible medial displacement of the articular disc.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has just a touch of anterior beaking present perhaps. Joint space is a little bit decreased posteriorly and superiorly.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyles bilaterally.
Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a skeletal Class II jaw relationship with a significant anterior open bite. Appears to have vertical maxillary excess but AP mandibular deficiency. There is a vertical difference between the inferior border of the mandible with one side being about 5 mm vertically higher than the opposite side. Oropharyngeal airway looks very good.

B278 has a tooth-size discrepancy. The spacing created in the upper arch between the lateral incisors and cuspids seems to compensate for the tooth-size discrepancy. However, the lower incisors are overangulated, and it would be of advantage to slenderize the lower anterior teeth and retract them some.

Basic Diagnoses
Vertical maxillary excess
AP mandibular deficiency
AP microgenia
Class II end-on occlusion
Anterior open bite
High occlusal plane angle
Accentuated curve of occlusion, upper arch
Overangulation of lower incisors
Tooth-size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2.5 mm
Rule out bilateral TMJ articular disc dislocations
Hypertrophied turbinates
Nasal airway obstruction
Myofascial pain
TMJ pain

Recommended Treatment
Presurgical orthodontics Continue to align and level maxillary arch. If possible, tip maxillary lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally particularly on the left side to help create more space
Continue to align and level mandibular arch. Strip lower anterior teeth removing 2 to 3 mm of tooth structure to correct for the tooth-size discrepancy and to decrease angulation of the lower incisors

Surgery
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to move it superiorly, correct the accentuated curve of Spee, and level the anteroposterior occlusal plane
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors Augmentation genioplasty
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B278 	MRI Scan Evaluation 
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading: 

Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width and possibly some slight loss of vertical dimension but difficult to tell. Downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa of only 1 to 2 mm. Mandibular condyle lateral pole extends beyond the lateral rim of the fossa. Difficult to tell where the discal tissue is, but it may be anteriorly positioned. Vertical joint space appears reasonably good.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. Lateral pole of the condyle extends slightly beyond the lateral rim of the fossa but not quite as far as the opposite side. Moderate downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa of probably 2 mm. Joint space appears to be relatively normal. However, it is difficult to identify the articular disc.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that is flattened on the posterior head particularly toward the lateral aspect of the joint but has a better morphology toward the medial side. Slight anterior beaking present more toward the medial side. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced particularly out toward the lateral aspect of the joint, but toward the medial aspect it appears to be in better position. Joint space looks good throughout, although at the lateral aspect there appears to be decreased posterior joint space. The disc is sitting in a vertical position along the posterior border of the articular eminence. A little bit of fluid in the superior and inferior joint space but not too significant.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the articular disc with reduction on opening.
Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has a little bit of flattening on the posterior head but not quite as much as the opposite side. More medially it has a little bit of flattening on the anterior head. A little sclerosis on the anterior head. A little bit of anterior beaking more pronounced toward the medial aspect of the joint. Articular eminence is fairly steep similar to the opposite side. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced but the lateral aspect of the joint assumes a vertical position directly behind the articular eminence. Toward the medial side, the disc may be in better AP position. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior and inferior joint space but not much.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the articular disc. The disc appears to be well-reduced in the opening views.
Impression:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocated particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint but with reduction
Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocated at the lateral aspect of the joint but reduces

original_note:
B054
B054 is 27 years old. B054's TMJ problems began at the age of 26, about one year and seven months ago when she yawned and her jaw locked open. She had a doctor sedate her and put the joint back into position. Her jaws were wired together for about 3 days afterwards and she had some significant pain associated with that. After 3 days, she came back and was unwrapped and then her jaw was locked closed and shifted towards the left side. She was placed on medications and it apparently it took about a month to realize that there was a closed lock situation. Dr. XXXX then did an arthrocentesis five times with no appreciable relief. She then had physical therapy and she was able to open her jaw but had very strong pain. Surgery was done on one year and two months ago with a disc plication of the temporal mandibular joint. Since that procedure, she continues to have significant pain problems. She continues to have limited opening and because of the pain situation she is unable to chew. Primary concerns that B054 has include the following:

Severe left TMJ pain.
Difficulties opening her mouth.
Unable to chew and is predominantly on a liquid diet.
She has been in splint therapy for two years and has had two splints. She also has had physical therapy. She takes Percocet 5 mg two to three per day and Uptagin, another pain medication.

B054 has no trouble with headaches. She rates her TMJ pain at 9, average daily pain would be at 9, jaw function at 8, diet at 10, disability at 5. She gets pressure in her left ear and has some decreased hearing on that side, but has no tinnitus nor vertigo. Other joints that bother her include her knees and her hips. She is not aware of clenching or bruxing.

In profile view, B054 has good facial symmetry and balance. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars and all of her upper teeth as well. She is basically a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. She has about a 4 mm anterior deep bite relationship. To palpation, she has a pain level of 8 over the left TMJ, but no other pain around the head and neck area. The incisal opening maximally is 26 mm, opening without significant pain 15 mm. The excursion movements are about 3 mm in each direction. Limitation of translation to the left is related to the pain that is created in the left joint without movement. She does not feel that it is due to restriction of the right joint. Oropharyngeal tissues are a little bit difficult to see, but appear relatively normal. Tonsils are maybe mildly enlarged.

Basic diagnoses would be as follows:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc degeneration.
Left TMJ severe pain with severely limited jaw function.
Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints.
2. Surgery. a.	Left TMJ condylectomy, diskectomy, and reconstruction with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. b.	Left TMJ fat graft (harvest from the abdomen). c.	Application of maxillary and mandibular arch bars with removal at the end of surgery.

Dr. XXXX had proposed cutting off the condyle and just leaving her a swing where she would develop facial asymmetry. I gave B054 the option of repeating the disc repositioning procedure to set the disc a little bit more posteriorly and more laterally over the condylar head and also perform a sagittal split osteotomy. However, I do not believe that this will work very good for her and gave her a less than 50 percent chance of success with that procedure. I believe she would have a 90 percent chance of success with the total joint prostheses. I also did warn her that it is possible that after the total joint prosthesis is done on the left side that she could develop a problem on the right side, although out studies have shown if there is a healthy right TMJ she would have about a 75 percent chance of the right side holding up and doing well. She has no pain or symptoms on the right side at all. I did discuss the pros and cons of both procedures with her and her grandmother. I answered all the questions that they had. My personal opinion is that the total joint prostheses would be much predictable for her and would get her the best result. I answered all the questions she and her grandmother had. They understand. I did discuss potential risks and complications such as infection, bleeding, nerve damage, etc. They understand. She believes she is anxious to proceed on with treatment. B054 MRI
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width. There appears to be some erosions or deformity on the lateral pole area of the condyle. There appears to be discal tissue medially displaced. There appear to be some degenerative changes perhaps in the fossa as well.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears about the same size as the opposite site. The condyle appears to have a little bit better morphology to it and not as degenerative. There is decreased superior joint space and the disc appears it may be medially displaced.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is somewhat degenerated. The articular disc appears to be in reasonably good position, although there are some degenerative factors associated with it. The condyle appears to have some erosions on the head and some little osteophytic kind of formation. It appears there may be some fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, there is restricted translation of the condyle and the disc. It appears that the disc reduced on opening.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit larger than the opposite side. The disc appears to be more degenerated on this side. The disc appears to be anteriorly displaced. The articular eminence is steep and the disc appears to be in vertical orientation. There are some areas of erosion and/or small osteophytic formations more towards the lateral aspect of the joint. There is a little bit of anterior beaking present medially. On opening, there is limited translation of the condyle and the disc.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ arthritis with a disc medially displaced, but AP in normal position with degeneration.
Right TMJ arthritis and the disc anteriorly and medially displaced with early reduction.
Bilateral restricted translation.

original_note:
B211
B211 is 16 years old. She began orthodontic treatment in the 4th grade, approximately age 10 and she wore headgear for 3 years at night. She had some appliances on by the original orthodontist and then were removed. She subsequently went to see Dr. XXXX and 9 months ago, Dr. XXXX placed orthodontic appliances.

PRIMARY CONCERNS:
1. Retruded jaws.
2. Difficulties eating and chewing.
3. Teeth do not fit together very well.
4. Snoring.
5. Difficulties breathing through the nose.

She takes no medications. She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. No other joints bother her. She is not aware of clenching or bruxing. She does get headaches at about a level of 7 that occur in the frontal and the top of the head area but only occur about 2 times per month. She rates her TMJ pain at 0, average daily pain at 0, jaw function at 1, diet at 4, disability at 3. She is aware of snoring at night but has no problems with daytime somnolence or sleep apnea.

In frontal view, B211 has fairly good facial balance in the middle and upper third face. Upper lip length when held forward is about 20 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is at least 6 mm. Mandibular dental midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Maxillary midline may be about 1 mm to the left. Chin may be just slightly to the right. A little bit of orbital dystopia with the right eye being 1 to 2 mm higher than the left side. In profile view, upper lip supralabrale is probably about at least 3 maybe 4 mm posterior to subnasale. The maxilla appears to be retruded probably a good 6 to 8 mm. Chin is retruded by about 20 mm. Chin-neckline is extremely short though the chin-neck angle is moderately well defined but very obtuse. Intraorally, B211 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has appliances on now. Some minor crowding in the lower arch but also a little bit of spacing. In the upper arch she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has an unusual shape of the upper arch with some flattening around the front and some mild crowding in that area as well. She has segmental archwires on currently. She has about a 3 mm anterior open bite. She occludes on the right side on the first and second molars and second bicuspids and the same on the left side. She has a Class II end-on occlusion by about 5 mm. She has a crossbite tendency on the right posterior side. Oropharyngeal airway looks reasonably healthy. The uvula and soft palate appear normal. Faucial pillars appear moderately constricted. Tonsils seem relatively normal in size. She has a wide columella and somewhat narrow nostrils. Septum appears reasonably straight. Turbinates appear moderately enlarged particularly for the narrow transverse dimension of the nose itself. To palpation, B211 has no pain around the head and neck area. Joints function smoothly. Incisal opening is about 52 mm. Maximal incisal opening is 52 mm. Excursive movement to the right 7 mm, left 8 mm.

B211
Page 2

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
: Panorex shows the presence of 4 impacted third molars. The rest of the teeth are present. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Septum appears relatively straight. Difficult to evaluate the condyles but the left one looks a little different than the right side. Cuspid roots are tipped mesially.

Waters view shows that the bony septum at least is fairly straight. The turbinates appear moderately enlarged with significant blockage of the airway. Sinuses appear relatively clear.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. There may be a little sclerosis on the top of it. Joint space appears fairly balanced.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. Joint space appears reasonably balanced. Articular eminence is moderately steep in both joints. On opening there is good translation of both joints. The left condyle appears as though there may be some anterior beaking present.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B211 has a retruded maxilla and severely retruded mandible. She has anterior open bite. She has a high occlusal plane angle facial morphology. Oropharyngeal airway is only about 2.5 mm at the base of the tongue and no more than 3 mm at the soft palate level. She has some prominence of the nasal dorsum. Bolton analysis shows that there is some relatively small tooth size discrepancy although on the model assessment it appears that the upper laterals are small. On the other hand it appears that the lower teeth may have been slenderized.

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
1. Severe AP mandibular deficiency.
2. AP maxillary deficiency.
3. Anterior vertical maxillary excess.
4. High occlusal plane angle.
5. Class II end-on occlusion.
6. Anterior open bite of 3 mm.
7. Severely decreased oropharyngeal airway of 2 mm (normal dimension 11 mm.)
8. Snoring.
9. Crowding of maxillary arch.
10. Mild crowding of lower anterior arch.
11. Impacted maxillary and mandibular third molars x4.
12. Wide columella and narrow nostrils.

B211
Page 3
RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
1. MRI of left and right TMJs.
2. Presurgical orthodontics. a. Align and level maxillary arch. Use a continuous archwire in the upper arch. Tip the lateral incisor mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies if necessary. Disconnect second molars from the archwire. b. Align and level mandibular arch. Disconnect second molars from the archwire.
3. Surgery. a. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to move the anterior aspect superiorly, level the curve of Spee and correct the transverse cant in the occlusion. b. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise rotation with pogonion coming forward approximately 20 mm. c. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. d. Nasal columella reconstruction. e. Surgical removal of impacted third molars x4.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B211
MRI EVALUATION
Age: 16/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm. Difficult to identify discal tissue between the condyle and fossa. The disc may be anteriorly displaced. Joint space seems adequate although slightly decreased out laterally.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. There appears to be adequate joint space but difficult to identify discal tissue. There may be discal tissue anterior to the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm. Transverse width of the fossa on the right side seems more narrow as compared to the left side.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears a little bit arthritic. There is some flattening on the posterior head and a little bit of flattening on the anterior head. Articular eminence is relatively normal in inclination. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting down towards the articular eminence. There does not appear to be any significant fluid within the joint space. No open static views are included unfortunately in this study.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some arthritic changes with a little bit of flattening on the posterior had and a little bit towards the anterior aspect. The articular disc is more prominent towards the lateral aspect of the joint than the medial aspect. The disc is anteriorly displaced sitting down wards the articular eminence. I would suspect that the disc would reduce on opening but no open static views are available.

IMPRESSION:
1. Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with probable reduction (open static views not available.)
2. Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with probable reduction (open static views not available.)

original_note:
B075
B075 is 15 years and 10  months of age. B075 was born with a cleft palate that was repaired at the age of 7 months. He then had a pharyngeal flap performed at the age of 4. He has had several sets of tubes in his ears. He takes no medications except occasional allergy medicines. He has no problems with headaches, TMJ pain, tinnitus, or vertigo. He gets occasional earaches. No other joints are of concern at this time. He rates jaw function at 9, diet at 1, and disability at 0.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B075 has good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 19 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 2 mm. The maxillary midline is probably about 3 mm off to the left side. The mandibular dental midline is about 1 mm off to the left side. The chin is about 1 mm off to the left side. In profile view, upper lip is probably about 5 mm AP deficient and the chin is about 20 mm AP deficient. Chin neckline is extremely short, although the chin neck angle is reasonably well defined. He has fairly good balance between the upper lip, cheeks, and nose. Intraorally, B075 is missing the lower first bicuspids that were extracted for orthodontic reasons. The lower teeth are almost a little bit over retracted. In the upper arch, he is missing the first bicuspids and may be missing the second bicuspids all on the left side. He has an anterior open bite of about 1 to 2 mm. He has a Class II cuspid relationship on the right side and to a lesser extent a non-Class II relationship on the left side. Upper teeth are pulled back in significantly lingual inclination. He has adequate attached gingiva, although the gingiva are somewhat inflamed. The lower arch is fairly symmetric relative to the AP position of the cuspids. In the upper arch, the left cuspid is probably about 3 mm posterior to the right cuspid. He has a nice repair on the palate. There is a pharyngeal flap present with an oronasal opening in the mid part of the flap. The palate appears nicely repaired. Intranasally, the turbinates appear relatively normal as does the septum. He has some mild nasal airway obstruction. He has moderate to severe snoring, moderate daytime somnolence, but does not have any sleep apnea symptoms apparently. He has a moderate sleep disorder. B075 tends to breathe more through his mouth than his nose except when he is out in public when it gets much easier. B075 has no tenderness around the head and neck area to palpation. Joints function smoothly. Incisal opening is 43 mm and excursion movements are about 7 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of four impacted third molars. He is missing the first bicuspids in all 4 quadrants plus the second bicuspid in the left maxillary quadrant. Right sinus appears to have something in it. It is difficult to evaluate the TMJs. Waters view shows that there is a septal spur going off the right side of the septum. Turbinates are moderate in size. Sinuses look relatively clear. Right TMJ tomogram shows that a condyle that has fairly good morphology and there appears to reasonable joint space, though difficult to evaluate radiograph. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Left TMJ tomogram is likewise a little bit hard to read, but it appears that everything is relatively normal there. On opening, there is good translation of both condyles. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B075 has a retruded maxilla, significantly retruded mandible, and a high occlusal plane angle. He has a low positioned pharyngeal flap also present. Upper and lower incisors are decreased in angulation. He has a head postured forward neck position.

Basic diagnoses for B075 would be as follows:
Repaid palatal cleft.
Posterior pharyngeal flap. AP maxillary hypoplasia. Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia.
AP mandibular hypoplasia. Class II occlusion on the right side, Class II end-on occlusion on the left side. Missing appears second bicuspids in the lower arch, maxillary right second bicuspid, and mandibular left first and second bicuspids. Maxillary dental midline shifted 3 mm to the left of the facial midline. Anterior open bite.
Impacted third molars x4.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics. Continue to align and level maxillary arch. Open up space between the left cuspid and first molar to equal about 6 mm (about the same width as the bicuspid on the opposite side) as this will improve the overall dental fit as well as flare the upper incisors forward and align them better on to the facial midline.
Continue to align and level mandibular arch. Monitor facial growth and development.
Surgery.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it forward about 6 mm, level it transversely, and expand if necessary. Lengthen the pharyngeal flap, if necessary, to accommodate the maxillary advancement. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible forward approximately 18 mm. Surgical removal of impacted third molars x4.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
5. Restorative dentistry. a. Place osteointegrated implant to the maxillary left bicuspid area. b. Place crown on maxillary left implant.

B075 MRI AGE: 17/M
Left TMJ coronal view shows a small condyle with significant loss of condylar structure. There is decreased superior joint space. There may be discal tissue anterior to the condyle. Lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat with a downward curvature of probably about 2 mm. There may be a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is small in size with loss of vertical and mediolateral volume. This condyle appears a little bit larger than the opposite side. There appears to be decreased joint space vertically. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably a couple of millimeters. Difficult to identify discal tissue, but there may be some anterior to the condyle. There may be a little bit of fluid in the right joint space.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears arthritic and sclerotic. There appears to be decreased vertical joint space. The articular disc appears to be anteriorly displaced and sitting towards the articular eminence. The articular eminence is moderately steep, but appears elongated. The disc appears to be deformed. On opening, it appears that the disc does reduce in position.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have undergone resorption and is very narrow anteroposteriorly with a decreased superior and posterior joint space. The disc is anteriorly displaced. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. On opening, the disc appears to reduce and there is moderately good translation of the condyle. The disc itself, however, does not appear to move very well and may be adhered to the fossa.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ resorptive arthritis and articular discs anteriorly dislocated, but it appears there is reduction on opening but with deformation of the articular discs.

original_note:
B525
B525 is 15 years old, referred by Dr. XXXX.

Patient History
Last month, B525 had her tonsils removed. Apparently she had lots of problems with tonsillitis, and her tonsils were huge even then noninflamed. B525 has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. Other joints that bother her include her neck and her knees occasionally. She has usual environmental kind of allergies. If she wears cheap earrings, it can cause some ear problems for her. She is not aware of clenching or bruxing her teeth at night. She had a tonsillectomy done last month. She was in a motor vehicle accident about 6 years ago, and about 2 years ago she fell down the stairs at school. About two or three years ago, she began for an unknown reason to develop locking in her jaw joints and clicking and popping. She really has not had any specific treatment to date yet. Dr. XXXX has been following her since she was about 8 or 9 years old but has not initiated treatment yet because he is still waiting for the permanent teeth to erupt in. About two or three years ago, B525's jaw began to start to lock up on her. She is not aware of any particular reason why the joints started to lock up on her. To date she has had no specific treatment for her situation.

Patient Concerns
Teeth don't fit together very well
Locking in the jaw joints
Clicking and popping in the jaw joints
Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B525 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 19 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 4 mm. Maxillary midline may be about a millimeter off to the left of the facial midline.

In profile view, she has a little bit of deficiency in the upper lip projection of probably about 3 to 4 mm. Lower lip is in fairly good balance with the upper lip, although the chin is somewhat prominent. Chin is anterior to the lower lip by probably 4 to 5 mm.

Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. Left second bicuspid is just starting to erupt into the oral cavity . Lower incisors appear to be in lingual version. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth through the second molars. Upper lateral incisors look somewhat small. She has an end-on Class III cuspid relationship. She has an anterior overbite of about a millimeter. She has an open-bite greater on the left side from the lateral incisor back to the first molar. On the right side, there is a lesser degree of open bite, but still significant. B525 has bilateral posterior crossbites and end-on incisor relation. Teeth include the left maxillary first and second molar, mandibular second molar, four central incisors, right second bicuspid through second molar in the upper arch, and in the lower arch first and second molar.

To palpation, she has moderate pain over the TMJs and milder pain over the masseter and styloid areas. Joints seem to function reasonably smoothly at this particular time though she does say that her jaws occasionally get locked. Incisal opening is 48 mm. Excursive movements are 7 mm in each direction. On opening, the joints seem to function relatively smoothly at this particular time.

Radiographic Evaluation
The middle part of the Panorex is blocked off, so I cannot see the teeth from the left central incisor through the right first bicuspid in the upper arch and in the lower arch from lower cuspid to right second bicuspid. There are impacted mandibular third molars x 2 but do not see any maxillary third molars. The condyles appear to have fairly good morphology. Sinuses appear reasonably clear.

Waters view shows that there appears to be some deviation of the nasal septum back in the bony aspect. Turbinates are moderately enlarged. Sinuses appear clear.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to have fairly good morphology. Articular eminence is sort of moderate in steepness. Disc appears to be a little bit posteriorly positioned in the fossa with a slightly increased anterior space.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. Joint space may be slightly decreased posteriorly. Articular eminence is a little bit more shallow on this side than the opposite side.

Open views show good translation of the condyles where the condyles come out beyond the articular eminences.
Basic Diagnoses
Rule out bilateral TMJ condylar hyperplasia and articular disc dislocations
AP maxillary deficiency
Transverse maxillary deficiency
Slight vertical maxillary excess
Mandibular prognathism
Class III occlusion Significant lingual inclination of lower incisors
AP soft tissue macrogenia
Impacted mandibular third molars x 2
Tooth-size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of about 1.5 to 2 mm
Hypertrophied turbinates
Nasal airway obstruction
TMJ pain
Myofascial pain
Headaches

Recommended Treatment
Presurgical orthodontics Align and level maxillary arch. Consider opening up spacing around the upper lateral incisors of about a millimeter around each tooth to account for the tooth-size discrepancy. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Be careful not to expand the upper arch too much because she already has an accentuated curve of Wilson, and she will need surgical expansion anyway to get a good fit
Align and level mandibular arch. Try to tip lower incisor teeth forward as far as possible. This will likely create an anterior crossbite. If it does create an anterior crossbite, this will actually be to advantage

Continue to monitor growth for condylar hyperplasia and for TMJ disc dislocations
Consider possible repeat of MRI
Surgery
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to reposition the mandible in a clockwise direction
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it forward, expand it, and move the posterior aspect superiorly slightly
Partial turbinectomies
Removal of mandibular impacted third molars
Consider bilateral TMJ high condylectomies and articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors if condylar hyperplasia is identified and/or disc displacements are confirmed

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B525 MRI Scan Evaluation
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading:

No coronal views are available.
Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that appears a little bit flattened on top particularly toward the lateral aspect of the joint. More medially the condyle appears to have better confirmation. Out laterally the disc is not seen as well which could be indicative of a medial displacement. Otherwise disc appears to be in fairly good position. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. At least some views show what appears to be an attempt to open with significant restriction, although the disc appears to be reduced in position. Translation is fairly minimal in the joint, if, in fact, these are open views. Articular eminence is moderately shallow.

Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has a little bit of flattening superiorly particularly toward the lateral aspect. More medially it has a little bit better confirmation. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. In one T-2 view, it appears that the disc could be sitting beneath the articular eminence, and on a couple other views it tends to indicate that it may be anteriorly displaced on this side. There is some fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces.

Impression:
Left TMJ mild arthritis. Articular disc appears to be in good position although there could be a slight medial displacement
Right TMJ articular disc possible displacement

B525 MRI Evaluation
Date of Acquisition:
Date of Interpretation:
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with head and neck that appears extremely long. Disc appears anteriorly displaced more so at the lateral aspect of the joint. There is decreased posterior joint space. The condylar head appears narrow anteroposteriorly in the mid aspect of the condyle. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Right TMJ shows similar elongated head and neck of the condyle. Posterior aspect of the condyle appears a little bit flattened and the condyle appears narrow in the mid part the joint as well as over medially. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc appears to be in a vertical orientation and anteriorly displaced. There is a decreased posterior joint space. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. It also extends posteriorly in the posterior sulcus.

Left coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. The lateral head of the condyle comes out even with the lateral rim of the fossa. There appears to be decreased joint space at the lateral aspect of the joint at the lateral rim. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm. Difficult to identify discal tissue but in one view it appears that it may be medially displaced. Decreased joint spaces mainly at the lateral aspect of the joint. In the T2 films, the condyle appears much larger but very difficult to identify discal tissue. Open view of left TMJ shows that there is good translation of the condyle. The condylar head appears extremely narrow and again the head and neck appear quite elongated. The condyle comes anterior to the articular eminence. It appears that the disc may be in position.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has relatively normal mediolateral width. There is a significantly decreased joint space at the lateral aspect of the joint. Cortex appears to be intact in the fossa and condyle but the bone is extremely thin in the fossa. Cannot see evidence of the disc in this view. Right TMJ T2 images show what appears to be a little bit better size to the condyle as compared what was seen in the T1. Difficult to separate out the discs in these views. In some of these views, condyles appear somewhat large mediolaterally as well as vertically. Right TMJ open view shows likewise good translation of the condyle where it comes anterior to the articular eminence. It appears that the disc is in place and reduces on opening. In the coronal views on opening, also there appears to be good translation forward and it appears that the discal tissues are in place in the open views.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ elongation of the head and neck of the condyles compatible with condylar hyperplasia.
Bilateral TMJ anterior dislocation of the articular disc with reduction on opening.

Dental model analysis shows that the patient still has bilateral posterior crossbites. Dr. XXXX has opened up significant spacing between the upper laterals and cuspids being about 4 mm on the right side and 3 mm on the left side. He was able to jump the occlusion but she is still end-on Class III by almost 5 mm on the right side and 4 mm on the left side. Still very stable occlusion plus the fact that she has significant pain problems and joint pathology. Cephalometric of the upper incisors are over angulated.

original_note:
B511 
B511 is 20 years old. I saw B511 originally when she was about 5 and the last time I saw her she was about 8 years old. By history, when B511 was 5 years old, her family was in Saudi Arabia. She was on a wall that was about 7 feet tall and she fell off of it and hit her jaw sustaining a right subcondylar fracture. I saw probably some time after that as she likely was not having any real significant symptoms and the malpositioned condyle had already solidified. While she was in orthodontics and for a time afterwards, she would have an occasional flare-up, but nothing real significant or constant. Dr. XXXX performed orthodontics on B511 5 years ago for 2 years and he practices in Houston. She had four bicuspids extracted for orthodontics. For the past 2 years, B511's pain problems associated with her jaws have increased.

At this time, she complains of headaches that occur on the right side almost daily that occur at a level of 8 in the frontal and temporal areas predominantly. She rates her right-sided TMJ pain at 8, average daily facial pain that occurs only on the right side at 7, jaw function at 0, diet at 7, and disability at 4. She gets right-sided earaches frequently. She has right-sided tinnitus and gets frequent vertigo. She has no other joints that bother her. She is allergic to Ceclor. She is not aware of clenching or bruxism.

Primary concerns B511 has at this time include the following:
Right-sided headaches. Right-sided TMJ pain. Difficulties eating and chewing. She cannot wear any hair type products that puts pressure in and around her right ear area as it creates significant pain problems. Facial asymmetry.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B511 has fairly good facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face, but she has asymmetry in the lower third face. Upper lip length is about 18 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship appears to be about 3 mm. The maxillary midline is fairly close to being on the facial midline. The mandibular dental midline is about almost 2 mm off to the right side and the chin is almost 5 mm off to the right side In profile view, she has some AP maxillary deficiency and a little bit of AP mandibular deficiency. AP maxillary deficiency appears to be probably about 4 mm. The chin may be retruded by 6 to 8 mm. Chin neckline appears a little bit shortened, and she does have a slight head postured forward neck position. Intraorally, she is missing the lower first bicuspids. She has a 3 x 3 retainer. She has adequate attached gingiva in the lower anterior arch.. In the upper arch, she is missing the first bicuspids. She has a slight Class II end-on cuspid relationship on the right side by about 2 to 3 mm, but on the left side she is fairly close to being Class I. She has an anterior deep bite of about 2 mm. There is a transverse cant in the maxillary occlusion with the right side being about 1.5 mm higher than the left side. The right mandibular cuspid may be about 2 mm posterior to the left cuspid. Chin is probably about 3 mm to the right of mandibular dental midline. By aligning her mandibular dental midline, her chin does still remain off towards the right side. To palpation, B511 has some very high moderate pain over the right masseter and moderate pain over the right temporalis and moderate tenderness over the right TMJ, right styloid area, and right posterior neck. Joints seem to actually function relatively smoothly. On opening, she has a maximum of 50 mm of incisal opening, but about 34 mm without significant pain. Excursion movement to the right is 8 mm, to the left 7 mm. Oropharyngeal tissues looks healthy and normal. Intranasally, the septum may be deviated just a little off to the right side. It appears she has some moderately decreased airway on the right side, but the left side looks open at least in the anterior aspect of the nose.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars and all four first bicuspids. Sinuses appear relatively clear. The left condyle looks normal. The right condyle shows evidence of a previous fracture with the height of the functioning condyle at the top of the neck area with the complete condyle itself missing. The ramus on the right side appears short in vertical dimension. The vertical height of the mandible on the right side in the body area is also slightly decreased compared to the left side. Waters view shows that the bony septum is reasonably straight. Turbinates appear moderate in size. There does appear to be a passable airway. Sinuses look clear. Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle with fairly good morphology. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Joint space looks adequate. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is extremely short in vertical height. Articular eminence is quite shallow. The condyle is actually functioning far anterior on the articular eminence and essentially out of the fossa. On opening, there is fairly good translation of both joints. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has some mild AP maxillary and mandibular deficiency. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 6.5 mm at the base of the tongue and maybe 7 mm at the soft palate level. Incisors appear to be in reasonable angulation, although both maxilla and mandible appear AP retruded.

Basic diagnoses would be as follows:
Right TMJ subcondylar fracture.
Right TMJ abnormal morphology secondary to previous condylar fracture with bony osteophytes that extend beyond the articular disc. AP maxillary hypoplasia. Right maxillary vertical hypoplasia. AP mandibular hypoplasia.
Loss of vertical height of the right side of the ramus secondary to previous subcondylar fracture. Class I cuspid relationship on the left side, Class II end-on cuspid relationship on the right side. Transverse cant in the occlusal plane with the right side being 2 mm shorter vertically than the left side.
Maxillary midline on the facial midline, but mandibular dental midline shifted 2 mm to the right and the chin is shifted 5 to 6 mm to the right. Right TMJ pain. Right-sided headaches.
Closing premature contact on the right molars.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Align and level mandibular arch. Surgery.
Right TMJ arthroplasty, articular disc repositioning and debridement of joint to allow the condyle to be positioned centrically in the fossa.
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible about 5 mm and level it transversely.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla and level it transversely.
Anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to shift the chin approximately 4 mm to the left of the facial midline.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

It appears, however, there may be discal tissue present. There appears to be decreased lateral joint space. There is a little deviation in the shape of the fossa as well as a little dimpling upwards at the mid fossa area.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. Articular eminence has moderate inclination. Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is very dysmorphic. There is some sclerosis on the head of the condyle and there is a V notch in the midportion of the condyle. IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ articular disc anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint, but with very early reduction. Left condyle with a normal architecture, but an anteriorly positioned disc at the lateral aspect of the joint but with early reduction. original_note:
B_001 B_001 is 26 years old and referred by Dr. XXX. B_001 had no problems or symptoms prior to an MVA that occurred 4 months ago. She was riding in a bus that got hit by an 18-wheeler from behind and slammed her into the side of the bus on her left side and she hit the whole left side of her face and left side of her body. She rates her headaches at a level of 6 in the frontal, temporal and posterior head area and has particular problems with pain behind her eyes. She rates her TMJ pain at 6, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 5, diet at 3, disability at 2. She gets frequent left-sided earaches, frequent tinnitus, moderate to frequent vertigo, and she has hearing loss when she gets the tinnitus. Other joints that bother her include her left hip, her knees, back (3 herniated disks) and neck. She had none of these problems prior to her accident. She also has some neurological factors affecting her legs and arms. She is aware of severe clenching and bruxing at nighttime and also during the day. She did not have this prior to her injury. The only medication she takes is Tylenol at times. She has essentially had no specific treatment to date.

B_001 has good facial symmetry and balance. She has relatively normal upper lip length of about 21 mm and upper tooth lip relationship of 2 mm. She has good balance in her profile. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has some crowding in the lower anterior arch and she has adequate attached gingiva. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the third molars. She does have an impacted mandibular left third molar. She has a broken down mandibular first molar with a broken tooth and restoration. Oropharyngeal tissues look relatively normal except the tonsils are of moderate size. She has basically a Class I occlusion. She has 1 mm anterior over bite relationship. Nasal structures look relatively normal. She apparently occasionally snores and has some moderate daytime tiredness, but is not aware of having overt sleep apnea. She is aware of breathing through her mouth at nighttime. To palpation, she has moderate to high moderate pain throughout the head and neck area. The worse pain to palpation is in the left TMJ. The maximum incisal opening is 49 mm and opening without pain 30 mm. The excursion movement to the right is 5 mm and to the left 6 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of all teeth. The mandibular left third molar is in distal angulation and impacted.
Coronal view shows that she has an enlarged mandibular left turbinate. She has a little sinusitis with some increased thickness of the synovial lining in the floor of the nose.

In the axial view, she has some increased thickening of the sinus membrane along the posterior and lateral aspect of the sinus. The left turbinate appears significantly enlarged compared to the right side.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is posteriorly positioned in the fossa, but there is a good anterosuperior and anterior joint space.
Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is posteriorly positioned in the fossa, but there is a good anterosuperior and anterior joint space.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 or 3 mm. There appears to be adequate joint space, although slightly increased on the medial side.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width. The top of the condyle is more flattened as is the fossa.
Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a skeletal and occlusal Class I relationship. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 9 mm at the soft palate level and about 7 to 8 mm at the base of the tongue.

B_001 does state that her speech is affected sometimes by the muscle spasms that she develops. When she is talking to the parents of her school kids, her jaw sometimes will pull off to the side. She sometimes slurs her words because of the muscle dysfunction that she currently has.

Basic diagnoses for B_001 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular discs anteriorly displaced with early reduction.
Mandibular hyperplasia. TMJ pain.
Headaches. Myofascial pain.
Impacted mandibular left third molar and malaligned maxillary third molars and mandibular right third molar.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1.	Medications: Klonopin 1 mg tablet, dispensing 30 tablets, 1 tablet q.h.s., refills x2.
2.	Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor. b.	Bilateral mandibular ramus sagittal split osteotomies. c.	Application of maxillary and mandibular arch bars. d.	Removal of third molars x4.

original_note:
B056
B056 is referred by XXXX. B056 is 60 years old. Her problems began about nine years ago at the age of 53. Her dentist told her that she needed some spacing closed or she would have difficulties in the future. This started a major downhill slide leaving B056 severely compromised. She went from having a relatively normal occlusion to where she has just some retained roots of the maxillary first and second molars bilaterally with two remaining implants in the upper jaw and missing mandibular left central incisor and left first molar. All four third molars are absent. At one point, there were ten implants placed in the upper jaw and eight of them have now been removed with only two remaining. B056 has very methodically outlined her treatment to date.

B056 rates her headaches at about a level of 8 in the frontal and temporal area bilaterally. She rates her TMJ pain at 8, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 8, diet at 5, disability at 9. She gets earaches on the left side occasionally, but has continuous tinnitus. She gets occasional vertigo and has hearing loss in the left ear. She has left leg stress fractures and also this involves the left side of her foot. She has right shoulder problems as well as hip problems. She has chronic left side fatigue. She is aware of clenching her teeth during the day, but not aware as to whether she does it at night.

To palpation, she has high moderate pain over the TMJs and moderate pain over the masseters, posterior neck, and mild discomfort over the shoulders. On opening she has a click on both sides with the right side being somewhat softer than the left side. On the left side, the opening click is at about 20 mm and a closing click at 15 mm. On the right side, the opening click is probably a little bit earlier at 15 with a closing click at about 10. She takes the following medications:

ASA 81 mg q.d.
Multiple vitamin supplements.
He diagnoses list would include the following:
Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc dislocations.
Absence of all maxillary teeth except for the first and second molars bilaterally.
Missing mandibular left central incisor and left first molar.
Lingual inclination of lower incisors.
Maxillary alveolar ridge atrophy.
Two osteointegrated implants in the maxilla with questionable stability.
TMJ pain.
Headaches.
Myofascial pain.
Clenching.

I had Dr. XXXX come and evaluate B056 with me, and her treatment plan at this point in time would be as follows:
Treatment of clenching with Klonopin 1-mg tablets 1 tablet q.h.s. Consultation with Dr. XXXX.
Orthodontics on the lower arch to align and level the lower arch, opening up space for the missing left central incisor as well as space around the deformed left cuspid. This will tip the lower incisors forward into a better position over basal bone. Surgery Stage 1: Bone grafting to maxilla including sinus lift procedures as well as augmenting anteriorly and vertically on the alveolar ridge. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
Osteointegrated dental implant placement to include four or more implants. The current maxillary implants will likely require removal.
Surgery Stage 2: Placement of interosseus implants. Restorative dentistry to reconstruct the arches.

B056 MRI AGE: 60/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears a little arthritic. Disc appears to be medially displaced. The condyle appears to have good mediolateral width. Joint space looks fairly good throughout however. Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. The disc appears to be anteriorly and laterally displaced.
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has flattening on the posterior head. The disc appears to be in reasonably good position. At the most lateral aspect of the joint, the disc may be anteriorly displaced. On opening, there appears to be good translation of the condyle and the disc bilaterally.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some flattening on the posterior head. It appears that the disc is in position, but it does appear a little bit degenerated. There appears to be a little bit of grayish kind tissue surrounding the disc.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular discs in reasonably good position, although the left one may be anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint and the right one may be laterally displaced.

original_note:
B400 
B400 is 34 years old. B400 has had some previous surgery including right knee arthroscopy 20 years ago. She had bilateral TMJ surgery 9 years ago and had sinus surgery 8 years ago. She had a laparoscopy 8 years ago and a hysterectomy 7 years ago. The surgeries were done on both jaw joints 9 years ago. Apparently there was a bone spur on the right side that was removed and then the discs were repositioned. Dr.   did the initial surgery.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS
Ultram.
Lexapro 20 mg.
Estratest q.d.
Fioricet p.r.n.
She has had a reaction to penicillin, Ancef (anaphylactic shock), codeine and hydrocodone where she has a rash and vomiting.

B400 states that her temporomandibular joint problems began as young as 5 to 6 years of age when her jaw would pop of unknown etiology. Before the temporomandibular joint surgery she did have orthodontics and splint therapy that was to no avail. 9 years ago she had the bilateral temporomandibular joint articular disc repositioned and she apparently had a bone spur removed from the right temporomandibular joint. She did not really experience any improvement in her symptoms following the surgery. She has had the following treatments in reference to the temporomandibular joints besides the surgery:
Orthodontics x3.
Splint therapy x6.
Maxillary front teeth capped to help improve her occlusion.
Equilibration.
Physical therapy.

She gets earaches and vertigo sometimes and she gets decreased hearing in the right ear but no problems with tinnitus. Other joints that bother include a right shoulder, right wrist, right hand, right fingers and right hip. She is very aware of clenching and bruxing at night and also she does it at times during the day. She gets some daily headaches about a level of 4 being worse on the right temporal sides compared to the left temporal side. These headaches can escalate to a level of 7 to 8 and actually initiate nausea and vomiting. The headaches are daily and frequently she will wake up with them but the other days she will develop them later on. She rates her average temporomandibular joint pain at 4, average daily pain at 6, jaw function and diet at 7, disability at 5.

PRIMARY CONCERNS
Temporomandibular joint pain.
Headaches. Muscle pain to the jaw areas.
Pain underneath the lower jaw.
Difficulties eating and chewing.  

Speech affected.
Snoring. Daytime tiredness.
Chronic clenching and bruxing.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, middle and upper third face appear to have fairly good symmetry. In the lower third face, the angle of the mandible and body of the mandible on the right side appears to be probably about 4 to 5 mm lower than the left side. Right angle is a little more prominent than the left angle transversely. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper-tooth-to lip relationship is about 2.5 mm. Maxillary midline is fairly close to being on the facial midline. Actually the maxillary midline is 1 mm off to the left. Mandibular dental midline is about 2.5 mm off to the left and chin is about 6 mm off to the left. In profile view, she has fairly good projection of the upper lip with no more than 1 to 2 mm of AP deficiency. The chin is probably 10 to 12 mm AP deficient. Chin-neckline is extremely short and chin-neck angle is not well defined. Intraorally, she has had lower first bicuspids removed. Some mild crowding in the lower anterior arch. Minimally adequately attached gingiva around the lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch she is missing first bicuspids. A little bit of crowding of upper anterior teeth. Little bit of a division II occlusion relationship. She has just a slight Class II about 1 to 2 mm at the most. She has about a mm vertical overbite. Intraorally, the oropharyngeal tissues look healthy. The uvula is a little bit elongated but the soft palpate and the faucial pillars appear relatively normal. B400 has a transverse cant in the occlusal plane in the upper arch with the right cuspid being 3 mm lower than the left. In the lower arch, the left side is probably just 2 mm higher than the right. Intranasally, turbinates are very mildly enlarged but not too significant. There appears to be adequate airway. The mucosal looks reasonably healthy. The septum appears relatively straight. To palpation, she has moderate discomfort over the temporomandibular joints, styloid areas and milder tenderness over the temporalis masseters, SCMs and posterior neck. Maximal incisal opening is 27 mm and about 20 mm without significant discomfort. Excursive movement is about 2 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all 4 third molars and all 4 first bicuspids. Sinuses look relatively clear. Condyles look short in vertical height and appear arthritic.

Waters view shows that the sinuses appear clear. The bony septum appears straight. Turbinates appear moderately enlarged.
Left temporomandibular joint tomograms show some significant arthritis in the condyles and some sclerosis. There appears to be significantly decreased joint space between the condyle and fossa. Articular eminence is relatively shallow. Decreased superior and anterosuperior joint space.

 
Right temporomandibular joint tomogram shows a condyle that has developed some arthritic changes. Articular eminence is deeper on this side. Joint space looks a little bit better balanced at least in one of the cuts. In another it appears that the joint spaces are more diminished. There is a pseudocyst in the back of the head of the condyle. Condylar head and neck on the right side is a little bit longer than on the left side. On opening, there is restricted translation in both joints.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she is AP deficient in both the maxilla and mandible. Occlusal plane is elevated. There is a discrepancy in the inferior border of the mandible at the angle with the right side being about 6 to 7 mm higher than the left side. Oropharyngeal airway is decreased with only about 3 to 4 mm at the most and about 4 mm at the base of the tongue.

OTHER SYSTEMS
B400 has problems with her right shoulder, right hand, right wrist, right fingers and right hip. She got frequent urinary tract infections from about the age of 4 to 10 that occurred on a frequency of about 1 time per month. Her periods were irregular and she had excessive pain prior to her hysterectomy 7 years ago. She has not had any miscarriages or fertility problems. She does have 2 children ages 12 and 10. The hysterectomy was required because of the endometriosis. She also had history of ovarian cyst. She has had pink eye a few times in the past and she has had a few bouts of conjunctivitis. She gets burning, itching and dryness of her eyes but does not wear contacts. She has allergies related to sinus problems. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day and has done this for 16 years. She gets earaches, occasional vertigo and gets occasional infection in the ear and has lots of hearing in the right ear. She gets bronchitis about 3 times a year and this has occurred for about the last 9 years. She had pneumonia once when she was 8 years old. No gastrointestinal problems reported and she is not aware of any exposure to chlamydia. She does have fatigue problems. She was around birds from about the age of 15 to 17 when the brother had 2 doves and also had about 5 to 8 pigeons. She has had cats all of her life and currently has 3. Some of those ate birds, rodents and other stuff. She has had a dog since about the age of 13 and the dog catches squirrels and rabbits. She has been exposed to horses and cows in the past. She is not aware of having any implants in her body.

BASIC DIAGNOSES
Severe bilateral temporomandibular joint reactive arthritis.
Maxillary AP hypoplasia and transverse asymmetry.
Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia. Mandibular AP hypoplasia.
Class II end-on occlusion. Decreased oropharyngeal airway of about 3 to 4 mm (normal 11 mm.)
Temporomandibular joint pain.
Headaches.
Myofascial pain.
Earaches and occasional ear infection on the right side.
Nocturnal daytime clenching and bruxism.
 

Significant limitation of jaw movement.
Masticatory dysfunction.
RECOMMENDED TREATMENT
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level mandibular arch.
CT scan (TMJ Concepts protocol) of the TMJs and jaws. Surgery.
Bilateral temporomandibular joint reconstruction and mandibular advancement using TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses.
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla slightly and down graft it posteriorly. Bilateral coronoidectomy.
Bilateral fat grafts to the TMJs (harvest from the abdomen.)
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B400  MRI Evaluation 
Age: 34, F
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation: 
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that is quite deformed. There is a lot of artifact around the joint probably related to previous surgeries in the area. There are osteophytic extensions from the condyle with an obvious one medial and then one going superior to the lateral extent of the remaining condyle. On one view it looks like there may have been a condylar fracture with the remaining condylar head medial to the condylar neck.

Right TMJ lateral view shows that whatever is left at the condylar head is masked to be cause of interferences probably related to previous surgery. The neck of the condyle appears to be laterally positioned towards the lateral extent of the fossa. I do not evaluate any functional interrelationship between the fossa and condyle.

Left TMJ sagittal view, shows a condyle that is better seen in this view. It is quite arthritic with degenerative changes and osteophytic formation. There is bone development in the joint and extending in a posterior direction off of the articular eminence. There appears to be a lot of fibrosis in the joint. There appears to be less bone-on-bone contact. There is a lot of interference indicative of previous surgeries. There may be some inflammation around the joint. It is difficult to tell if there is any translation because of the significant interference in the joint.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows some imaging of the condyle. There are significant degenerative changes in this joint. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There may be some discal tissue in place on the left side in one view but there is a tremendous amount of interference particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint. There may be some inflammation in the bilaminar tissues. On opening, there is some mild translation. There appears to be a fluid at the posterior head of the condyle. There may be some discal tissue within the joint space but it appears to be fairly degenerated. Towards the medial aspect of the joint, it appears that there is almost bone-on-bone contact.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ severe arthritis with no identifiable disc and severe interference seen in the area of previous surgery.
Right TMJ severe osteoarthritic changes with evidence of some discal tissue but highly degenerative and evidence of previous surgery.

original_note:
B360 
B360 is 64 years old and referred by Dr. _.
Patient History
B360 has had a previous appendectomy, hysterectomy, and hemorrhoid surgery. She also at the age of 10 or 11 had polio. She also has fibromyalgia and migraine headaches. She also has degenerative arthritis. She has degenerative disc disease in the lower back. She has had previous problems with anemia. She has thyroid problems, and she has low thyroid hormone.

She has had adverse reactions to PENICILLIN AND SULFA AS WELL AS #5 YELLOW DYE.
Other joints that bother her include her neck, lower back, occasionally her shoulders, her wrists, her knuckles are enlarging in her hands, her hips, knees, feet, and toes. Sometimes her feet will draw up. She has earaches, tinnitus, occasional vertigo, and hearing loss particularly on the left side. She has had hearing loss since a long time ago with unknown etiology. She has a history of clenching and bruxing nocturnally. B360 gets headaches in the frontal, temporal, and posterior head area at about a level of 8 on the left side and probably a level of 7 on the right side. Her TMJ pain on an average day is about 5 but can escalate easily to 9. Her pain on an average day is about a level of 7. She rates her jaw function at 7, diet at 9, and disability at 8.

Current Medications
Fiorinal #3 with codeine
Diazepam 2 mg. Sometimes she has to take 5 mg
Ultram 50 mg
Lortab 7.5 mg taken at night to help her sleep
Armour Thyroid
Paxil
Glucosamine/chondroitin Imitrex
Amitriptyline 25 mg q.h.s.

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B360 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 1 mm. Maxillary dental midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline is shifted just about 1 mm to the right. Chin is pretty much on the facial midline.

In profile view, she has fairly good facial balance. Some AP deficiency in the chin area, but otherwise structures appear to be in reasonable balance.

Intraorally, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has crowns on the second bicuspids through the second molars. Has adequate attached gingiva. Some mild crowding, lower anterior arch.

In the upper arch, she is missing the right second and third molar. She has crowns on the remaining three upper molars. She has basically a Class I cuspid-molar relationship and about 1-mm overbite relationship.

To palpation, she has some moderate discomfort over the temporalis muscles, TMJs, left shoulder, and high moderate tenderness over the right SCM and right posterior neck. Her pain does cycle from side to side, and at times it will be worse on one side, and then it will be less on that side and be more intense on the other side.

On opening, she has significant crepitation in both joints, but it is audible in the left TMJ. Maximal incisal opening is 35 mm, but she only opened about 10 mm without having significant discomfort. Excursive movements to the right are about 8 mm and to the left 7 mm.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex reveals the sinuses appear clear. Right turbinate appears a little bit enlarged, and the left one is fairly small. Missing all four third molars and the maxillary right second molar as well as mandibular left first molar replaced by a bridge. Apparently B360 did have an upper partial to replace the missing maxillary right second molar, but she left it out for a while, and then it did not fit. She has root canals on the maxillary right cuspid, second bicuspid, and first molar.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears small in size and appears it has lost vertical dimension. There is decreased superior and posterior joint space. Some anterior beaking is present. Condyle appears narrow anteroposteriorly.

Left TMJ tomograms show severe arthritis in the left condyle with loss of condylar substance. Condyle is very narrow anteroposteriorly. Severely decreased posterior joint space. Some beaking of the condylar head. Degenerative changes within the condylar head. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

In open views, it shows that there is restricted translation bilaterally; however, clinically she seems to have good translation, although there appears to be decreased joint space between the condyles and the articular eminences. Both articular eminences just have moderate inclination to them.

Waters view shows that the sinuses are all clear. Left maxillary sinus is larger than the right maxillary sinus. Nasal airway looks good. Turbinates appear moderate in size.

Cephalometrically, she appears to have a high occlusal plane angle and some retrusion of the maxilla and mandible. She has significantly decreased oropharyngeal airway of only about 2 mm at the soft palate level and at the base of the tongue about 5 mm.

Oropharynx appears clear; however, the posterior faucial pillars appear to attach into the posterior pharyngeal wall area, and the distance from the soft palate to posterior pharyngeal wall is extremely short. Uvula actually is relatively normal in size.
Patient Concerns

Headaches TMJ pain
Neck pain, shoulder pain, and back pain
Cervical problems
Difficulty eating and chewing
Eating frequently generates headaches Talking causes pain and headaches Sleep disorder
Severe snoring
Apneic episodes when sleeping
Daytime somnolence
She is aware of the fact that she sometimes wakes up at night unable to breathe.

Basic Diagnoses
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis and severe degeneration of the articular discs with perforations
Mandibular hypoplasia
Slight AP maxillary hypoplasia
Posterior vertical maxillary hypoplasia
Class I occlusion
Severely decreased oropharyngeal airway of 2 mm (normal is 11 mm)
High occlusal plane angulation
Missing mandibular left first molar (replaced by a pontic) and maxillary right second molar as well as all four third molars
Earaches
Tinnitus
Hearing loss
TMJ pain
Myofascial pain
Sleep apnea
Severe snoring
Daytime somnolence

Recommended Treatment
Presurgical orthodontics Align and level maxillary arch Align and level mandibular arch. Consider stripping lower anterior teeth to keep from flaring them any further forward and worsening the occlusal relationship

Surgery
Bilateral TMJ condylectomies, reconstruction, and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla forward in a counterclockwise direction
Bilateral coronoidectomies
Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvested from abdomen)

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B360  MRI Evaluation 
Date of Acquisition: Date of Reading:
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that appears to have undergone significant resorption. This is very narrow mediolaterally. Significantly decreased vertical joint space. Significant downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. In fact, it hooks back in toward the neck of the condyle. It covers the entire head of the condyle. This could possibly be heterotopic bone, and it could be associated with an ankylosis. On some of the view, there is virtually no joint space, particularly around the lateral wall of the joint.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that is very sclerotic as was the other side. Significant decreased joint space. The condyle is very small with evidence in both joints of significant condylar resorption. Lateral rim of the fossa curves downward around the condyle and again extends well down toward the condylar neck of the condyle. In some areas there appears to be major loss of joint space which could be indicative of ankylosis. Difficult to identify discal tissue on these views, although there are some views that it appears there may be some displaced discal tissue.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has undergone some resorption. There is flattening on the anterior head. Condyle is posteriorly positioned in the fossa. There is an increased joint space particularly toward the medial side. There is some evidence of discal tissue present, but it is severely deformed and very narrow anteroposteriorly. Articular eminence is moderately shallow.

T2 films show significantly worse arthritis being present with an osteophyte extending up from the condylar head in the mid head portion that is fairly significant.

On opening, there is very minimal translation. The condyle remains in the depth of the fossa.
Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle which is small in size. Evidence of significant resorption is present. There is an osteophyte extending off the posterior head. Condyle is posteriorly positioned in the fossa. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Posterior joint space is significantly decreased. Difficult to identify any discal tissue, but it appears that there is some over medially.

On opening, there is a little bit greater translation on this side than the opposite side but still quite constricted. Very difficult to identify distal tissue on this side.

Impression:
Left TMJ severe arthritis and articular disc dislocation with severe deformation and nonsalvagable disc
Severe right TMJ arthritis with articular disc dislocated medially and degenerated
