original_note:
B399 
B399 is 60 years old and referred by Dr.  . He smokes 1  ppd of cigarettes. B399 has high blood pressure the is treated with medications. His primary concerns are: Pain in the jaw joints.
Closed lock with inability to open mouth adequately to eat.
Snoring.
Daytime tiredness.

B399 became aware of having jaw pain 2-3 months ago when he had endodontic treatment. He feels the device used to open his mouth and suction fluids caused the problem. B399 has had no treatment for his jaw condition to date. Dr.  does not feel B399 can be treated without surgery.

B399 takes the following medications:
Lipitor 40 mg qd.
Motrin 800mg bid
Lisinopril 20mg qd
Hyzaar 100-25 qd.
B399 rates his TMJ pain at 6, average daily pain at 7, jaw function at 6, disability at 0. He gets headaches on the left side at a level of 3.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B399 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face. Upper lip length is about 23 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is probably about -1 mm. The maxillary midline is pretty close to being on the facial midline and so is the mandibular dental midline. Chin may be just off the right side probably 2 to 3 mm. In profile view, upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale by probably 3 to 4 mm. Maxilla is at least 6 mm AP deficient. Chin is probably about 10 mm AP deficient. Chin neckline is short, and chin neck angle is not well defined. He does have a head postured forward neck position. Intraorally, B399 has all of his lower teeth back through the second molars. It is possible that the second molars may be missing and the third molars may have drifted forward into the second molar position, but difficult to tell clinically. He has a lot of erosion on his lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch, he is missing first bicuspids bilaterally and has the rest of his teeth back through the third molars present. He has a Class II end-on cuspid relationship, being slightly greater perhaps on the left side as compared to the right side. He is probably about 3 mm Class II. He has an anterior deep bite of at least 4 mm. Oropharyngeal tissues look healthy and anatomically appear to be normal. Intranasally, the turbinates appear moderate in size. The septum appears reasonably straight. Luminal valves appear somewhat constricted, but he may have some nasal airway obstruction, but B399 reports that he is not aware of any difficulties breathing through his nose. To palpation, B399 has no tenderness around the head and neck area. Maximal incisal opening is 37 mm and excursion movement to the right 7 mm, to the left 10 mm. Joints function relatively smoothly. Jan's main factor is that he cannot open wide enough to eat properly and normally. The restriction he feels is on the left side.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of the maxillary first bicuspids and the mandibular second molars, but the mandibular third molars have drifted forward into the second molar position. In the upper arch, the third molars are present. The sinuses look relatively clear as best that can be seen. It is difficult to evaluate the condyles. He has a lot of crowns particularly on the maxillary incisors and on the mandibular first molars, right mandibular bicuspid and cuspid as well as the maxillary right bicuspid. Waters view shows that he does have a deviation of the bony nasal septum. Nasal airway does appear somewhat obstructed. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Tomograms are not taken since we did have an I-CAT. Basic diagnoses for B399 would be as follows:

AP maxillary hypoplasia.
AP mandibular hypoplasia. AP macrogenia. Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction. Decreased oropharyngeal airway. Sleep apnea. Class II end-on occlusion.
Missing maxillary first bicuspids and mandibular second molars with the third molars drifted forward into the second molar position, but with significant mesial inclination. Anterior deep bite of 4 to 5 mm.
Crowns on the 4 incisors as well as on some of the posterior teeth. TMJ pain. Headaches.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Open up 1 mm of space between the upper lateral incisors and cuspids bilaterally. Align and level mandibular arch. Try to level the third molars.
Sleep study. Discontinue smoking. Surgery.
Maxillary osteotomy to advance it forward approximately 6 to 8 mm. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance it forward about 8 mm. Left TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
Restorative dentistry as necessary to maximize the occlusal fit.

I did discuss with B399 about his significant smoking problem, and it would be extremely important for him to stop smoking beforehand. The smoking will significantly increase the potential risks for complications including infection and interference with the healing process. He understands and he will heed my recommendations to stop smoking several months prior to surgery. I did review all the other major factors in reference to complications and answered all the questions that he had at this time in reference to the diagnoses and recommended surgery. I strongly suggested he get a sleep study as well.

B399  I-CAT  
AGE: DOB:
Date of Acquisition: Date of Interpretation: 
I-CAT shows in the sagittal view that the mandible is postured forward perhaps secondary to splint wear. There is arthritis on the head of the condyle with some anterior beaking and some narrowing that is anteroposterior particularly in the mid-part of the condyle. Articular eminence is moderately steep. The condyle is positioned down and forward on the articular eminence. In the right side, the condyle is positioned down almost beneath the articular eminence. The condyle has a little bit better shape on the right side, although it does have a little bit of hockey stick shape to it. Articular eminence may be a little bit steeper on this side compared to the opposite side. In the axial view, both condyles are fairly broad mediolaterally.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has some sclerosis in the head of the condyle. The condyle is postured forward in the fossa so it is difficult to evaluate any joint space.

Right condyle appears to be a little flat on top, but again is postured forward so unable to evaluate the joint space.
IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ arthritis. Right TMJ mild bony changes.

B399 MRI  
AGE: DOB:
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation:  
Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have fairly good morphology. Articular disc appears to be in position. Articular eminence is relatively normal in angulation.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that towards the medial aspect is quite narrow and pointed superiorly. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting almost beneath the articular eminence. There is fluid in the anterior joint space. Disc on the left side actually appears to have fairly good morphology yet, but is definitely anteriorly displaced. There is peaking on the head of the condyle.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width. There is a little bit of a lateral osteophyte extending almost beyond the lateral rim of the fossa. There appears to be discal tissue anterior to the condyle. Left TMJ open view shows significant restriction of translation and the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. There is narrowing of the joint space at the lateral aspect of the joint with the disc slightly medially displaced. On opening, there appears to be restricted translation, but the disc is in a normal position.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced without reduction. Right TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc that maybe slightly medially displaced.

original_note:
B268 
B268 is 20 years old and is referred by Dr. __. She has had three sets of tubes in her ears and adenoids and tonsils removed. She has some sinus problems. She takes Prozac 20 mg daily and she takes birth control medication. She takes Naproxen 500 mg p.r.n. She gets earaches, tinnitus and occasional vertigo. The only other joint that really bothers her is her left shoulder. She has some clenching at nighttime and during the day. She rates her TMJ pain at 3, facial pain and headaches at 4, headaches at 4 in the temple and top of the head area.

In frontal view, B268 has good left to right facial symmetry in the middle and upper third face. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 4 mm. Maxillary midline is shifted about 1.5 mm to the left. Mandibular dental midline is shifted probably 5 mm to the left. Chin is probably about 6 mm to the left. In profile view, B268 has fairly good facial balance. She has fairly good chin projection. There may be just some slight deficiency in the maxillary projection may be 2 to 3 mm. Otherwise, she has good facial balance. Intraorally B268 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. Teeth appear to be fairly well aligned and leveled. Lower incisors are tipped lingually. She has a little bit of spacing around the right and left cuspids. In the upper arch she has all of her teeth back through the second molars present. Maxillary left cuspid is about 1 mm posterior to the right cuspid. The lower arch appears fairly symmetry. Slight cant in the occlusal plane with the right cuspid being about 1 mm lower than the left cuspid. She has a Class III end-on cuspid relationship on the right side being probably about 3 to 4 mm Class III and on the left side is a little bit closer to being a Class I. She has a crossbite on the left posterior side and anteriorly on the left side. She has 0 vertical overbite. Maximal incisal opening is 56 mm. Excursive movement to the right 9 mm, left 7 mm. There is an opening click at 15 mm with manipulation and a closing click about 15 mm all on the left side. Right side functions smoothly. Mild tenderness to palpation over the left masseter, left medial pterygoid, left styloid area and moderate discomfort over the left TMJ.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
Panorex shows the absence of the lower third molars but present impacted maxillary third molars. Sinuses look relatively clear. Turbinates appear moderate in size. Right condylar head and neck appear elongated compared to the left side.

Waters view shows the sinuses are clear. Turbinates are enlarged particularly on the right side. She does have a nasal ring in position on the right side. The mandible is deviated off towards the left side.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology with a little flattening on the posterior head. Joint space looks fairly good. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Right TMJ shows an elongated length of the condylar head and neck. Joint space appears a little bit decreased. Articular eminence is moderately shallow. On opening there is some restricted translation on both joints.

B268 
Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has some slight AP maxillary deficiency and perhaps some mandibular prognathism. There is a vertical difference in the heights of the inferior border of the mandible as well as the occlusal plane. Oral pharyngeal airway is somewhat constricted with the base of the tongue with dimension of about 5 mm, soft palate measures closer to 8 mm. Moderate high occlusal plane. A little bit elongated vertical length of the mandible. B268 has a tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm.

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
Right TMJ condylar hyperplasia versus osteochondroma. Right TMJ posterior displacement of the articular disc. Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation.
Mandibular deviated prognathism off towards the left side. AP maxillary deficiency. Anterior vertical maxillary excess. Anterior crossbite and left posterior crossbite. Class III end-on occlusion on the right side. Impacted maxillary third molar x2. TMJ pain. Headaches. Earaches and tinnitus. Hypertrophied turbinates. Partial nasal airway obstruction.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT: Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Open up 1 mm of space between each maxillary lateral incisor and cuspid. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies.
Align and level mandibular arch. Continue to monitor facial growth and development. Surgery. Right TMJ high condylectomy and articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor. Left TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchor.
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to shift the mandible back onto the facial midline. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it, move it superiorly and correct the transverse arch discrepancy. Removal of impacted maxillary third molars. Bilateral partial nasal turbinectomies.

B268 MRI EVALUATION
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3 mm. Joint space appears decreased. There appears to be discal tissue displaced medially and probably anteriorly.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears much larger in size and shape. Significantly decreased vertical joint space. The trabecular pattern appears a little bit different. It extends out to the lateral rim of the fossa. Difficult to tell where the discal tissue is.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with a little bit of flattening on the anterior head of the condyle. A little peaking of the condyle. Articular eminence has moderate inclination but somewhat elongated. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and appears to be sitting beneath the articular eminence. There appears to be some decreased superior joint space. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces. On opening, there is significantly reduced translation of the left condyle and it appears to be in a closed lock situation.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have an elongated condylar head and neck. Articular eminence is moderately inclined. The articular disc is posteriorly displaced. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space and actually at the base of the articular disc, which is posteriorly displaced. In the right joint, there is very minimal translation and the articular disc remains posteriorly displaced.

IMPRESSION: Right TMJ condylar hyperplasia with posteriorly displaced articular disc.
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced with closed lock

B268  MRI EVALUATION
It is not labeled where I can read it so we will do side one first.
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that out laterally has a little flattening on the anterior head. Articular eminence has a moderate inclination to it. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting along the posterior aspect of the articular eminence but anterior to the condyle. There may be slight decreased vertical joint space. There may be just a small osteophyte sticking off the top of the condyle. There is some fluid in superior joint space underneath the articular eminence. Open views show that there is restricted translation of the condyle. However, it appears that the articular disc does reduce.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have some arthritic changes particularly at the lateral aspect of the condyle where the top is flattened. More medial there is a little bit better shape but still some degenerative changes. Articular eminence has moderate inclination. It appears that there may be discal tissue posteriorly displaced. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space but particularly at the posterior aspect of the condylar neck near the base of the posterior band of the disc. Open views show virtually no translation of the condyle and the articular disc remains posteriorly displaced.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle to have fairly good morphology mediolaterally. There appears to be slight decreased joint space. There is some discal tissue medial. There also appears to be discal tissue anterior. There is moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa of about 3 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears fairly large. There appears to be significantly decreased joint space vertically. Moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim about 2 to 3 mm. It appears there may be discal tissue posterior to the condyle. Right condyle appears significantly larger than the left condyle.

IMPRESSION: Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly dislocated with reduction. Right TMJ enlarged condyle with articular disc posteriorly displaced.

B268 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient is about 5 days post surgery. Doing fairly well. Suctioned her nose today. Her occlusion is reasonably good. No evidence of infection or wound dehiscence. She is in fairly good spirits. Getting her diet down well. She is progressing nicely and return to see me in one day.

B268 
B268 presents for followup evaluation. The patient is doing fairly well. Occlusion is good. I suctioned her nose and she had a lot of mucus and bloody materials in her nose and sinuses. She has a sore throat and examination shows that she has a buildup of yeast intraorally. I gave her prescription for Nystatin 100,000 units/mL, dispensing 200 mL, 1 teaspoon q.i.d., rinse mouth thoroughly, hold for 5 minutes, then swallow. I answered all the questions she and her mother had today. She is progressing well except for the yeast buildup. She is to return to see me in one day.

B268 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well. Occlusion is fairly good, although not quite as well interdigitated on the left side. I took off the elastics on the right and just placed some relatively light vertical elastics on the left side and a light Class II elastic on the left side. Removed her sutures today. I suctioned her nose. Swelling is decreasing. The yeast infection is much improved, and she is feeling much better in regard to that. She is progressing nicely and to return to see me in one day.

B268 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient having some problems with nausea and constipation. She apparently threw up today on her way to the office. She popped off some more brackets. I clipped a wire removing some of the brackets on the left side, and I removed all of her elastics. Occlusion is actually reasonably good and because some of the brackets that have come lose, it may be better if we do not proceed with any elastics at this time, but wait until she gets back to the orthodontist and let him begin to finalize the occlusion. The nausea and the constipation could be related to the narcotics she is taking (hydrocodone) and the antibiotics. I told her to stop taking her antibiotics. She is to continue on with the Nystatin for one more day as her mouth appears to be clean at this time. I gave her a prescription for Ultram 50-mg tablets, dispensing 40 tablets, 1 tablet q.3 hours p.r.n. pain. Will see if this decreases her problems in both nausea and constipation. I also suggested that she try over-the-counter Dulcolax or a similar type medication to see if this would help her. She will try this. She has moderate swelling, but overall appears to be progressing satisfactory. I did suction her nose today and got a fair amount of mucus out of both sides of her nose. She is progressing satisfactorily and to return to see me in one day.

B268 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing very well. Occlusion is fairly good, but slightly open on the left side. I placed a vertical elastic on that side in the bicuspid area. I suctioned out her nose. She is progressing well and to return to see me in one day.

B268 
The patient presents for followup evaluation. The patient doing fairly well. I took off the current elastics and put a light Class II elastic on the left side. Did a note to her orthodontist. She can have her splint removed in mid-October. I drew directions on how to remove the splint. She is in good spirits. Did not need her nose suctioned today. Pain is under control. I gave her a prescription for Klonopin 1-mg tablets, dispensing 30 tablets, one tablet q.h.s., refill x5, and gave her a prescription for Ultram 50, dispensing 50 tablets, 1 tablet q.4 to 6 hours p.r.n. pain, refill x1. She is doing well and to return to see me around Thanksgiving, and she is to call me if she has any concerns or problems.

B268 
Telephone conversation with B268 . B268 has been having a little bit of sinus problems on the left side. She went to see her doctor and the doctor put her on Augmentin as an antibiotic. She says the right side has cleared and she is getting some feeling back on the right side, but the left side of her face is still pretty numb. She has had some crackling in her joints as she has moved her jaws, and I told her this was normal and actually a good thing. She otherwise is progressing well and to keep me informed of her progress.

B268 
B268 presents for followup evaluation. She is doing reasonably well. Incisal opening is about 34 mm and excursion movements were about 1 or 2 mm in each direction. She is taking the following medications:

Klonopin 1 mg q.h.s.
Ambien 5 mg q.h.s.
Birth control pills.
Prozac 40 mg q.d.
Tramadol 50 mg p.r.n. pain.
Swelling is decreased. Occlusion looks very good. No evidence of infection or wound dehiscence. Palatal splint has been removed. There is one wire yet remaining around the maxillary left and submaxillary right cuspid that were removed today. Otherwise, she appears to be progressing well. I answered all the questions she and her mother had. She does feel like she has a sinus problem, but in her nasal airway I could not see any drainage and at the oropharyngeal airway I could not see any drainage. I will get some x-rays to evaluate that. We also removed the wire from the right maxillary cuspid. She is progressing nicely and to return to see me for a 1 year follow-up.

B268 
Telephone conversation with her. She says has a little bump up in the vestibule of the upper jaw around the canine area. She felt it might be a bone plate. I told her that the bone plates are quite high, so it would be very unusual for that to happen. She states she got some brown strings out the other day so it very well could be the sutures coming out. She does not have a bad taste in her mouth and does not have any swelling, but does have a little bit of tenderness up in that area. It could be just the incision is a little bit tender for her. She is not running a temperature. She does have an appointment to see me in about a week and a half or so. Unless she develops any other significant problems, we will wait until her appointment and see her then.

B268 
B268 presents for followup evaluation. She is now about almost 11 months post surgery. Doing fairly well. She rates her TMJ pain at about a level of 2, average daily pain at 5 but this is mainly in the shoulders and in the neck area. She rates her jaw function at 2, diet at 0, disability at 0. She gets headaches about 2 days a week in the frontal and temporal areas, but feels this may be related to nocturnal clenching. Incisal opening is 45 mm and excursion movements are about 3 mm in each direction. Occlusion looks good and stable. To palpation, she had some moderate tenderness over the left masseter muscle. Joints seem to function smoothly. She currently takes birth control pills and Prozac 40 mg q.d. She gets some earaches on the left side greater than the right side, but no tinnitus but occasional vertigo, and she does have some decreased hearing. Other joints that bother her include her left shoulder, hips, and knees. She is aware of nocturnal clenching.

I suggested that she go back on Klonopin, but she does not like that medication. Therefore, we will try Flexeril first, so I gave her a prescription for Flexeril 10 mg, dispensing 30 tablets, 1 tablet q.h.s., refill x5. Otherwise, she appears to be progressing nicely. X-rays look good. She has some decreased sensation to the lower left lip and chin area, but hopefully this will continue to improve for her. She is doing well and to return to see me in 2 years.

original_note:
B225
B225 is 14-1/2 years old. She is in good health with no major medical problems.
By history, three years ago she got kicked in the jaw by a horse. She had some upper teeth fractured and laceration on her chin area that did not require any closure. She was not knocked out but apparently got kicked away from the horse. It fractured some front teeth in the upper arch. It did not seem to create any problems for her relative to eating and chewing as long as she bit on her back teeth and she obviously could not chew very well with her front teeth for awhile. She has really had no other treatment.

In frontal view, B225 has fairly good left to right facial symmetry. There may be just some slight increased fullness on the right side as compared to the left wide. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 3.5 mm. Mandibular dental midline and chin midline are pretty much on the facial midline. Maxillary dental midline maybe about 1 mm off to the left side. In profile view, she has reasonably good facial balance. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has some significant crowding in the lower anterior arch. She has adequate attached gingiva. In the upper arch she has all of her teeth back through the seconds molars. She has a reverse curve of Spee in the upper arch. Central incisors appear to be somewhat extruded. She has basically a Class I cuspid molar relationship. She has an anterior deep bite of about 3 mm. Oropharynx appears healthy and uvula, soft palate and faucial pillars are all within normal limits. Intranasally, turbinates look moderately enlarged but the transverse width of the nose is very good and it appears that she has adequate airway space. According to B225's mother, B225 does have some bruxism that occurs predominately at nighttime. She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. No other joints bother her. She takes no medications. It was about 3 years that she got kicked by a horse and it hit her in the chin but there were no significant problems with other areas since the injury. She is unaware of any soreness or pain that she may have had in the jaw joints at the time. She said she has had no treatment since that time. To palpation she has had very mild tenderness over the masseter muscles and left medial pterygoid muscle but no other pain to the head and neck area. On opening, she has a click in the left joint at 10 mm of opening and 10 mm of closing. Relative to the right joint there is an opening click of 15 and closing click of 10. Maximal incisal opening is about 28 mm. Excursive movement to the right 6 mm, left 5 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
: Panorex shows that she has impacted third molars in all 4 quadrants. Sinuses are clear. Nasal airway looks reasonably clear. Hard to evaluate the condyles on this view.

Waters view shows that she has huge frontal sinuses. The sinuses appear relatively clear. Right turbinate appears a little bit enlarged compared to the left side.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears to have anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is prominent. There appears to be decreased vertical joint space. The condyle appears somewhat arthritic. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has reasonably good morphology. There appears to be a decreased joint space. Articular eminence is mildly steep. On opening, there is some restricted translation in both joints.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a good skeletal and possible an occlusal relationship with a slightly anterior deep bite. Oropharyngeal airway is somewhat constricted with the airway margin of about 5 to 6 mm at the soft palate level and towards the base of the tongue hyoid area. There appears to be slightly anterior vertical maxillary excess. There appears to be a high occlusal plane angle.

Before moving here from Panama, B225 lived out in the country and they had a lot of chickens. B225 would play with the chickens for a good part of the day everyday until she was 7 years old and moved here. The mother remembers one episode when she was about 4 years old she developed a fever and apparently had significantly elevated white blood cells. She was told that she should go to the hospital but the mother nursed her at home and she got better. She was given some antibiotics and apparently this helped her. It is possible she could have been exposed to Chlamydia psittaci.

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
1. Bilateral TMJ reactive arthritis with medial articular disc displacements.
2. Limited incisal opening of only 28 mm.
3. Crowding of lower anterior arch.
4. Mild crowding of upper anterior arch.
5. History of extensive exposure to birds (rule out Chlamydia psittaci infections in the TMJs.)

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
1. Conference with Dr. Gladstad and MRI radiology.
2. Consider the following blood tests. a. ANA. b. C-reactive protein. c. Rheumatoid factor. d. CBC. e. Chlamydia antibody titers. f. Sedimentation rate.
3. Orthodontics. a. Align and level maxillary arch. b. Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth as necessary to correct for the tooth size discrepancy (approximately 2 to 3 mm.)
4. TMJ surgery if indicated following blood tests and further assessments.

B225 MRI Evaluation
Age: 14/F DOB:
Date of Acquisition: Dat of Interpretation:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone significant arthritic changes. There is a significant depression in the mid part of the condyle with a medial osteophytic extension. Decreased lateral joint space. It appears that there is discal tissue medially displaced sitting about the mid condylar position. There is decreased lateral joint space. Moderately downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa of probably about 4 mm. There is almost a 4 mm vertical step from the lateral aspect of the condyle down towards the medial aspect.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has similar morphology to the opposite side except the step in the medial half of the condyle is not quite as deep as on the left side. Decreased lateral joint space. It appears that the disc is medially displaced and sitting into the depression in the condyle. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably 3 mm. There may be some discal tissue anteriorly positioned. The condyle lights up significant to a much greater extent as compared to the left condyle which also lights up excessively.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows out laterally there appears to be decreased joint space. As the mid part of the condyle is approached, the anterior band of the articular disc can be seen. As we get further into the joint space, the posterior band can be seen sitting a little bit forward on the condyle. At the step area, there is a significant arthritic appearance with some superior peaking of the condyle and very large appearing erosion on the anterior aspect of the condyle. More medially, there appears to be a thickened, somewhat deformed disc that may be in position. No particular inflammatory process seen but the condyle certainly has major arthritic changes associated with. Articular eminence is moderately steep. In the open views, the cuts appear to be done more on the medial side of the mandible and on the lateral aspect it is excluded. On opening, there is fair translation of the condyle and the articular disc appears to be in a reduced position.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows out laterally the condyle actually looks fairly reasonable in shape. There is some discal tissue towards the lateral aspect of the joint but not all the way out to the lateral aspect. Articular eminence is moderately steep. As the medial aspect of the joint is approached there is an erosion in the condylar head and the disc appears to be in a little bit better position towards the medial aspect of the joint. There is a hot spot in the head of the condyle actually through most of the condyle probably compatible with cystic formation within the condyle. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space but not too much. In T2 films, the head of the condyle really lights up in some areas. At least at the levels of the cut the disc appears to be in position.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ loss of medial condylar bone with medial displacement of the articular discs that could be anterior bony cysts in the right condyle.

original_note:
B431
B431 is 29 years old. Referred by Dr XXXX. B431's TMJ problems she believes she began when she was about 13 years of age of unknown etiology. She had orthodontics from about the age of 12 through 15. She gets headaches about once every 2 weeks at about a level of 3 that are predominantly on the right side in the temporal area and up towards the top of the head. She is not aware of any TMJ pain and her average pain around the head and neck area is about a 1. She rates her jaw function at 2, diet at 1, disability at 1. She takes no medications. She has no earaches, occasional tinnitus, frequently vertigo, but no hearing loss. The left knee bothers her. She is allergic to cats and bee stings and has no known allergy to jewelry. She clenches and grinds her teeth at night and also during the day. She is predominantly a mouth breather particularly at night but is unaware of snoring, although she does have some mild daytime somnolence. She is not aware of any sleep apnea problem.

In frontal view, B431 has fairly good symmetry in the middle and upper third place, but has asymmetry in the lower third face. The upper length is about 18 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 0. The maxillary dental midline is slightly to the left about 1 mm. The mandibular dental midline is also a little bit off to the left probably about 1 mm. Chin is shifted probably about 5 or 6 mm off towards the right side. The left side of the face is probably about 8 to 10 mm lower than the right side. In profile, she has about 2 to 3 mm of AP maxillary deficiency. In the mandible, the chin appears to have reasonably good projection, but she does have a prominent labial mental fold. The chin does appear a little bit strong compared to the lower lip by maybe 2 to 3 mm. B431 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars in both the upper and lower jaw. She is basically a Class I cuspid molar relationship. She has a significant transverse cant in the occlusal plane. The right cuspids are at least 4 mm higher on the right side than the left side. The lower right cuspid is about 1 to 2 mm posterior to the left cuspid in both upper and lower arches. She has slight increased fullness in the left mandibular angle area on the left side compared to the right side. There appears to be a little bit of a posterior yaw in both the maxillary and mandibular arches being shifted towards the left side about 2 mm. Oropharyngeal tissues look normal and healthy. Intranasally, at least anteriorly the turbinates appear relatively normal and septum appears reasonably straight. She does have about a 3 mm anterior over bite relationship. To palpation, she has some very mild tenderness over the TMJ areas. The incisal opening is 68 mm and opening without discomfort 50 mm. The excursion movements are 13 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. She has a root canal on the maxillary left first molar. Sinuses look relatively clear.

Coronal view shows that the septum does deviate a little bit off towards the right side in the bony area. The turbinates appear enlarged on the left side. The right-sided turbinates are more normal in size.

Axial view shows that the sinuses are clear. The left turbinate is hyperplastic and the right one appears relatively normal in size. The septum appears reasonably straight in this view.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has a relatively normal mediolateral width. Vertical height is not too abnormal. The joint space looks reasonably good, although it is decreased at the lateral aspect.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly reasonably morphology. The joint space looks reasonably good.
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have a little sclerosis on the top of it. The joint space looks fairly good. The articular eminence is moderately steep. Condylar head may be somewhat longer than the opposite site.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle with fairly good morphology. There is good joint space surrounding it. The articular eminence is slightly more shallow than the right side.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B431 has a low mandibular occlusal plane facial morphology. The left side of the mandible is lower than the right side by probably 5 to 6 mm. There is a vertical difference at the occlusal plane level as well. The maxilla and mandible appear to be AP deficient, although the chin is relatively prominent. Oropharyngeal airway looks fairly good. The turbinates extend posterior to the hard palate. She has a low occlusal plane angle, but basically a Class I skeletal and occlusal relationship.

Basic diagnoses would be as follows:
Left mandibular condylar osteochondroma. Rule out articular disc dislocations.
Maxillary AP and right-sided vertical hypoplasia. Mandibular asymmetry being longer on the left side and shorter on the right side. Transverse cant in the occlusal plane with the right side being shorter than the left side.
Class I occlusion.
Left nasal turbinate hyperplasia with nasal airway obstruction. Headaches.
Nocturnal clenching and bruxism.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1.	Medications: Klonopin to see if this decreases her nocturnal clenching and relieves her of morning headaches.
2.	MRI of left and right TMJ.
3.	Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level maxillary arch. b.	Align level mandibular arch.
4.	Surgery. a.	Left mandible high condylectomy and articular disc repositioning with ligament repair. b.	Maxillary osteotomies to level it transversely, advance it, and down graft it in the front. c.	Bilateral ramus osteotomies to align on the facial midline. d.	Anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to decrease chin prominence. e.	Left nasal partial turbinectomy.
5.	Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has fairly good mediolateral width. It appears there may be some discal tissue present on the joint, but there is some discal tissue anterior to the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view show a condyle that appears larger than the opposite side. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 2 mm. There appears to be some discal tissue anterior to the condyle. There is some decreased lateral vertical joint space.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. There is a little bit of sclerosis on the head of the condyle. The disc is positioned just slightly forward in the fossa more so at the lateral extent of the joint. Medially, the disc is in a little bit better position but out laterally it is just slightly in a forward position. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology in this view. The disc is slightly anteriorly positioned particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. The condyle is somewhat posteriorly positioned in the fossa. There is a greater amount of fluid in the superior and inferior joint spaces as compared to the opposite side.

In the dynamic view, left TMJ shows a reduction and fairly good translation of the disc and condyle. The disc appears at least at this cut to be in reasonable position, although just slightly forward from the most ideal place.

Right TMJ dynamic view shows that there is an early reduction of the condyle in the right joint and fairly good translation of the disc and condyle. The disc itself does not seem to slide very much and may have an adhesion anteriorly to the articular eminence.

Right TMJ articular disc anteriorly displaced with early reduction.

original_note:
B111
B111 is 34 years 11 months and 3 weeks of age. She will be 35 next week. B111 is in good health with no major medical problems. Her TMJ problems began when she was about 14 years of age shortly after she got out of orthodontic treatment. B111 had orthodontic treatment from the age of 11 to 13. She believes her TMJ problems began when she was about 14 years old shortly after her appliances were removed. Her jaw has slowly become more retruded. She has had TMJ problems for approximately 20 years. She gets periods times now where her jaw will get stuck where she cannot open it. She has a lot of grinding in her joints and occasionally will have a significant pop. She has no real significant problems with headaches, but she has TMJ pain at a level of 5, average daily pain at 5 predominantly through the jaw muscles, and she rates her jaw function at 6, diet at 6, and disability at 5. She has no problems with earaches, gets occasional tinnitus and vertigo. Other joints that bother her include her shoulders, hips, wrists, and fingers. She is aware of clenching and bruxing at night. She takes the following medications:

Ibuprofen Zyrtec p.r.n. BCP.
Primary concerns that B111 has include the following:
TMJ pain. Muscle and jaw pain. Difficulties eating and chewing.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In the frontal view, B111 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is 5 mm. The maxillary midline is on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline and chin are probably 1 mm off to the left side. In profile view, B111 is probably about 4 mm AP deficient in the maxilla and the chin is retruded about 15 mm. Chin neckline is very short and chin neck angle is not well defined. Intraorally, B111 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has appliances on that reach all the way to the second molars. The teeth appear to be nicely aligned and leveled. She has some lack of attached gingiva around the lower anterior, particularly the left central incisor that is developing a Stillman's cleft in that area. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars present and they also appear to be nicely aligned. She has a Class I end-on cuspid relationship that is slightly worse on the left side than the right side. She is probably 3 mm Class III. She has about a 2 mm overjet. She has an anterior deep bite of about 2 mm. The transverse occlusal plane is fairly level. Oropharyngeal tissues appear normal and healthy. The nasal airway looks fine. Turbinates are mildly to moderately enlarged, but B111 puts no nasal airway obstruction. She also does not snore nor does she have daytime somnolence. She is predominantly a nasal breather at night. She may have a slightly head postured forward neck position. To palpation, B111 has some mild tenderness over the temporalis muscles, but nowhere else to palpation. On opening, she has significant crepitus in both TMJ joints with no evidence of disc reduction. Incisal opening is 50 mm and 35 mm without discomfort. Excursion movements are 10 mm in each direction. B111 finds it difficult to keep her teeth together, but also difficult to open up and hold her mouth open.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars and braces on all the rest of the teeth. The sinuses appear relatively clear. Both condyles appear arthritic. Axial view shows that the sinuses are clear, but the inferior turbinates look quite large and appear to constrict the airway. In coronal view, the turbinates likewise appear quite large, although the bony septum is fairly straight. Sinuses are clear. Left TMJ tomograms show that she has advanced arthritis and sclerosis and osteophytic formation on the head of the condyle. She has significant anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is fairly steep. Right TMJ tomogram shows also advanced arthritis with significant anterior beaking. There is decreased vertical joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Sclerosis is present on the head of the condyle. Left TMJ coronal view shows that the condyle has fairly good mediolateral width, but advanced arthritis is present. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly fairly significantly, probably 4 to 5 mm. There is significantly decreased joint space and it appears that there is bone-on-bone contact at the lateral rim of the fossa. Right TMJ coronal view also shows advanced arthritic changes and significantly decreased vertical joint space. The lateral pole of the condyle is significantly lower positioned as compared to the medial pole. There is very minimal joint space, and there is bone-on-bone contact between the condyle and the lateral rim of the fossa. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B111 has a retruded maxilla and significantly retruded mandible. She has a high occlusal plane angle. Her oropharyngeal airway is only about 3 mm at the soft palate level and 4 mm at the base of the tongue (normal dimension is 11 mm).

B111's orthodontist is Dr. XXXX.
Basic diagnoses for B111 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis. AP mandibular hypoplasia.
AP maxillary hypoplasia.
Anterior vertical maxillary hyperplasia.
High occlusal plane angle.
Class II end-on occlusion. Decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 3.5 mm (normal 11 mm).
TMJ pain. Difficulties eating and chewing. Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of approximately 1.5 to 2 mm.
Over angulation of the lower incisors.
Lack of attached gingiva in lower anterior arch with development of a Stillman's cleft around the left central incisor.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Periodontal evaluation and grafting to lower anterior arch. Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing about 2 mm of tooth structure and retract. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol). Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement in a counterclockwise direction with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it forward, move the anterior aspect superiorly, and posterior aspect inferiorly to decrease the occlusal plane level.
Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). Bilateral coronoidotomies with bone plate stabilization. Anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to augment the chin. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies.
5. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B349 is 19 years old.
Patient History
B349 is in good health.
B349 has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, gets occasional vertigo, but no hearing loss. She is aware that she does clench her teeth at night, and she usually wakes up with headaches and soreness in her jaws. She gets headaches in the frontal and temporal areas that she registers at about a level of 4. She rates her TMJ pain at 5, average daily pain at 5, jaw function at 5, diet at 6, and disability at 2.\

B349's problems may have begun as long as 8 to 9 years ago when she would wake up with headaches. However, it has only been over the past two years that she has been aware of having clicking and popping noises in her jaw joints.

Current Medications
Adderall 20 mg
Prozac 25 mg 1 time a week
Patient Concerns
Jaw joint noises
Headaches
Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B349 has good facial symmetry and balance. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 4 to 5 mm.

In profile view, she has fairly good facial balance. May be just some slight AP deficiency in the chin area of probably about 4 to 5 mm.
Intraorally, B349 has all of her teeth back through the second molars erupted in, and the right third tooth are just peeking through a little bit. In the upper arch, she has all of her upper teeth back through the second molars. She has a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. Has similar facets on the upper cuspids. Oropharynx is clear. Teeth are in good repair. Has about a 2-mm anterior overbite relationship.

To palpation, she has some mild tenderness over the masseters, TMJs, and styloid areas.
On opening, she has a click at about 30 mm of opening and reciprocal click at about 20 in the right joint. Left joint seems to function reasonably smoothly. I could not detect any particular noises in excursive movements. Maximal incisal opening is about 55 mm but only about 25 mm with reasonable comfort. Excursive movements are 9 mm in each direction.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows the presence of all four third molars with three of them being bony impacted and the right third molar being partially soft tissue impacted. Sinuses look clear. Turbinates look relatively normal in size. Condyles appear a little bit flattened anteriorly.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that has reasonably good morphology. Joint space may be a little bit decreased superiorly and posteriorly. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that is a little bit flattened anteriorly. Decreased superior and posterior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

On opening, there is good translation of both condyles with the condyles coming significantly anteriorly to the articular eminence.
Cephalometrically, B349 has basically a Class I skeletal and occlusal relationship. Bony chin might be slightly retruded. Some adenoid tissue remaining in the nasopharynx. Good oropharyngeal airway otherwise.

Basic Diagnoses
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocations with reduction
Mandibular hyperplasia
Headaches TMJ pain
Myofascial pain
History of nocturnal clenching

Recommended Treatment
Medications
Klonopin 0.5 mg, 1 tablet q.h.s. to eliminate nocturnal clenching and bruxism
Presurgical orthodontics A.	Align and level maxillary arch B.	Align and level mandibular arch

Surgery
A.	Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors
B.	Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies with bone screw stabilization

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion

original_note:
B499
B499 is referred by the TMJ Association, . B499 is 60 years old. Her problems began at the age of 53. Her dentist told her that she needed some spacing closed or she would have difficulties in the future. This started a major downhill slide leaving B499 severely compromised. She went from having a relatively normal occlusion to where she has just some retained roots of the maxillary first and second molars bilaterally with two remaining implants in the upper jaw and missing mandibular left central incisor and left first molar. All four third molars are absent. At one point, there were ten implants placed in the upper jaw and eight of them have now been removed with only two remaining. B499 has very methodically outlined her treatment to date.

B499 rates her headaches at about a level of 8 in the frontal and temporal area bilaterally. She rates her TMJ pain at 8, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 8, diet at 5, disability at 9. She gets earaches on the left side occasionally, but has continuous tinnitus. She gets occasional vertigo and has hearing loss in the left ear. She has left leg stress fractures and also this involves the left side of her foot. She has right shoulder problems as well as hip problems. She has chronic left side fatigue. She is aware of clenching her teeth during the day, but not aware as to whether she does it at night.

To palpation, she has high moderate pain over the TMJs and moderate pain over the masseters, posterior neck, and mild discomfort over the shoulders. On opening she has a click on both sides with the right side being somewhat softer than the left side. On the left side, the opening click is at about 20 mm and a closing click at 15 mm. On the right side, the opening click is probably a little bit earlier at 15 with a closing click at about 10. She takes the following medications:

ASA 81 mg q.d.
Multiple vitamin supplements.
He diagnoses list would include the following:
Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc dislocations.
Absence of all maxillary teeth except for the first and second molars bilaterally.
Missing mandibular left central incisor and left first molar.
Lingual inclination of lower incisors.
Maxillary alveolar ridge atrophy.
Two osteointegrated implants in the maxilla with questionable stability.
TMJ pain.
Headaches.
Myofascial pain.
Clenching.

I had Dr. XXXX come and evaluate B499 with me, and her treatment plan at this point in time would be as follows:
Treatment of clenching with Klonopin 1-mg tablets 1 tablet q.h.s. Consultation with Dr. XXXX.
Orthodontics on the lower arch to align and level the lower arch, opening up space for the missing left central incisor as well as space around the deformed left cuspid. This will tip the lower incisors forward into a better position over basal bone. Surgery Stage 1: Bone grafting to maxilla including sinus lift procedures as well as augmenting anteriorly and vertically on the alveolar ridge. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
Osteointegrated dental implant placement to include four or more implants. The current maxillary implants will likely require removal.
Surgery Stage 2: Placement of interosseus implants. Restorative dentistry to reconstruct the arches.

B499 MRI
AGE: 60/F
DOB:
Date of Acquisition:
Date of Interpretation:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears a little arthritic. Disc appears to be medially displaced. The condyle appears to have good mediolateral width. Joint space looks fairly good throughout however. Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. The disc appears to be anteriorly and laterally displaced.
Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has flattening on the posterior head. The disc appears to be in reasonably good position. At the most lateral aspect of the joint, the disc may be anteriorly displaced. On opening, there appears to be good translation of the condyle and the disc bilaterally.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some flattening on the posterior head. It appears that the disc is in position, but it does appear a little bit degenerated. There appears to be a little bit of grayish kind tissue surrounding the disc.

IMPRESSION: Bilateral TMJ mild arthritis and articular discs in reasonably good position, although the left one may be anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint and the right one may be laterally displaced.

original_note:
B176
B176 is 44 years old and referred by Dr. XXXX. Her dentist is Dr. XXXX. She currently takes the following medications:
Wellbutrin 300 mg XL. Yasmin.
Ambien 10 mg q.h.s.

B176 has been on the Wellbutrin for 7 years.
B176's primary concerns are as follows:
Clicking in the jaw joints. Crossbite. Headaches and TMJ pain.
B176 had orthodontics x2 from the age of 12 to 14 and then from age of 15 to 17. She had a bicuspid extracted from each quadrant. It is unknown when her TMJ problems began and the etiology is unknown. B176 gets headaches about once a week behind the right eye which would include the frontal and temporal area. She rates her TMJ pain at 3, average daily pain at 3, jaw function at 4, diet at 0, disability at 0. She gets occasional right-sided earaches, occasional right-sided tinnitus, and she does have some right-sided hearing loss. The only other joints that bother her are her ankles. She is aware of clenching and bruxism at night and also during the day. She has had previous nose, sinus, septum, and turbinate work by Dr. XXXX. B176 is not aware of snoring, but she does have moderate daytime somnolence and she is predominantly a mouth breather at night time and also during the day. She is not aware of having any sleep apnea issues.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B176 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 3.5 mm. The maxillary midline, mandibular dental midline, and chin midline are all fairly well aligned with each other. In profile view, she has some slight AP maxillary deficiency and some slight AP mandibular deficiency of probably about 4 mm. Chin neckline is a little bit short and chin neck angle is not well defined. She has a slightly head postured forward neck position. Intraorally, she is missing what appears to be probably the first bicuspids in all four quadrants. She is basically a Class I cuspid relationship with bilateral posterior crossbites. She has about a 1 mm overbite and 1 mm overjet. Oropharyngeal tissues all look normal. Intranasally, there is some mucous material that makes it difficult to evaluate, but turbinates appear relatively normal as best as I can see them in the front. The septum may be reasonably straight. She has constricture of the luminal valves. The nostrils are somewhat narrow. Holding the nostrils open with a nasal scope significantly improved her abilities to breathe through her nose. She currently has moderate nasal airway obstruction. Both maxillary and mandibular arches are quite narrow and constricted. To palpation, she has no tenderness around the head and neck area. She has a click in the left joint at about 10 mm of opening and 5 mm of closing. The right side seems to function reasonably smoothly. Incisal opening is 47 mm and excursion movements are 7 mm in each direction.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars and four first bicuspids. She has root canals on mandibular second molars bilaterally and maxillary left first and second molar and right first molar. Coronal view shows that her turbinates have essentially totally removed in the anterior and mid part of the nose, but there is still some inferior turbinate tissue posteriorly but there appears to be adequate airway. Sinuses appear clear. There is a septal perforation present. Axial view shows that the septum is reasonably straight with just a little deviation off towards the left side. There is some residual inferior turbinate bilaterally at the posterior aspect of the nose. Sinuses appear clear. Left TMJ sagittal view shows condyle that appears to have fairly good morphology with just some slight anterior beaking. Joint space appears reasonably good. Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that there is decrease superior and anterior joint space. There appears to be in one view a little erosion on the anterior head of the condyle. The joint spaces seem less on this side compared to the opposite side. Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with moderately good mediolateral width. There is decreased lateral joint space. Lateral rim of the fossa curves downward probably 4 mm. Right TMJ coronal view shows significantly decreased vertical joint space and almost bone-on-bone contact at the lateral aspect of the joint. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 3-4 mm. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows B176 has some moderate AP maxillary and mandibular deficiency. Oropharyngeal airway at the soft palate level measures about 8 mm, but at the base of the tongue there are some areas that measure about 3 mm to 6 mm.

Dental model analysis shows that there is only about 1 mm of vertical overbite relationship. There are bilateral posterior crossbites. The four bicuspids have been removed. The maxilla appears to be approximately 10-12 mm deficient transversely in the second molar area. B176 has a tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm.

Basic diagnoses for B176 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation with reduction on the left side and probably nonreducing on the right side. Maxillary significant transverse hypoplasia and to a lesser degree AP hypoplasia. Mandibular AP hypoplasia. Bilateral posterior crossbites.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway.
TMJ pain. Headaches. Bilateral collapse of the nasal luminal valves.
Nasal airway obstruction. Recommended treatment would be as follows:

MRI of left and right TMJs.
Presurgical orthodontics. Align and level maxillary arch. Tip lateral incisor roots mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level mandibular arch. Surgery. Bilateral TMJ reconstruction (method will be dependent on MRI findings).
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible forward. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla forward and significantly expand it. Reconstruct nasal luminal valves with bone grafts from posterior maxilla.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B176 MRI AGE: 44/F
Left TMJ frontal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width and good vertical height. There is decreased lateral joint space. There disc is medially displaced. There could be some anterior displacement of the articular discs.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width and vertical height. It appears that the joint space is decreased vertically, although there may be some discal tissue in pace. There appears to be some decreased lateral joint space and so the disc also may be medially displaced.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. A little bit of flattening on the anterior head. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination. The articular disc is not seen out laterally, bur more medially it appears to be in reasonably good position, although perhaps just slightly forward. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space, but not too significant. On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the disc does reduce into a good position.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows out lateral the disc is not as readily identifiable. More medially, there appears to be better imaging of the disc, although the disc appears quite thin in all the views with a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space, but not too significant. On opening, there is good translation of the condyle and the disc appears to be in a reduced position and translates well with the condyle.

IMPRESSION:
1. Left TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc medially displaced with reduction.
2. Right TMJ mild arthritis and articular disc medially displaced with reduction on opening.

original_note:
B130
B130 is 26 years old, referred by Dr. XXXX. The only previous surgery that B130 has had has been fusion of L4-L5 x3. B130 believes her jaw problems began during her teenage years of unknown etiology. She had orthodontics from about the age of 12 to 16 and this included extraction of four bicuspids including the mandibular second bicuspids, maxillary first bicuspids. B130 has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, nor hearing loss. The only other joints that bother her are her back. She has some clenching during the day.

B130 rates her headarches at a level of 8 and they occur in the frontal, temporal, and top of the head. She rates her average TMJ pain at 5, daily pain at 6, jaw function at 6, diet at 5, disability at 3.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
In frontal view, B130 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 8 mm. The maxillary, mandibular, and chin midline are all pretty much on the facial midline. The nasal tip is deviated just slightly to the right side by 1 to 2 mm. In profile view, upper lip supralabrale is probably about 3 mm posterior to subnasale. The maxilla is probably 6 to 8 mm AP deficient. The chin may be retruded about 10 mm. Chin neckline, however, looks fairly strong. The chin is strong compared to the AP position of the lower lip. Chin sticks out probably 6 mm beyond the lower lip. Intraorally, B130 is missing the lower second bicuspids. Molars are actually tipped lingually creating increased curve of Wilson. The lower anterior teeth are well aligned. She has adequate attached gingiva. In the upper arch, she has a reversed curve of Spee. She is missing upper first bicuspids. Upper incisors appear as though they are almost in lingual inclination. B130 is fairly close to a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. She has an anterior deep bite of about 6 mm. Oropharyngeal tissues look healthy and normal. Intranasally, the septum appears relatively straight. Turbinates appear enlarged and appear significantly inflamed. There may be some moderate constricture of the luminal valves. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the left TMJ, retromandibular area, left masseter, bilateral shoulders, and milder tenderness over the right TMJ and right retromandibular area. On opening, she has a click in the left joint at about 15 to 20 mm and a closing click at 10. The right side seems to function reasonably smoothly. Maximal opening is 56 mm, opening without discomfort 40 mm. Excursion movement to the right 9 mm, to the left 10 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of impacted mandibular third molars, but absence of maxillary third molars. Mandibular second bicuspids and maxillary first bicuspids are also missing. Sinuses appear reasonably clear, although there could be some polyps in the right sinus. Septum in the bony area is deviated off significantly towards the right side. The left condyle appears a little flattened anteriorly with a little peaking at the superior aspect of the condyle. Right side appears more normal. Coronal view shows that the turbinates are moderate in size. Septum is deviated significantly off towards the left side. There is a sinus polyp hanging down from the right infraorbital rim.
Axial view shows that the septum is deviated off towards the left side. Turbinates appear moderate in size. Sinuses appear relatively clear at the one cut that I have to evaluate. Right TMJ sagittal view shows condyle that has reasonably good morphology. There appears to be fairly well balanced joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle is posteriorly positioned in the fossa, particularly at the lateral aspect of the joint with increased anterior joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. There appears to be some decrease lateral joint space. Vertical joint space also appears somewhat narrow in areas. Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appear may be just slightly smaller in size than the right side. Vertical joint space may be slightly decreased. Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B130 has a retruded maxilla and mandible, but has AP macrogenia probably in part due to previous orthodontic treatment. Oropharyngeal airway is slightly constricted with an AP dimension at the soft palate level of about 8 mm and at the base of the tongue of 5 mm. She has a slight increased occlusal plane angle and an anterior deep bite. The roots are quite short on the incisors. Upper incisors are retro-inclined.

Basic diagnoses would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ articular disc dislocation with early reduction. AP maxillary hypoplasia.
Vertical maxillary hyperplasia. AP mandibular hypoplasia.
AP macrogenia. Headaches. TMJ pain. Impacted mandibular third molars x2.
Missing maxillary first bicuspids and mandibular second bicuspids.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway. Hypertrophied turbinates. Deviated nasal septum.
Nasal airway obstruction. Snoring. Resorbed roots on the maxillary incisors. Polyps, right maxillary sinus.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level the maxillary arch. Tip the lateral incisors mesially and cuspid roots distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level the mandibular arch.
Surgery. Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
Maxillary osteotomies to move the maxilla superiorly approximately 6 mm and advance it forward approximately 6 to 8 mm. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a slight clockwise direction.
Anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to reduce the prominence in the chin. Surgical removal of mandibular impacted third molars x2. Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. Nasal septoplasty.
Removal of nasal polyps from right maxillary sinus. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B130 MRI AGE: 26/F
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good morphology. Joint space appears decreased vertically. Discs appear that they may be anteromedially displaced.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has good mediolateral width. Joint space may be just slightly wider, but difficult to tell. Discs may be anteriorly displaced, but kind of difficult to tell on the coronal views.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that appears to have fairly good morphology. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, the disc reduces and there is good translation of both the condyle and the disc.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has fairly good morphology. The disc may be just slightly anteriorly displaced at the lateral aspect of the joint. The head is a little bit flattened on the anterior slope at the lateral aspect of the joint. More medially, the disc appears to be in better position. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. On opening, there is good translation and early reduction of the articular disc.

IMPRESSION:
Left TMJ articular disc dislocation with early reduction. Probable right TMJ articular disc anterior dislocation with early reduction.

original_note:
B495
B495 is 43 years old and is referred by Dr. XXXX
PRIMARY PROBLEMS:
TMJ pain.
Headaches.
Difficulties eating and chewing.
Sleep apnea problems. Ear pain.
Feeling of choking.
Difficulty swallowing. Even when drinking water she will choke.
B495 has been diagnosed with acid reflux and recently had a procedure to expand her esophagus to breakup some adhesions. This helped her swelling for a short time but her difficulties are back again.

B495 is not really sure when her jaw joint problems began. She says her lower jaw has always been somewhat retruded. However, she feels it has become much more receded in the past 5 years. She developed sleep apnea problems during the past 5 years. She was placed on a CPAP machine but she is unable to tolerate it. The CPAP machine significantly aggravates her allergies and her aspergillosis, a fungal infection of the lungs. Seven years ago, at about the age of 39, she noted the joint problems progressing. However, it was not until last August that she developed severe pain problems. She was put in physical therapy for 6 to 8 weeks and this seemed to help her muscle spasms but has not reduced her pain levels. B495 has had splint therapy for approximately 10 years. This obviously has not corrected her situation.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:
Ibuprofen 800 mg tablets. She limits herself to 1 a day because it causes GI problems. Q-Var inhaler. Albuterol.
Prednisone periodically as needed for her symptoms.
Nexium.

B495 rates her TMJ pain at a level of 9, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 5, diet at 7, disability at 6. She gets headaches predominately in the right temporal and posterior head area at a level of 7. She gets a headache at least every other day. She does find that she clenches at night and also during the day. She gets earaches worse on the left side than the right side and they are fairly continuous. She also gets tinnitus and she gets occasional vertigo. No other joints bother her. She does have a history of breast cancer that was diagnosed in the fall, 11 years a go. She had a left mastectomy and subsequently had a breast implant placed. She has done well since that treatment.

In frontal view, B495 has some transverse facial asymmetry. She has more fullness on the right side of her face than the left side. Upper lip length is about 3.5 to 4 mm. B495 states that the right side increased fullness may be due to swelling and it tends to become more prominent and less prominent but it stays more full on the right side. B495 says she used to be more symmetric than she is now. It is possible there could be some slight masseteric hyperplasia there. Maxillary and mandibular midlines are fairly well centered. She has lip incompetence of about 6 mm. In profile view, upper lip supralabrale is posterior to subnasale by probably 2 to 3 mm. She probably has a maxillary deficiency of probably 4 to 6 mm. Chin appears to be retruded by at least 15 to 18 mm. Chin-neckline and angle are well formed. Intraorally, she has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. The uvula appears normal size and shape but the soft palate appears elongated with a very narrow oropharyngeal space remaining. Faucial pillars appear normal. She had her tonsils previously removed when she was 7 years old. Transversely the occlusal plane is fairly level. She has some significant crowding in the lower anterior arch. Mandibular left lateral incisor is completely lingually blocked. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. Slight division II angulation of the incisors. She has a Class II end-on occlusion being worse on the left side as compared to the right side. She has an overjet of about 4 mm. Anterior vertical overlap of about 2 mm. Oropharyngeal area tissues look healthy. She has severe snoring. She has severe daytime somnolence and could fall asleep while driving and also at work. She has severe sleep apnea symptoms and apparently has significant occurrences of cessation of breathing at night while she is sleeping. Intranasally, the septum appears fairly straight. Turbinates appear fairly large. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the TMJs and mild tenderness over the styloid areas, but no other significant discomfort around the head and neck area. With jaw function, she feels squishy noises in her joints. On reassessment of B495 in centric relation, she is actually very significantly Class II bilaterally. In the first assessment she was postured a little bit off towards the left side. The midlines and chin are all fairly well aligned in centric relation. The overjet is actually about 5 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
Panorex shows the absence of all 4 third molars, but all the rest of the teeth are present. The sinuses appear reasonably clear. Condyles appear small in size and a little bit arthritic.

Waters view shows that the bony septum has a little bit of deviation in it. Turbinates appear moderately enlarged although there does appear that there may be airspace but all sinuses appear clear.

Right TMJ tomogram shows that there appears to be decreased joint space. Condyles appear arthritic. Very difficult to view probably due to small size of the condyles.

Right TMJ tomograms show that the condyle is likely arthritic but there appears to be an increased joint space on this side vertically and the condyle is postured slightly forward. On opening, there is moderately good translation of both condyles with perhaps a little bit more on the right side than the left side.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that both the maxilla and mandible are retruded. She has a severely decreased oropharyngeal airway of less than 2 mm at the soft palate level and at the base of the tongue is only about 2 mm (normal is 11 mm.)

BASIC DIAGNOSES:
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis with significant condylar resorption.
AP maxillary deficiency.
Anterior vertical maxillary excess.
Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency. Severe AP mandibular deficiency.
Class II end-on occlusion. Significant crowding of lower anterior arch.
Severely decreased oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 1 to 2 mm (normal dimension 11 mm.)
Severe sleep apnea (life threatening.) TMJ pain. Headaches. Ear pain and tinnitus. Tooth size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm. Hypertrophied turbinates. Partial nasal airway obstruction.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Keep lateral incisor roots tipped mesially and cuspid roots tipped distally to make room for interdental osteotomies. Align and level mandibular arch. Slenderize the lower anterior teeth removing at least 2 mm of tooth structure to correct for the tooth size discrepancy and to help keep the lower incisors from being flared too far forward.
CT scan (TMJ Concepts protocol.)
Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla, expand it and downgraft it posteriorly.
Bilateral TMJ fat grafts.
Bilateral mandibular coronoidectomies.
Bilateral partial inferior turbinectomies. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

The husband notes that he frequently observes his wife holding her breath for a minute or longer between breaths when sleeping.
B495 MRI EVALUATION

DOB:

Date of Acquisition:
Date of Interpretation:
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone severe resorption. Significant loss of condylar volume. The condyle appears narrow with medial beaking. There is increased soft tissue space. The fossa appears in some areas to have a little bit of degeneration but difficult to tell. There is moderate downward curvature at the lateral rim of the fossa of probably about 3 to 4 mm. There may be discal tissue anterior and medial.

Right TMJ shows a condyle that is also quite small in mediolateral width. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 to 3 mm. There is significantly less joint space on this side compared to the opposite side. There may be some discal tissue anterior in this joint. Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has undergone significant condylar resorption. There are osteophytes remaining on the superior head and anterior on the head of the condyle.
