There is significant fluid in the superior joint space and the soft tissues are exceptionally thick in the joint area. On opening, there is moderately good translation of the condyle but the disc remains anteriorly displaced and severely deformed. There still remains almost excessive joint space in the open view.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows significant condylar resorption and loss of volume. It appears that the cuts through the joint are done at an odd angle compared to how they are usually done. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Decreased superior joint space. Condyle appears to be posteriorly positioned. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and severely deformed and degenerated. In some areas, the articular eminence appears fairly flat with changes in the fossa with significant degenerative changes of the condyle. There is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space although not as much as the opposite side. On opening, there is moderate translation and the articular disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

IMPRESSION:
1.	Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis and severe degeneration of the articular discs.
2.	Probable candidate for total joint prostheses.

original_note:
B103
B103 is 34 years old and is a self-referral. B103 had an onset of her TMJ problems at the age of 14 probably related to AICR. She did have an accident of age of 7 on a diving board where she hit the underneath of her chin and damaged some of her primary teeth. She had orthodontics from the age of 11 to 12 and then again from the age of 14 to 15. She had her third molars removed at the age of 15. At the age of 16, she had double jaw surgery by Dr. XXXX. That same year she also had a nasal septoplasty and an external rhinoplasty. She has been in splint therapy for 14 years and estimates she has had 20 to 30 splints. Following completion of her orthodontics, her bite did open again. After the surgery, the bite opened once again. B103 rates her headaches at a level of 7 that occur in the temporal areas bilaterally. They occur at a rate of two times per day. She wakes up with the headaches and then in the afternoon around 5 o'clock the headaches begin again. She rates her TMJ pain at 8, average daily pain at 8, jaw function at 2, diet at 3, disability at 7. She gets occasional earaches, gets tinnitus about 2 times per week, but has no vertigo or known hearing loss. Other joints that bother her include her wrists and her neck. She is aware of clenching and bruxing at nighttime. She takes the following medications:

Lexapro 10 mg q.d.
Advil 1200 mg p.r.n.
In frontal view, B103 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip is 20 mm in length and upper tooth lip relationship is about 2 mm on the left and 2.5 on the right. The maxillary midline is about 1 mm off to the right side. The nasal tip is about 1 mm off to the left side. The chin is about 2 mm off to the left side. In profile, the maxilla is retruded about 4 to 5 mm and the chin is retruded about 10 to 12 mm. The chin neckline is short and chin neck angle is not defined. Intraorally, B103 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has adequate attached gingiva around the lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. She has got crowns in the maxillary left first molar and right first and second molars. She is fairly close to a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. There is some mild crowding in the lower arch. She has a 2 mm anterior deep bite. Oropharyngeal tissues look healthy and normal with the soft palate appearing maybe a little bit elongated with a deep crease dimension perhaps from the soft palate to the posterior pharyngeal wall. Intranasally, the turbinates appear relatively normal in size and the septum appears reasonably straight. There appears to be good nasal airway. To palpation, she has some moderate discomfort over the TMJs and milder tenderness over the temporalis, masseters, medial pterygoids, and SCMs. The maximal incisal opening is 47 mm but 25 mm without discomfort. Excursion movements to the right is 9 mm, to the left 8 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. There are four bone plates in each side, but each bone plate only has two screws with one screw above and one screw below the osteotomy site. There are two screws in the left ramus, but none in the right ramus but apparently these were removed. She has two screws in the chin area. She had root canals on the maxillary left second bicuspid, right cuspid, first bicuspid, and mandibular right cuspid and left first molar. She has crowns on the maxillary right first and second molars, mandibular left first and second molars, and maxillary left first molar. The condyles appear arthritic.

Coronal view shows that the septum is reasonably straight and turbinates are relatively normal in size. The sinuses appear clear.
Axial view shows that the septum has a little deviation off towards the right side. The turbinates are relatively normal in size and the sinuses appear clear.

Left TMJ sagittal tomograms show condyles that have undergone significant resorption with loss of vertical and anteroposterior volume. The articular eminence is moderately shallow. There is decreased joint space more towards the lateral aspect of the joint. There are some pseudocysts in the head of the condyle.

Right TMJ sagittal tomograms show a condyle that has undergone significant condylar resorption with loss of vertical and anteroposterior volume. There are some pseudocysts in the head of the condyle. The articular eminences are just slightly steeper on this side but are still moderately shallow. The condyle is positioned somewhat posterior in the fossa.

Left TMJ coronal view shows that there is significant loss of vertical volume and mediolateral width of the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably about 5 mm. There is decreased vertical joint space particularly towards the medial side of the joint.

Right coronal view shows a condyle that has lost significant vertical volume and mediolateral volume and may be a little bit more narrow than the opposite side. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably 5 to 6 mm extending down beyond the head of the condyle. There is somewhat decreased vertical joint space.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that she has a Class I occlusal relationship, but probably a slight Class II skeletal relationship. She has a high occlusal plane angle. Oropharyngeal airway measures 4 mm at the soft palate level and about 6 mm at the base of the tongue.

Basic diagnoses for B103 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis (AICR).
Maxillary AP and posterior vertical hypoplasia.
Mandibular AP hypoplasia. Class I occlusion.
Moderate crowding of the lower anterior arch.
Decreased oropharyngeal airway.
Sleep apnea. Bilateral TMJ pain. Headaches.
Myofascial pain.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level the maxillary arch. b.	Align and level mandibular arch.
2. CT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol).
3. Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement in a counterclockwise direction with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. b.	Multiple maxillary osteotomies to down graft the posterior aspect and advance in a counterclockwise direction. c.	Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). d.	Bilateral coronoidotomies.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B103 MRI
Left TMJ coronal view show a condyle that is very narrow in mediolateral width and has lost significant vertical volume. There is decreased vertical joint space. The lateral rim appears to curve inferiorly 5 mm.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle is very narrow mediolaterally and has lost vertical volume. The lateral rim of the fossa appears to curve inferiorly about 4 mm. There is decreased superior joint space.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is somewhat narrow anteroposteriorly. The articular eminence is moderately steep. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence. The disc is significantly deformed and degenerated. The condyle is sitting posterior and superiorly in the fossa with decreased joint spaces. The anterior joint space is increased. On opening, there is fairly good translation of the condyle, but the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction with significant deformation.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that is arthritic with some sclerosis in the ________ portion of the head of the condyle. There is some anterior beaking present. There is decreased superior joint space. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting beneath the articular eminence and appears significantly deformed and degenerated. On opening, there is fairly good translation of the condyle, but the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction with significant deformation.

IMPRESSION:
Bilateral TMJ resorptive arthritis and articular disc anteriorly displaced without reduction with severe deformation and degeneration. Discs appear non-salvageable. Patient probably a candidate for total joint prostheses.

original_note:
B356 
Date of Birth: 
The patient is a 16-year-old female referred by Dr. __.
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS: B356 states that her jaw joint problems began about 1-1/2 years ago of unknown etiology. She became aware of some clicking and popping in her joints and also started to develop headache and pain problems. She has had no previous orthodontic treatment. She has had splint therapy. She takes ibuprofen as her only medication.

PATIENT CONCERNS/PROBLEMS
Jaw and mouth pain. Headaches.
Jaws pop creating increased pain. Jaw locking.
Difficulties eating and chewing.
She has no problems with earaches, tinnitus, vertigo or hearing loss. She has no other joints that bother her. She has been diagnosed as having ADD. She is aware of clenching and bruxism at nighttime. She apparently has fairly continuous headaches and usually wakes up with headaches. She rates the headaches at a level of 8 on the left side throughout the head area and a level of 6 on the right side. She rates her TMJ pain about at level of 8 and it does get to a 10. Average daily facial pain and headaches are about an 8. She rates her jaw function at 5, diet at 5 and disability at 7. To palpation, she has moderate tenderness over the masseters and TMJs. Incisal opening is about 40 mm according to some early information provided by Dr. __. Photographs were sent. She appears to have fairly good facial symmetry in the frontal view. In profile she also appears to have good facial symmetry. In occlusal view, midlines are off by about 1/2 to 1 mm. She appears to have about a 3 mm vertical overbite relationship anteriorly. She appears to have a crossbite tendency bilaterally in the posterior aspect. She has a Class II end-on occlusion of about 3 mm in right cuspid area and probably 1 mm perhaps on the left side, although she appears to have more of a Class II molar relationship on the left side. Phone evaluation was interesting because today B356  was at her home ill because of the flu and has been throwing up. I actually talked to her through her mother and aunt whom were both at the aunt's home but then had to call B356 at her and her mother's home and we had to relay the questions through a third party.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the presence of all four third molars. Sinuses appear clears. Rami are cut off so I could not evaluate the joints. It appears that she may have an accentuated curve of occlusion in the lower arch and a reverse curve of occlusion in the upper arch.

Some right TMJ films are present and it appears the condyle may be posteriorly displaced but hard to tell. Articular eminence appears moderately steep.

Left TMJ films show a condyle that appears to have perhaps some arthritic changes but the quality of the film is not real good so it is very difficult to tell. B356 

MRI showed that she has some bilateral TMJ arthritis with some erosions and the articular disc is dislocated without reduction and significantly deformed and degenerated. The left side appears worse than the right side. However, she claims that she has clicking and popping in her joint which means that perhaps with normal function that the joints still click and pop thus reducing whereas on the MRI because of the situation the disc did not reduce.

BASIC DIAGNOSES
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocation without reduction.
Relative mandibular hyperplasia.
Severe TMJ pain.
Severe headaches.
Myofascial pain.
Masticatory dysfunction. Impacted maxillary and mandibular third molars x4.
Accentuated curve of occlusion in the lower arch and slightly reverse curve of occlusion in the upper arch. Class II end-on occlusion.
Tendency towards posterior crossbites.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Try to expand the posterior arch particularly in the bicuspid area to eliminate the tendency towards posterior crossbite. Create about 1 mm of space around each of the upper lateral incisors as it appears that there is a tooth size discrepancy.
Align and level mandibular arch. Surgery.
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors.
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to maintain Class I occlusion.
Surgical removal of impacted third molars x4.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B356  MRI Evaluation 
Date of Birth: 
Date of Acquisition: 
Date of Interpretation: 
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears to have undergone some resorptive changes. In the mid part of the condyle there is decreased superior joint space. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably about 3 to 4 mm. It could be even up to about 4 mm as we come more anteriorly. Decreased superior joint space. In one area there appears to be a little calcification or a little osteophyte towards the middle third of the condyle. It appears that there have been erosive changes at the lateral aspect of the condyle. Significantly decreased joint space at the lateral rim. Articular disc appears to be anteriorly displaced.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone even greater arthritic changes. It appears that there has been some significant erosion of the condyle at the lateral aspect and also across the medial aspect. There is some osteophytic formation extending superiorly in the mid part of the condyle. There is some lateral osteophytic development as well. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly probably about 4 to 5 mm. Decreased superior lateral joint spaces. It appears that there is disc tissue displaced anteriorly but somewhat more degenerated than the opposite side. The lateral pole of the condyle is significantly more inferiorly positioned than the medial pole.

Left TMJ sagittal shows a condyle that laterally has erosion of the condylar head and some flattening on the anterior aspect of the condylar head. More medially, the condyle appears a little bit better shaped but it appears somewhat narrow anteroposteriorly. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Articular disc is anteriorly displaced and sitting down towards the inferior aspect of the eminence. It is more anteriorly displaced along the entire aspect of the condyle. Decreased superior and posterior joint spaces. The disc is significantly deformed and narrow anteroposteriorly as well as thickened. The posterior band is quite thick and the intermediate zone is extremely narrow. On opening, there is restricted translation and the articular disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction. It is possible that this disc could be salvageable but there are significant degenerative changes preexisting.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has some significant erosions at the lateral aspect of the joint. More medially, the condyle has a little bit better morphology. There is anterior beaking more towards the medial aspect of the joint. There is decreased superior and posterior joint spacing. Articular eminence is moderately steep. There may be some erosion at the lateral aspect of the articular eminence. The disc is significantly degenerated much more so than the opposite side. The disc is more evident at the lateral aspect of the joint than at the medial aspect. However, the definition of the disc is very poor. It appears there is a little bit of fluid in the superior joint space. It is difficult to differentiate between the articular eminence and the disc at the lateral aspect of the joint. On opening, there is significant limitation of translation somewhat similar to the opposite side and the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

IMPRESSION
Bilateral TMJ advanced arthritis and articular disc dislocations without reductions and significant deformation of the disc with the left side being worse than the right side. Right disc could possibly be salvageable but left disc appears nonsalvageable.

original_note:
B185
B185 is 39 years old. He got my name off the Internet. He has had the previous surgical procedures:
Rhinoplasty.
Sliding genioplasty in approximately 14 years ago.
Four months ago, double jaw surgery to advance the maxilla and mandible.

PRIMARY CONCERNS: Sleep apnea.
B185 had orthodontics done at the age of 18 with extraction of upper and lower first bicuspids and teeth retracted. He had repeat orthodontics at about the age of 30 to close up some residual space but this moves his teeth back even further. The double jaw surgery in 4 months ago was to correct his sleep apnea problems but B185 does not notice much difference or improvement. He still needs about 10 to 12 hours of sleep at night to even be able to function the next day and sometimes still his mind is foggy. He is getting very poor quality REM sleep.

The only medication that B185 takes is Clonazepam 0.5 mg tablets 1 to 2 tablets at bedtime.
B185 has no problems with headaches, TMJ pain or myofacial pain. No trouble with earaches or vertigo but does have bilateral tinnitus. He has significant hearing loss and wears bilateral hearing aids. He is not aware of clenching or bruxing at night or during the day.

CLINICAL EXAMINATION
:
In frontal view, B185 has fairly good left to right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 22 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 2 mm. Maxillary midline is fairly close to being on the facial midline. In profile view, B185 has some slight AP maxillary deficiency maybe about 3 to 4 mm. Infraorbital hypoplasia with the infraorbital rims being probably about 6 mm deficient. The chin is probably 12 to 15 mm AP deficient. Maxillary teeth actually are more retruded than the maxilla is because the teeth are retruded posteriorly fairly significantly. Intraorally, B185 is missing lower first bicuspids but has the rest of his teeth back through the second molars. The lower teeth are in a little bit in lingual inclination. It shows some of the root. In the upper arch, he is missing first bicuspids. He has the rest of the teeth back through the second molars. He has basically a Class II end-on cuspid relationship on the right side by probably 3 mm but on the left side closer to Class I relationship. He has probably about almost 5 mm vertical overbite. Oropharyngeal areas look reasonably healthy. There is evidence of a previous UPPP procedure and B185 remembered that he had that done in approximately 18 years ago, but experienced no improvement in his airway following that procedure. He also has tried the Thornton appliance but this did not improve the situation and actually only made his teeth loose. Intranasally, the septum appears fairly straight. He has probably had previous turbinectomies. Perhaps on the left side, however, there are some of the turbinates still remaining posteriorly but there does appear to be adequate air space inferior and there appears to be adequate airway on both sides. Even with the UPPP procedure, B185 is aware of having some mild snoring. He has some moderate to severe daytime somnolence. He has moderate to severe sleep apnea issues. TMJ joints seem to function smoothly. He has no apparent tenderness around the head and neck area.

Incisal opening is about 42 mm counting the overbite. Excursive movements are about 9 mm in each direction and opening is 42 mm.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
:
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars and all four first bicuspids. He has root canals on the maxillary left second molar and left lateral incisor. He has a crown on the maxillary left first molar and central and lateral incisors. There are bone plates present in the maxilla. Bone screws are present in the mandible. He has bone plates in the anterior mandible from his previous chin procedure. There are some bony defects present in that area. The condyles look reasonably good. The styloid processes are hypercalcified and elongated.

Waters view shows that the right nasal airway appears wide open and the left one appears that there is some turbinate and that may be the area seen posteriorly and may obstruct that side some. The bony septum at least is straight. The sinuses look relatively clear.

Right TMJ tomogram shows that the condyle appears narrow anteroposteriorly. There appears to be adequate joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Left TMJ tomogram shows that there is probably adequate joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Condyle is hard to identify. On opening, there is moderately good translation of the condyles.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that there is AP retrusion of maxilla and mandible. There is slight increase in the occlusal plane angle but too much. The chin is strong relative to AP position of the mandible. Upper incisors are actually angled posteriorly. Oropharyngeal airway measures less than 3 mm (normal AP dimension would be 11 mm.) At the soft palate level, the airway measures about 6 mm.

BASIC DIAGNOSES: AP maxillary deficiency.
AP mandibular deficiency.
AP macrogenia.
Significantly decreased inclination of maxillary incisors. Missing all four first bicuspids and all four third molars.
Severely reduced oropharyngeal airway with an AP dimension of 2.5 mm (normal dimension of 11 mm.)
Severe sleep apnea.
Moderately increased occlusal plane angle.
Class II end-on occlusion on the right side but fairly close to being a Class I on the left side. Anterior deep bite of 5 mm. Previous double jaw surgery performed 4 months ago.

RECOMMENDED TREATMENT:
Presurgical orthodontics.
Align and level maxillary arch. Open up first bicuspid spacing by pushing the anterior teeth forward to increase angulation of the upper incisors as well as to distalize the posterior teeth at least a couple of mm. Open up the space to equal the size of a first bicuspid tooth approximately 7 mm. This should tip the upper incisors forward at least 5 mm from their current position.
Align and level mandibular arch. Surgery.
Maxillary osteotomies to advance the maxilla about 2 to 3 mm and downgraft it posteriorly approximately 4 mm. Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible forward approximately 14 to 15 mm. Consider possible extraction of second molars if impingement on the discal tissues of the mandible.
Consider possible anterior mandibular horizontal osteotomy to set the chin backwards about 3 to 4 mm. Removal of previously placed maxillary bone plates x4 and screws x22 as well as removal of mandibular bone plates x2 and screws x13.
Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.
Bilateral maxillary osteointegrated implants to the first bicuspid area.
Restorative dentistry to place crowns on the maxillary first bicuspid implants.

original_note:
B064
B064 is 22 years old. B064 was referred by XXXX. B064 problems began likely when she was 13 or 14 years of age. At the age of 14 is when she first became aware of clicking and popping in her joints. It was noted when she was wearing elastics for orthodontic reasons. She had orthodontics from age 14 to 17 years old. After removal of her appliances, she noted her bite was started to shift. She went back into orthodontics from age 19 to 20 years old. She had double jaw orthognathic surgery in two years ago by Dr. XXXX. Primary concerns that B064 has at this time include the following:

Lower jaw is becoming recessive again. Bite is opened anteriorly. Crepitus noises in the jaws. Painful jaw muscles.
Drooling.
Headaches. Difficulties breathing through the nose.

Additional treatments that B064 has had includes chiropractic treatment, facial massage therapy, and speech therapy. The only medication she takes is Motrin for her pain.

B064 gets headaches at about a level of 3 in the temporal and posterior head area. She rates her TMJ pain at 8, average daily pain at 4, jaw function and diet at 5, disability at 8. She gets occasional earaches, but no tinnitus, vertigo, or hearing loss. The only other joint that bothers her is her right shoulder. She is aware of clenching her teeth at night. She is predominantly a mouth breather particularly at night and to a moderate extent during the day. She is unaware of snoring, has mild daytime somnolence, but no sleep apnea. Post surgery, B064 did develop an infection in the left maxillary area and Dr. XXXX had to go in and remove the bone plate and screws.

In frontal view, B064 has fairly good left-to-right symmetry. Upper lip length is 21 mm. Upper tooth lip relationship is about 3.5 mm. The maxillary midline is slightly to the right about 1 mm. The mandibular dental midline is probably 2 mm to the right and so is the chin. Upper lip supralabrale is probably a good 3 mm posterior to subnasale. The maxilla is probably deficient about 6 to 8 mm. The mandible is retruded about 15-18 mm. The chin neckline is short. Intraorally, B064 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars. She has a 3 x 3 lower retainer. She has very thin tissue around the anterior teeth that appears to be stable. In the upper arch, B064 has all of her teeth back through the second molars present. She has palatal tori present. She has a Class II end-on occlusion being approximately 4 or 5 mm Class II. She has an anterior open bite of about 2 mm. She has an overjet of about 3 mm. In centric relation, the mandibular dental midline is actually about 3 mm off towards the right side as is the chin. Oropharyngeal tissues look normal and healthy. Intranasally, the turbinates appear moderately enlarged and probably are blocking the airway. To palpation, she has moderate pain over the temporalis muscles, posterior neck and shoulders. She has audible crepitation particularly in the left joint, but also crepitation in the right joint. The maximal incisal opening is 51 mm, opening with comfort 32 mm. Excursion movement to the right 9 mm, to the left 10 mm. When B064 occludes, she hits only on the second molars and all other teeth are out of occlusion.

RADIOGRAPHIC EVALUATION
Panorex shows the absence of all four third molars. She has four bone screws in the left ramus and three in the right ramus. The sinuses appear relatively clear. A 3 x 3 retainer can be seen in the lower arch.

Coronal view shows that the turbinates are quite large. The septum is reasonably straight. Sinuses appear relatively clear.
Axial view shows that there is a little deviation of the septum off towards the right side. The turbinates are quite large and appear to obstruct most of the nasal airway. The sinuses appear relatively clear.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows that she has severe arthritis in the left TMJ with significant loss of condylar volume. There are some small pseudocysts in the joint. The articular eminence is relatively flat.

Right TMJ sagittal view also has severe arthritis with significant loss of condylar volume. The articular eminence is slightly steeper on this side compared to the opposite side. The condyle is narrow mediolaterally.

Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has undergone severe arthritic changes. The fossa also has undergone significant arthritic changes. There is a pseudocyst in the head of the condyle. There is medial beaking of the condyle. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 mm. There is significantly decreased superior joint space.

Right TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that appears to have lost more volume than the opposite side and is a little bit more narrow mediolaterally. Significant decreased vertical joint space is present. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2-3 mm.

Lateral cephalometric radiograph shows that B064 has a significantly retruded maxilla and particularly the mandible. She has a high occlusal plane angle. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 5 to 6 mm at the soft palate level and about 5 mm at the base of the tongue. She has a skeletal Class II relationship and an anterior open bite.

Basic diagnoses for B064 would be as follows:
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis and articular disc dislocations with severe deformation and nonreducing (probable AICR).
Maxillary AP and posterior vertical hypoplasia.
Mandibular AP hypoplasia.
Class II occlusion. High occlusal plane angle.
Occluding only on the second molars bilaterally.
Hypertrophied turbinates with nasal airway obstruction. Decreased oropharyngeal airway. TMJ pain.
Headaches. Myofascial pain.

Recommended treatment would be as follows:
1. Presurgical orthodontics. a.	Align and level mandibular arch. b.	Align and level maxillary arch.
2. CAT scan of jaws and jaw joints (TMJ Concepts protocol).
3. Surgery. a.	Bilateral TMJ reconstruction with mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses. b.	Multiple maxillary osteotomies to advance it in a counterclockwise direction. c.	Bilateral TMJ fat grafts (harvest from the abdomen). d.	Bilateral coronoidotomies. e.	Bilateral partial turbinectomies.
4. Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion.

B064 MRI
Left TMJ coronal view shows a condyle that has significant condylar resorption and destruction. There are also degenerative changes in the fossa. The lateral rim curves inferiorly about 2 or 3 mm. There is some fluid in the superior joint space. There may be discal tissue anterior to the condyle.

Right TMJ condyle is a little bit wider in width, but still a lot of loss of vertical volume. There is less degeneration in the fossa on this side. The lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly about 2 mm. There may be a little fluid in this joint space as well.

Left TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that has undergone severe degenerative changes with loss of vertical volume. There is some mushrooming out of the condylar head. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced, severely degenerated and deformed, and extremely anteroposteriorly. There is degenerative changes in the fossa. The articular eminence is moderately steep. On opening, there is some restricted translation. The articular disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

Right TMJ sagittal view shows a condyle that similarly has undergone significant degenerative changes. The articular disc is anteriorly displaced, although in slightly better condition than the opposite side. The articular eminence has a moderate inclination. The fossa appears quite broad in width compared to the size of the condyle. The articular disc is significantly degenerated. On opening, there is some restriction in translation, but the disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

IMPRESSION:
Bilateral TMJ severe arthritis with significant destruction of the condyles. Bilateral disc displacements with severe degenerative changes and nonreducing. The patient probable candidate for total joint prostheses.

original_note:
B372 
B372 is 40 years old and is referred by Dr. _.
Patient History
B372 has had a previous laparoscopy 12 years ago. B372 is in good health except for her jaw problems. She was on WELLBUTRIN when she filled out the form, but it caused her to be jittery, and she since has discontinued it. She has had an adverse reaction to PENICILLIN. She apparently got hives in the past when she has taken penicillin.

B372's problems began when she was about 14 or 15 years of age in reference to her TMJ problems. The etiology is unknown. She tolerated things fairly well, and in the past year-and-a-half she has really developed significant pain, headache, and dysfunction problems. She did finally get a splint this year, and the splint does help by reducing the pain. She chronically holds the lower jaw forward as it feels better in that position. If she goes back into a centric relation, she has severe pain. She has taken Vicodin occasionally but also has taken aspirin and Excedrin for migraines most of the time.

Patient Concerns
Headaches that progress into migraines
Severe pain in the TMJ joints
Difficulties opening her jaws
Difficulties eating and chewing
Teeth and jaws don't fit together properly
She has to posture her jaw forward to try to achieve relief
Lower jaw is becoming progressively more retruded
Earaches
Tinnitus
Frequent vertigo
Hearing loss
Frequently wakes up with headaches at least 50% of the time
Nighttime clenching and grinding of the teeth
Daytime clenching
Not sleeping well
Snoring
Even though she has been an aerobics instructor for years, lately she feels as though she gets out of breath just walking and can't catch her breath
Breathlessness problems
Difficulties breathing through her nose
Chronic fatigue

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, B372 has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 24 mm. Upper tooth-to-lip relationship is about 2.5 mm. Maxillary midline is pretty much on the facial midline. Mandibular dental midline and chin are shifted to the right about 1 to 2 mm.

In profile view, B372 has fairly good balance between the upper lip, cheeks, and nose. Chin is retruded, and chin-neckline is short. Chin-neck angle is poorly defined. Chin is probably about 15 mm AP deficient. She does have some mild crenations on the tongue. Intraorally, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. Some moderate crowding, lower anterior arch. Slight accentuated curve of occlusion, lower arch. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars. Some mild crowding, upper anterior arch. B372 has a Class II occlusion. She has an overjet of probably about 4 mm. In manipulating her jaw back into a centric relation, it is quite uncomfortable for her. She is about 5 mm Class II bilaterally. Difficult to visualize the soft palate and uvula but was able to see it, and tissues look healthy. Transverse width of the oropharynx appears as though it could be somewhat narrow. Turbinates are moderately enlarged intranasally. She does have some constricture of the luminal valves.

To palpation, she does have some mild tenderness over the TMJs and styloid areas. All other areas are free of pain or discomfort. Maximal incisal opening is 48 mm. Excursive movements are 10 mm in each direction. She can fairly easily open up, but if she tries to go through repeated openings, it becomes quite painful for her to do that.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows crowns on the mandibular first molars, maxillary right first molar, and the tooth also has a root canal on it. Sinuses appear relatively clear. Difficult to evaluate turbinates. Condyles appear arthritic with the right side being worse than the left side. The right side appears as though it has an erosion in the center of it.

Left TMJ tomogram shows a condyle with severe arthritis and significant anterior beaking present. Fossa has a moderate slope to it. The patient may not have been all the way back in centric relation with this radiograph, but nonetheless the condyle is quite arthritic in appearance.

Right TMJ tomogram appears to be taken in more of a centric relation as compared to the opposite side. Decreased posterior joint space, and appears that there is a little osteophyte perhaps extending posteriorly off the condylar head that appears to almost touch against the posterior wall of the fossa. Articular eminence is of moderate inclination. Significant anterior beaking is present. Appears to be an erosion in the center of the condylar head.

Opening views show fairly good translation of both condyles. The condyles are quite arthritic.
Waters view shows that the sinuses appear fairly clear with the left one being just a little bit more cloudy than the right side. Ethmoid and frontal sinuses look clear. Turbinates appear to fill a good part of the nasal cavity.

Cephalometrically, B372 has a Class II skeletal relationship. She has a high occlusal plane angle. Oropharyngeal airway actually looks not as bad as one might expect. Airway at the soft palate level is about 7 mm and at the base of the tongue is about 8 mm. She has posterior vertical maxillary deficiency. On the lateral ceph, her head is tipped upwards which will increase the airway. B372 has an aunt and her dad who have severe arthritic problems in multiple joints. No significant tooth-size discrepancy is present.

Basic Diagnoses
Bilateral TMJ severe reactive arthritis
AP mandibular deficiency
Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency
Class II occlusion
High occlusal plane angle
Mild crowding, lower anterior arch
Mild crowding, upper anterior arch
AP microgenia
Hypertrophied turbinates
Nasal airway obstruction
Decreased oropharyngeal airway dimension
Severe TMJ pain
Severe headaches
Earaches Tinnitus
Vertigo
Hearing loss

Recommended Treatment
Presurgical orthodontics Align and level maxillary arch Align and level mandibular arch
CT scan of TMJs and jaws (TMJ Concepts protocol)

Surgery
Bilateral TMJ reconstruction and mandibular advancement with TMJ Concepts total joint prostheses
Bilateral TMJ fat grafts
Bilateral coronoidectomies
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to downgraft the posterior aspect and upright the incisors
HTR implant to anterior mandible

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
Other Systems
B372 does have problems with her hips and knees. She has never had any urinary tract infections, but she does have polyuria; however, she drinks a lot of water. When she has her period, she has excessive pain. She has had two children, ages 14 and 16, and no miscarriages. She was diagnosed as having endometriosis when she was younger and was told she wouldn't be able to have children. She has had lots of problems with ovarian cysts. She had pelvic inflammatory disease x 1. She had an abnormal Pap smear once, and she had cryosurgery, and this was at the age of 37. She used to have problems with vaginal yeast infections with the use of panty hose, but she doesn't wear those anymore and no longer has a problem. She had gingivitis x 1. She does have earaches, tinnitus, vertigo, and has loss of hearing. No known STDs. She is tired a lot. She gets palpitations of her heart during her periods. For about a year-and-a-half recently, they had three parakeets. One of them died. Her sister has two love birds and a parrot that she spends a fair amount of time with. She has had a cat for about a year. They have had guinea pigs in the past. She has had several outside dogs.

B372 MRI Evaluation 
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading: 
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that appears to have undergone some significant condylar resorption. Cortical bone may not be intact all the way across. The superior cortex looks a little raggedy. Fossa appears a little bit rough but could be just the quality of the MRI. Significantly decreased joint space vertically. Mild downward curvature of the lateral rim of the fossa. Discal tissue not identifiable.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle that appears to have significant arthritis associated with it. Condyle looks quite sclerotic and appears as though there has been significant resorption. Condyle very narrow mediolaterally. This joint may have had previous surgery. Lateral rim of the fossa curves inferiorly quite significantly, and it appears as though there is reactive bone extending down from the lateral rim of the fossa. Bone in the fossa looks fairly thin.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that is narrow anteroposteriorly. Appears to have lost a lot of vertical height and volume of the condyle. Significant anterior beaking is present. May be some discal tissue anteriorly but appears to be fairly degenerated. Decreased vertical joint space. Could possibly be some erosions even in the fossa articular eminence area but difficult to verify. Discal tissue definitely is anteriorly displaced.

On opening, there is fairly good translation of the condyle, and it appears that the remnant of the discal tissue remains anteriorly displaced.
Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows a condyle that has undergone severe condylar resorption with loss of vertical height and anteroposterior dimension. Significant anterior beaking or osteophytic formation in the front. Some cratering out of the condylar head toward the medial side. Appears to be some remnant of discal tissue sitting beneath the articular eminence. May be erosions in the fossa area.

On opening, there is moderately good translation of the condyle as it comes down beneath the articular eminence, but the remnant of the articular disc remains anteriorly displaced without reduction.

Impression:
Left TMJ severe arthritis with articular disc dislocation with severe deformation and nonreducing
Right TMJ severe arthritis with articular disc dislocation with severe deformation and nonreducing

B237 is 28 years old and referred by Dr. _______.
Patient Concerns
Severe headaches Clicking and popping in the jaw joints
Patient History

The only previous surgery has had is on his left wrist. is in good health except for a headache everyday. He takes Lortab 10. Bilateral TMJ injections with Marcaine

original_note:
B375
B375 is 12 years old and referred by Dr.  .
Patient History
She may have ADD, and she does take Adderall XR 10 mg once a day, and this has significantly helped her abilities to focus. Otherwise she has no other problems. B375 does get headaches when she chews gum particularly. She also gets headaches at other times. She does tend to get headaches about three to four times per week. B375's problems began about one year ago of unknown etiology. She just began developing headaches. She rates her headaches at a level of 5, and she gets these three to four times per week primarily in the temporal areas. Chewing gum will set it off and create headaches for her. She states no pain in the TMJ area, but her overall pain levels on an average day are about at 5, jaw function at 1, diet at 0, and disability at 6.

Clinical Examination
In frontal view, she has fairly good left-to-right facial symmetry. Upper lip length is about 20 mm. Upper tooth to lip relationship is about 5 mm. Maxillary, mandibular, and chin midlines are all pretty much on the facial midline.

In profile view, she has fairly good balance between the upper lips, cheeks, and nose. Chin is retruded by probably about 15 mm. Upper lip might be just a little bit retruded by maybe about 3 mm.

Intraorally, B375 has all of her lower teeth back through the second molars present. She has some moderate crowding, lower anterior arch. She has really thin attached gingiva around the lower anterior teeth. In the upper arch, she has all of her teeth back through the second molars present. She has basically a Class I cuspid-molar relationship. She has an overjet of probably about 3 mm. She has an overbite of about 2 to 3 mm. Oropharynx is clear. Uvula is moderately large. A little difficult for her to relax her tongue.

To palpation, she has mild discomfort over the temporalis, masseters, TMJs, styloids, SCMs, and milder discomfort over the posterior neck, shoulders, and medial pterygoids. TMJs actually seem to function reasonably smoothly.

Intranasally, she does have an enlarged turbinate on the right side but not so much on the left side at least anteriorly. She does have a wide columella base and narrow nostrils. She has some constricture of the luminal valves intranasally. Holding the nostrils open significantly improved her abilities to breathe through her nose. She is aware that she breathes predominantly through her mouth at night when she sleeps.

Radiographic Evaluation
Panorex shows the presence of four developing but unerupted third molars with little room for them to erupt in. All other teeth are present. Sinuses look clear. Nasal airway looks reasonably good. Condyles appear a little bit flattened on the anterior surfaces bilaterally, more so on the left side as compared to the right side. No significant pathology identified.

Left TMJ tomograms show a condyle with fairly good morphology but a little bit flattened anteriorly. Appears to be decreased vertical joint space. Articular eminence is moderately steep. A little bit of anterior beaking present in one of the views.

Right TMJ tomogram shows a condyle that appears a little bit smaller as compared to the opposite side. Flattening on the anterior head of the condyle. Joint space looks a little bit better balanced on this side. Articular eminence is moderately steep.

Opening views show good translation of the condyles bilaterally.
Panorex shows that there is a high occlusal plane angle. Appears to be a skeletal Class II relationship. Some slight anterior vertical maxillary excess and probably posterior vertical maxillary deficiency. Some adenoid tissue still remaining in the nasopharynx area. Oropharyngeal airway measures about 6 mm at the soft palate level and about 9 mm at the base of the tongue. Has hyperfunction of the mentalis muscle forcing her lips closed. B375 does snore at times when she is sleeping. The parents note that when they do go in and observe her sleeping that if she is not grinding her sleep, she is sleeping with her mouth fairly wide open. There is a tooth-size discrepancy of about 2 mm. There is also a slight tooth-size discrepancy in the bicuspid area of probably about 0.5 mm with each tooth, although this can work in our favor. With the tooth-size discrepancy, it tends to allow B375 to be in a Class I cuspid relationship, but as we get close to the molars, the molars are in a little bit more of a Class II end-on relationship.

Basic Diagnoses
Bilateral TMJ arthritis and articular disc dislocations (rule out idiopathic condylar resorption)
Anterior vertical maxillary excess
Posterior vertical maxillary deficiency
AP mandibular deficiency
AP microgenia
Tooth-size discrepancy with a Bolton's difference of 2 mm
Tooth-size discrepancy in the bicuspid area with the lower bicuspid being about 0.5 mm larger than the upper bicuspids
Class I cuspid relationship but Class II end-on molar relationship due to tooth-size discrepancy Moderate crowding, lower anterior arch
High occlusal plane angulation
Impacted maxillary and mandibular third molars x 4
Lack of attached gingiva around the lower anterior arch (could possible require some gingival grafting to provide quality attached gingiva) Headaches TMJ pain
Myofascial pain
Wide columella base creating narrow nostrils
Constricture of intranasal luminal valves
Nasal airway obstruction
Predominant mouth breather

Recommended Treatment
Surgery, Stage I
Bilateral TMJ articular disc repositioning and ligament repair with Mitek anchors
Reconstruction of columella Bilateral reconstruction of nasal luminal valves with placement of stents
Consider small chin augmentation of 5 mm

Orthodontics
Align and level maxillary arch
Align and level mandibular arch. Strip lower anterior teeth removing 2 mm of tooth structure. Also, strip lower bicuspids removing 0.5 mm of tooth structure from each four lower bicuspids and retract maximizing posterior anchorage

Surgery, Stage II
Multiple maxillary osteotomies to move the anterior aspect superiorly, posterior aspect inferiorly, and advance it
Bilateral mandibular ramus osteotomies to advance the mandible in a counterclockwise direction
Surgical removal of four bony impacted third molars

Postsurgical orthodontics to refine occlusion
B375 MRI Evaluation 
Date of Acquisition:	
Date of Reading:	
Left TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with good mediolateral width. Decreased joint space at the lateral aspect. Discal tissue seen to be medially displaced. Cortical bone appears to be intact over the top of the condyle. Lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat.

Right TMJ, coronal view, shows a condyle with fairly good mediolateral width. Some depression in the superior cortex. Decreased vertical joint space. Appears that there may be some discal tissue medially. Condyle must be angled significantly in three different views. Lateral rim of the fossa is fairly flat.

Left TMJ, sagittal view, shows some flattening of the anterior head of the condyle and some anterior beaking present. Articular eminence is moderately steep. Out laterally, the disc is not as well seen. The disc is in a vertical orientation between the condyle and fossa and is displaced anteriorly. May be some inflammation in the bilaminar tissues and a little bit of fluid in the inferior joint space.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyle, and the disc does reduce and translates reasonably well also.
Right TMJ, sagittal view, shows there is significant anterior beaking of the condyle. Articular eminence is steep and extremely long in vertical length particularly out laterally. Decreased vertical joint space. Disc is anteriorly displaced particularly toward the lateral aspect of the joint. More medially, the disc appears that it may be in a little bit better position. There does not appear to be a significant inflammatory process in this joint.

On opening, there is good translation of the condyle, and the disc appears to reduce on opening and also translates fairly well itself.
Impression:
Left TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly and medially displaced with reduction
Right TMJ arthritis and articular disc anteriorly and medially displaced with reduction
